story:
Summary

SB TIYA is a student-led theater company aimed at providing a voice to young artists in the Santa Barbara community. Our first production will be Frank Wedekind’s SPRING AWAKENING (the play, not the musical). The provocative and controversial story takes on the theme of miscommunication between teens and adults regarding sexuality, mental health, and freedom of expression in 1880’s Germany.


What We Need & What You Get

Creating a whole show, especially as students, is not easy. We want to be able to share our art with the Santa Barbara community, but there are expenses that need to be covered. Here's where you come in! 

For $5, we will be able to purchase one costume piece and you will receive social media recognition.

For $15, we will be able to print 25 posters and you will receive 2 refreshment tickets (pick up at will call) and recognition on social media.

For $30, we will be able to pay for photography expenses and you will receive a thank you card signed by the cast, 2 tickets, recognition on social media and in program, and 2 refreshment tickets. 

For $50, we will be able to purchase lighting and you will receive 2 reserved seats, a thank you card signed by the cast, recognition on social media and in program, and 2 refreshment tickets. 

For $100, we will be one step closer to covering the expense of our venue, and you will receive an onstage thank you, 4 reserved seats, a thank you card signed by the cast, recognition on social media and in program, and 2 refreshment tickets.

For $500, we will be able to fund the majority of our show and we'd be forever thankful for your kindness. You will be the show's official sponsor with front-page program and poster recognition, receive an onstage thank you, 5 reserved seats, a thank you card signed by the cast, recognition on social media, and 2 refreshment tickets. 

The Impact

The Santa Barbara Theatre Initiative for Young Adults' goal is to get youth involved in every aspect of producing a show: from directing to performing, while also allowing them to discover their own strengths and passions by testing and extending their boundaries. 
We hope to provide a voice to young artists by incorporating relevant themes and making our art accessible to the Santa Barbara community. By donating, you can help us achieve our goal and share our passion and art with the community. 


Don't forget to come see the show!

Spring Awakening will be on January 8, 9, 10 - event details coming soon!

Even if you can't donate, please share this link and spread the word. Every little bit counts!

story:
Our Story So Far

Ignight Dance Fitness can be described in one word: Passion. We have unbridled passion for community, exercise, dance, love, joy, inspiration and acceptance.

In the beginning, we had a dream to share the hottest dance fitness classes with all people: small and large, old and young, gay and straight--everyone is welcome.

We achieved this dream with our incredible community: our fantastic instructors, our attentive and caring front desk staff, and all of you--our awesome supporters!

The Next Chapter

We're very grateful for Ignight's success, but it's time to take this concept to the next level with:

  • A larger space with plenty of PARKING!
  • An extended schedule. No more classes only after 5pm--we are going to be open and running classes all day long!
  • More formats: 6am Rise & Grind class, XXX Step, Kickboxing and kids classes.  We are creating our new schedule based on your feedback and desires. This means more hot instructors and the RETURN of a few of your favs!
  • Childcare. Our childcare professionals will have experience with children of various ages, strong references, infant and child CPR, and first-aid certification. Also, we will require a background check before employment.
  • More workshops: Dance Instructor Academy 1 & Dance Instructor Academy II, Technique Basics, Intro to Zumba, Intro to FierceFunk, TwerkShop, and more in the works!

We Need Your Help!

We've found our new home, but we need funds to build out the space to be PERFECT for you. We've heard your thoughts on flooring & childcare, as well as your desire for a shower and changing rooms. Please help us make this a reality!

The new studio is a 4000 sq ft shell. Here are some key components of our build-out list and where your contributions will be vital to our success:

  • 3500 sq feet of Dura dance floors
  • Huge, new stage
  • Shower build-out
  • New front desk
  • Childcare area + toys and entertainment equipment
  • Extra speaker + subwoofer
  • New dividing wall between bathrooms, showers, changing rooms and main studio
  • Ignight's signature blacklights
  • Workshop space in the back with mirrors

We are extremely thankful for our community of supporters and we promise to spend each dollar that is pledged wisely. Every bit of your support counts; we won't be able to do this without you!

THANK YOU!!!

Opening night at Ignight v1. What will v2 look like?

Risks and challenges

Lease 
We are right in the middle of signing a lease, as you can imagine, there are lots of details and scenarios to imagine. We have an amazing new landlord and are very optimistic that the process will go smoothly.

Permits
We need an occupancy permit. Shouldn't be a problem, but we are good friends with Murphy's Law. Good thing we've got friends in the permitting office, too!

Zoning
Good news!! Our new studio falls in Fairfax county (JUST barely). This means we are good to go with zoning. We are considered "by right" allowed to operate a dance studio in the space. We have to get this confirmed, but we feel comfortable this is a fairly easy check-box.

Construction snafus
Hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes, and floods any act of God could halt or delay our plans. Thankfully, we've got an amazing contractor AND our new landlord is also a contractor who can complete our build-out as a plan B without affecting our launch plans.

story:
Dear Friends,

We are raising $10,000 to organise International Dance Week Budapest, a one week workshop for dancers and non dancers with teachers from world-wide acclaimed companies. The magic will happen this summer, July 14-18, Budapest!





About International Dance Week Budapest

IDW Budapest is organised by SUB.LAB Collective, a dancetheater group based in Budapest. The members of the collective (Adrienn Acs, David Miko, Peter Juhasz) are young artists who acquired their artistic knowledge from different places in Europe. We see this festival as a messenger of dance and art that aims to bring people together.

IDW Budapest is an annual gathering for dancers and nondancers where everyone can find their match in a broad spectrum of classes. It is a place to share their experiences, to share their passion of dance and gain knowledge. Each participant meets the chance to improve and enhance his abilities, both physical and emotional.
Our primary focus is on the high level of quality therefore we invite teachers from all over the world and we would like to involve more and more people each year. Therefore the success of this festival and to continue it in the future is very important.
The first IDW Budapest was organised last year which was a great succes with more than 100 participants in a week with the help of SIN Culture Center.


THIS SUMMER...



This summer each day will consist of different classes such as: technique classes, repertory, physical theater, improvisation, composition, yoga and floor-work.
Participants will be given the opportunity to explore their own creative ideas by taking part in impro jams each night.

Our guest teachers:
Julia Robert Pares  - Jasmin Vardimon company
Csaba Varga - Les Ballets C de la B
Livia Balazova - Ultima Vez
David Miko - Sub.lab collective
Wies Van Houplines - GAGA - Ohad Naharin movement language
Peter Juhasz - Les Ballets c de la b
Purusa Sukta Das - Hatha yoga
Adrienn Acs - Sub.lab collective



 HOW YOU CAN HELP

We are delighted to invite those individuals who feel able and motivated to give donations to make International Dance Week Budapest happen again this summer.

When you donate any amount, you will be helping SUB.LAB Collective the organiser team of IDW Budapest.

Your contribution will support us to:
  •  rent the whole SIN Culture Center with its 4 studios + 1 kitchen
  •  cover overhead costs
  •  cover the travel + accomodation expenses of our teachers
  •  provide food for our participants
  •  ensure teachers' salary
  •  arrange press and marketing
  •  rent equipments (yoga mats and blocks)

We now need your participation to raise $10,000 in our first Indiegogo campaign Please make this possible and donate now to our project.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us make some noise about our campaign!  Share this with your friends and family to help us get the word out about our campaign!
THANK YOU!

story:
Check out this teaser for a preview of our show!

Cal VSA Culture Show is a space that lets us build family and lifelong friends and foster creativity as we all work towards the same goal.

The Culture Show experience lets us try new things and helps us grow as we learn and educate about Vietnamese history, community, and culture through the show. Without the Culture Show space, we would be limited to conventional tools for developing awareness of our culture and the contemporary issues that our community faces. 

Every year, since the establishment of Cal VSA at Berkeley in 1978, the Cal VSA Culture Show brings together students, Vietnamese and non-Vietnamese alike, to produce an integrated theatrical production of music, dance, drama, and prose. This integration of creative disciplines sets our show apart from the typical Vietnamese "variety show." Our production always focuses on a contemporary issue affecting the Vietnamese and Vietnamese American communities. In recent years, we have discussed the topics of family & generation gap, of human trafficking, and of adoption history.

Your contribution to our campaign will fund the items that we design and create ourselves.

Our show is on April 12. The script is written, our crew is assembled, and we already have a cast. We've also secured a venue, but the world-class stage of Zellerbach Hall costs a whopping $18,000 on its own!

We're asking you to help us with the creative expenses. The funds raised will go directly and immediately into use for our marketing collateral, backdrops, stage props, and costumes. $3,500 is the amount we need to get the minimum amount of supplies.

This year, our show is about acceptance, about resilience, and about love.

Ảo Ảnh: Between the Lines opens the book on one family and their history of mental illness. It tells the story of a mother and daughter, Jennifer and Kasey, struggling to overcome the taboo of talking about mental illness.

Mental illness is a difficult topic to discuss, and it tends to be ignored and downplayed in many families and communities, but pretending that it doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Through this show, we wish to portray the consequences of untreated mental illness and the importance of communication and acceptance, especially within the family. Although there are many who may not necessarily understand or know how to treat or to cope with a mental illness, we believe that everyone has the ability to take the first step — everyone has the ability to speak up.

Help us spread the word! Share our campaign with your friends and followers on Facebook, Twitter, email, and other outlets.

Not satisfied with our perks? Let us know what you want to see. Contact us at cultureshow@calvsa.com.

Don't forget that you can also contribute without choosing one of the perks. Just click on the bright pink "CONTRIBUTE NOW" button :)

story:
Hello lovers of poetry and comedy and Slam Up! For those of you who don't know us, we are Cali and Emily, co-founders of The Slam Up Tour, a show in which we rap, sing, spit (poetry), & grab you by the heartstrings with our tales of the many shades of love-- requited, unrequited, gay, straight,queer, or, well, just "creative." Slam Up has improvised characters and dance parties and merriment to be had by all!

BUT the show on the road has stalled out. Literally. Our car won't work.

We have already had to cancel two performances, and in order to get the show back on the road for our 25+ future gigs we NEED to get Rhonda our Honda fully operational.

Unfortunately this means $2700+ in labor and parts. All my non-mechanic brain can decipher is that our radiator cracked and flooded the engine with water. I don't know what this means other than that it's bad and expensive.

ANYTHING you can give (us and Phillip DaJar understand that everyone be struggle bussin'), will help us absorb the costs of Rhonda's health issues. This in turn will help us bring Slam Up to our friends who haven't witnessed it yet, AND ensure that we eat and have gas, and all those hairy details that let us share our work with the world.

Our current goal is $500. We want to be clear that The Slam Up Tour will continue on regardless, but anything helps! Good reasons to donate:

  • You have already seen The Slam Up Tour live, FOR FREEZLE, and loved it.
  • You have already seen The Slam Up Tour live, for $$, and loved it.
  • You have yet to see The Slam Up Tour live, but want to ensure that you do!
  • You want to help support sharing creativity!
  • You love Cali and Emily.

Every dollar donated on Indiegogo will go directly to taking care of costs incurred by Rhonda's breakdown. 

If you are unable to give anything, share this with your friends. Every dollar and shout out helps!

story:
Hello Beautiful People!

Dance is for me a balancing act between perfection and beauty. It is a language without words; the expression of our soul. We can't dance in the past or in the future, but dance is always here and now with all of our self!

I am Eva Kolarova, professional dancer and choreographer, originally from Czech Republic. Since the age of 15 I have traveled with dance all over the world. I have lived in 3 different countries and am currently dancing as a demi-soloist with   Les Grands Ballets Canadiens in Montreal for the third year.

I love to dance. But since my childhood I have always felt a desire to create my own steps; my own dance language. So I started to choreograph and  it soon became my passion, and something I want to do in the future  in addition to dancing.

I was recently accepted to the renown dance festival “Quartiers Danses” this September 2014 in Montreal at theatre Le Gesu.

 (For more details:  http://www.quartiersdanses.com/ )

I also plan to bring to life my own full-length performance to introduce to the public next year!

So what I am asking you is to help me meet the costs of attending this great festival and my path to create my new show next year.

Money will be used:

1. pay all the people who are involved in my creation !
2. money on costumes , props ( projector, screen )
3. and most important, remaining money will allow me to rent theater space and technicians for the realization of my full-length performance !

My new creation Cycle will be presented in the festival this fall. It started from a great opportunity to collaborate for the first time with outstanding composer Reiko Yamada, cellist Juan Sebastian Delgado and film director Luciana Marcos in cooperation with cinematographer Derek Branscombe. Reiko composed wonderful music that will be played on stage by cellist, together with the dance and combined with video projection.

Little synopsis of Cycle:

I've always wondered. Everything in nature takes place in certain periods, everything is repeated, each time in a slightly different form, but the basic principles remain unchanged; it's just different variations , viewpoints and under different conditions.
And that fascinates me. I want to capture one story out of thousands. Each human being goes through a period of spring, summer, autumn and winter, but that is not the end , because after winter comes spring again! Every beginning has an end, and without end there would be no beginning!

I live to dance, and I really appreciate all the support you can provide.Whether it will be by making a financial donation and/or spreading the word, I hope that together we can make this new creation a success!

Thank you very much.

Eva Kolarova x

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eva Kolarova  - Biography (Ceske Budejovice, Czech rep.)

Started training at Actors Studio in Prague then at the National Dance Conservatory in Prague. Her great talent, hard work and ambition enabled her as a fifteen years old to gain acceptance to the world-famous school of Maurice Béjart  in Lausanne,Switzerland as the youngest student in the program. She had the good fortune to work with Maurice Béjart and also dance in some of his choreographies with his company “Béjart Ballet Lausanne”.

After completing studies in Lausanne at the age of 17, she passed the audition for the Ballet Academy in Munich - “Hoschule für Kunst und Musik”, where she got a chance to dance with the “Bayerisches  Staatsballett” ( under Ivan Liška ).

After obtaining the diploma, she left Germany and began work in France with the company “Ballet de l 'Opéra National du Rhin”, led by directorBertratnt D´At.
Here she danced for three years, where she had the opportunity to get acquainted with a very large repertoire of classics such as "La Sylphide, and Giselle” amongst many others, and  the works of world-renowned choreographerssuch as j. Kylián, l. Childs, w. Forsythe, m. Béjart, J. Inger, Hans van Manen and dance theatre.


She was also selected to represent the “Ballet du Rhin” at the Gala
"40th Anniversary Gala of Northern Ballet Theatre’s" in Leeds in England.

In spring 2011 she was offered a contract in Montreal, Canada by the director of “Les Grands Ballets Canadiens”,  Gradimir Pankov.
Her dancing has enabled her to travel many countries of the world such as Spain, France, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Germany, Italy, Greece, Holland and South Korea to China and currently, Canada.

Ever since she was young, she was always been invigorated by choreography.  Already as a young student in Germany, she organized and choreographed her first own full-length performance in Prague.
Eva has participated in several choreographic and dance competitions and has won many of them. The jury has always appreciated the precision of her movements, natural elegance, particular personality and her specific poetic expression in dance.

As a choreographer she has worked on performances for the “Ballet du Rhin”, “Reves 6”.
She has also produced three choreographies for the “St-Louis Dance Conservatory” and for the “Mulhouse Dance Conservatory”.
She has been invited to several Gala performances in Prague, and in June 2012 in Seoul, South Korea.

In August 2012 she presented her own full-length performance “Metamorphosis of love” at theatre La Chapelle in  Montreal, Canada.

Currently her main focus is her new creation “Cycles“

For more information, go to: www.eva-kolarova-and-company.com

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Drazí přátelé !

Pro mě je tanec, balancování mezi dokonalostí a krásou, jde o řeč beze slov o projev duše. Nemůžeme tančit v minulosti ani v budoucnosti, ale tančíme vždy tady a teď celým svým já!

Jmenuji se Eva Kolářová a jsem profesionální tanečnice a choreografka, narozená v  České republice. Od svých patnácti let jsem začala, díky tanci, cestovat po celém světě. Žila jsem ve třech různých zemích, a v současné době tančím jako demi - sólistka v Les Grands Balletu Canadiens v Montrealu, již třetím rokem.

Miluji tanec!  Ale už jako malá jsem vždy pociťovala potřebu vytvářet své vlastní kroky, svůj taneční jazyk. A tak se choreografování brzy stalo mou vášní, něčím co chci dělat v budoucnu spolu s tancem.

Momentálně jsem byla vybraná na velmi důležitý choreografický festival – Quartiers Danses, který se koná každoročně v září v Montreálu a pro mě je velkou poctou se ho zúčastnit se svou novou kreací „ Koloběh“ .

( Pro více informací : www.quartiersdanses.com )

Dále chci přivést k životu, své vlastní celovečerní představení a prezentovat ho veřejnosti příští rok !

To o co vás žádám, je pomoc s uhrazením nákladů, které jsou spojené s účastí na festivalu Qurtiers Danses a mou další choreografickou tvorbu směřující k uvedení  celovečerního představení v příštím roce.


Peníze budou použity :


 1. výplata všem lidem, kteří se podílejí na mé kreaci ( tanečníci, skladatelka, režisérka, čelista a technici ) !
2. peníze na kostýmy , rekvizity, ( projektor, plátno )
3. a to nejdůležitější, peníze které zbudou mi umožní pronájem divadelní prostory a techniků, na realizaci mého celovečerního představení !

Má nová choreografie „Koloběh se zrodila z příležitosti spolupráce s vynikající skladatelkou Reiko Yamadou , violoncellistou Juanem Sebastianem Delgadem a režisérkou Lucianou Marcos, ve spolupráci s Dereckem Branscombem .
Reiko pro mě složila nádhernou hudbu a mým cílem je, aby spolu s tancem a videoprojekcí vytvořila dokonalou symbiózu,aby navzájem každá složka násobila svou sílu. Violoncellista bude doprovázet tanečníky během vystoupení na jevišti.

Krátký obsah Koloběhu:

O nos mi zavadila myšlenka, která mě zaujala a od té doby jsem o ní několikrát přemýšlela. V přírodě se všechno odehrává v určitých cyklech, obdobích, vše se opakuje, pokaždé jen v poněkud jiné podobě, ale základ, podstata zůstává beze změny, jde jen o různé varianty, úhly pohledu a odlišné podmínky.                                A to mě fascinuje.

Chci zachytit tento princip v jednom příběhu vyňatém z tisíce podobných, kdy každá lidská bytost projde svým obdobím jara, léta, podzimu a zimy, ale po zimě není konec, protože přichází opět jaro!

Každý začátek má konec a bez konce by nebyl začátek. Jde o nekonečnou spirálu. A my koneckonců jsem jen pouhým vesmírným prachem.

Já tancem žiji! Je to pro mě způsob vyjádření ! A proto opravdu ocením veškerou podporu, kterou mi můžete poskytnout. Ať už to bude finanční dar / nebo šířením slova doufám, že společně dojdeme k cíli!

Děkuju mnohokrát.

Srdečně

Eva Kolářová

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eva Kolářová – životopis

Již jako malé dítě (od 5 let), začala s výukou akrobacie, herectvím, malováním a hraním na klavír.

Teprve později  (od 8 let), začala s výukou moderního tance a baletu.

V 10 letech složila přijímací zkoušky na Státní taneční konzervatoř v Praze. Zároveň pokračovala ve studiu na soukromé umělecké škole Actors Studio.

Její velký talent, píle a ambice, způsobili, že po dalších čtyřech letech studia její otec natočil jak tančí tři náročné, moderní choreografie a zaslal film do Švýcarska.

Díky tomu byla pozvána na konkurz do světoznámé školy Maurice Béjarta v Lausanne, kam posléze v 15 letech ( o rok mladší, než byla školou stanovená spodní věková hranice ) sama odjela studovat.

Měla to obrovské štěstí pracovat se samotným M.Béjartem a též tančit v některých jeho představeních v  souboru „Béjart Ballet Lausanne“ i možnost presentovat se na vystoupení svou vlastní sólovou choreografií.

Po dokončení studií v Lausanne, v 17  letech udělala konkurz do „Baletní Akademie v Mnichově“  - „Hoschule fur Kunst und Musik“, kde mimo jiné také tančila s „Bayerisches Staatsballettem“ pod vedením Ivana Lišky.

Po ukončení vysoké školy a obdržení diplomu, opustila Německo a zároveň dostala nabídku smlouvy ve Francii v souboru „Ballet de l´Opéra National du Rhin“, od ředitele Bertranta D´Ata.

Zde tancovala po dobu tří let, kdy si dále rozvíjela své znalosti díky velmi širokému rejstříku repertoáru od úplné klasiky ( jako např.: „La Sylphide", Giselle aj. ) přes světoznámé choreografy ( jako J.Kylián, L. Childs, W.Forsythe, M.Béjart , J.Inger,Hans van Manen ad. ) až k tanečnímu divadlu.

Také byla vybraná reprezentovat „Ballet du Rhin“ na Gala představení

“40th Anniversary Gala of Northern Ballet Theatre´s” v Leedsu v Anglii, či na Gala v Praze ve Stavovském divadle.

Na jaře 2011 se rozhodla pro změnu a dostala nabídku smlouvy v Montreálu, od Gradimíra Pankova  ředitele divadla „Grands Ballets Canadien“.

S tancem projezdila mnoho zemí světa :  od Španělska,Francie,Lucemburska, Švýcarska,Německa,Itálie, Řecka, Holandska přes Jižní Koreu až  Čínu a momentálně pracuje v Kanadě.

Už od mlada jí přitahovala choreografie jako taková.

Svou první cenu za choreografii získala jako věkově podlimitní ( v 13 letech )

na soutěži Jarmily Jeřábkové v Praze.

Od té doby si průběžně tvořila své choreografie, až během studií v Německu, v roce 2007 poprvé spolu-realizovala celovečerní představení „Taneční portrét Evy Kolářové“, převážně z vlastní tvorby v Praze v divadle ABC.

Mimo jiné se zúčastnila několika choreografických a tanečních soutěží, z kterých si odnesla nejednu první cenu.

Poroty a taneční veřejnost vždy a znova zaujímá precizností pohybu, přirozenou elegancí, svou výraznou osobitostí a jí specifickou poetičností.

Choreograficky spolupracovala na celovečerním představení pro „Ballet du Rhin“.

Také udělala tři choreografie pro Taneční konzervatoř v St.Louise a pro Taneční konzervatoř v Mulhouse.

Byla pozvaná na několik Gala představení v Praze a naposledy v červnu 2012 na Gala do Soulu v Jižní Koreji.

Také úspěšně zrealizovala a uvedla své celovečerní představení „Metamorfózy lásky“ složené z jejích choreografií v divadle La Chapelle 11. a 12.srpna v Montreálu. 

Ohlas místní taneční kritiky byl velmi dobrý.

Momentálně se plně soustředí na svou novou kreaci „Koloběh“, která se uskuteční v Montrealu v rámci choreografického festivalu Quartiers Danses v divadle Le Gesu 13.září 2014.

Pro více informací navštivte web : www.eva-kolarova-and-company.com
story_txt:
Hello Beautiful
People!
Dance is for me a balancing act between perfection and
beauty. It is a language without words; the expression of our soul. We can't
dance in the past or in the future, but dance is always here and now with all of
our self!
I am Eva Kolarova, professional dancer and choreographer,
originally from Czech Republic. Since the age of 15 I have traveled with dance
all over the world. I have lived in 3 different countries and am currently
dancing as a demi-soloist with   Les Grands Ballets Canadiens in
Montreal for the third year.
I love to dance. But since my childhood I have always felt
a desire to create my own steps; my own dance language. So I started to
choreograph and  it soon became my
passion, and something I want to do in the future  in addition to dancing.
I was recently accepted to the renown dance festival “Quartiers
Danses” this September 2014 in Montreal at theatre Le Gesu.
 (For more
details:  http://www.quartiersdanses.com/ )
I also plan to bring to life my own full-length
performance to introduce to the public next year!
So what I am asking you is to help me meet the costs
of attending this great festival and my path to create my new show next year.Money will be used:1. pay all the people who are involved in my creation !2. money on costumes , props ( projector, screen )3. and most important, remaining money will allow me to rent theater space and technicians for the realization of my full-length performance !
My new creation Cycle will be presented in the
festival this fall. It started from a great opportunity to collaborate for the
first time with outstanding composer Reiko Yamada,
cellist Juan Sebastian Delgado and film director Luciana Marcos in cooperation with cinematographer Derek Branscombe. Reiko composed wonderful
music that will be played on stage by cellist, together with the dance and combined
with video projection.
Little synopsis of Cycle:
I've always wondered. Everything in
nature takes place in certain periods, everything is repeated, each time in a
slightly different form, but the basic principles remain unchanged; it's just
different variations , viewpoints and under different conditions.And that fascinates me. I want to capture one
story out of thousands. Each human being goes through a period of spring,
summer, autumn and winter, but that is not the end , because after winter comes
spring again! Every beginning has an end, and without end there would be no
beginning!
I live to dance, and I really appreciate all the
support you can provide.Whether it will be by making a financial donation
and/or spreading the word, I hope that together we can make this new creation a
success! 

Thank you very much.
Eva
Kolarova x-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------





Eva Kolarova  - Biography (Ceske
Budejovice, Czech rep.) 

Started training at Actors Studio in
Prague then at the National Dance Conservatory in Prague. Her great talent,
hard work and ambition enabled her as a fifteen years old to gain acceptance to
the world-famous school of Maurice Béjart  in Lausanne,Switzerland as the youngest student in the program. She had the good fortune to work with Maurice Béjart
and also dance in some of his choreographies with his company “Béjart Ballet
Lausanne”.
After completing studies in Lausanne at the age
of 17, she passed the audition for the Ballet Academy in Munich - “Hoschule für
Kunst und Musik”, where she got a chance to dance with the “Bayerisches 
Staatsballett” ( under Ivan Liška ).
After obtaining the diploma, she left Germany and
began work in France with the company “Ballet de l 'Opéra National du Rhin”,
led by directorBertratnt D´At.
Here she danced for three years, where she had
the opportunity to get acquainted with a very large repertoire of classics such as "La Sylphide, and Giselle” amongst many others, and  the works of world-renowned choreographerssuch as j. Kylián, l. Childs, w.
Forsythe, m. Béjart, J. Inger, Hans van Manen and dance theatre.
She was also selected to represent the “Ballet
du Rhin” at the Gala
"40th Anniversary Gala of Northern Ballet Theatre’s"
in Leeds in England.
In spring 2011 she was offered a contract in
Montreal, Canada by the director of “Les
Grands Ballets Canadiens”,  Gradimir Pankov.
Her dancing has enabled her to travel many countries
of the world such as Spain, France, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Germany, Italy,
Greece, Holland and South Korea to China and currently, Canada.
Ever since she was young, she was always been
invigorated by choreography.  Already as a young student in Germany, she organized and
choreographed her first own full-length performance in Prague. 
Eva has participated in several choreographic and dance competitions and has
won many of them. The jury has always
appreciated the precision of her movements, natural elegance, particular
personality and her specific poetic expression in dance.
As a choreographer she has worked on
performances for the “Ballet du Rhin”, “Reves 6”.
She has also produced three choreographies for the
“St-Louis Dance Conservatory” and for the “Mulhouse Dance Conservatory”.
She has been invited to several Gala
performances in Prague, and in June 2012 in Seoul, South Korea.
In
August 2012 she presented her own full-length performance “Metamorphosis of love” at theatre La Chapelle
in  Montreal, Canada.
Currently her main focus is her new
creation “Cycles“
For more information, go to: www.eva-kolarova-and-company.com-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Drazí přátelé !

story:
Who we are and what we are doing!

We are Super Paua – a theatre company set up in 2013 to make brave work for young audiences.  Our aim is to make socially-focused theatre that inspires and challenges young people, about topics that are relevant to their needs as citizens.  Our first show – Aunty Ben – is about to premiere at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, before transferring to the Brighton Fringe Festival, and we need your help to launch it!

Aunty Ben is a very pioneering show – it is a play for children (and adults!) aged 7+, about a drag queen.  The story revolves around nine-year-old Tracey’s relationship with her favourite aunty, Ben. It doesn't matter to Tracey at all that Aunty Ben is actually her uncle, or that he is a drag queen, because in Tracey’s family dressing up is for everyone! But when Ben meets her school friends, Tracey is shocked to discover that other people’s families can be very different to her own. Aunty Ben is a colourful and playful exploration of gender issues, acceptance, love and happiness created specifically for, and tailored to the needs of, primary school aged children. Most of all, Aunty Ben is a sensitive and entertaining celebration of diversity, dignity, and marching to the beat of your own drum.

Throughout our rehearsal process, we have been inviting contributions from teachers, academics, theatre makers, youth workers and parents, and the positive feedback and support so far has been massive. We are confident that we have a great show, with a very promising future and tonnes of potential for expansion – but first of all, we need to get our Dublin show off the ground.

What We Need & What You Get

We gratefully acknowledge the support of IdeasTap, who awarded us the Brighton Fringe Award 2014, which is funding the travel and accomodation of our UK trip.  However, we still need funds for essential costs in our Dublin show.  The Indiegogo money raised will be spent on…

  • 5 Weeks of Rehearsal Space Rental 
  • Insurance
  • Design, Props and Costumes (Despite our thrifty budgeting, dressing a 6’3’’ man in women's clothing and heels is surprisingly expensive!)
  • Printing, Flyer Distribution, Marketing and PR services
  • Photography and Documentation
  • Technical support for our Brighton shows

In return for a donation to our fundraising campaign, we have a whole host of rewards on offer – from signed programmes, recorded DVD’s of our performance, and show tickets, to an invitation to Super Paua’s official launch party and funders reception!  And of course - our eternal gratitude!

The Impact of Aunty Ben

The relevance and importance of a show like Aunty Ben was best summed up, we think, by Dr Audrey Bryan, of St Patricks Teacher Training College, Dublin…

"From my perspective as a Teacher Educator, Aunty Ben complements beautifully a number of topics covered in the primary school curriculum, and addresses a number of universal themes that are likely to appeal to children and adults alike. It encourages audiences to reflect critically on a range of issues—including the value of being true to oneself, and what it means to be accepting of others and to embrace diversity—in a non-confrontational, energising, and engaging way. It contains many valuable lessons about how social norms can restrict us and shape our interactions with those who refuse to be defined by these norms, and encourages us to reflect on how we relate to others and to ourselves, and how we can overcome our prejudices to accept, affirm and embrace one another in all of our humanity, complexity and diversity" 

We believe that times are changing, and that Ireland is ready for and accepting of strong LGBT role models for their children.  Please allow us to kick start this project, and see how far we can take it!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to Aunty Ben financially (we are in the midst of a recession, after all!) there are other ways you can help!  If you would like to come and see our shows, you can buy tickets on the IDGTF’s website (www.gaytheatre.ie) or at the Brighton Fringe Website (www.brightonfringe.org).

If you are interested in working with us, talking to us, hearing more about our project, or if you know of a school that might be interested in our drama workshops, please contact Sian Ní Mhuirí at info@superpaua.org - we would love to hear from you!

Finally – liking us on Facebook would be a big help!  Our page is www.facebook.com/superpaua

Thanks so much for your time!
story_txt:
Who we are and what we
are doing!
We are Super Paua – a theatre company set up in 2013
to make brave work for young audiences. 
Our aim is to make socially-focused theatre that inspires and challenges young people,
about topics that are relevant to their needs as citizens.  Our first show – Aunty Ben – is about to
premiere at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, before transferring
to the Brighton Fringe Festival, and we need your help to launch it!
Aunty Ben is a very pioneering show – it is a play for children
(and adults!) aged 7+, about a drag queen. 
The story revolves around nine-year-old Tracey’s relationship with her
favourite aunty, Ben. It doesn't matter to Tracey at all that Aunty Ben is
actually her uncle, or that he is a drag queen, because in Tracey’s family
dressing up is for everyone! But when Ben meets her school friends, Tracey is
shocked to discover that other people’s families can be very different to her
own. Aunty Ben is a colourful and playful exploration of gender issues, acceptance,
love and happiness created specifically for, and tailored to the needs of,
primary school aged children. Most of all, Aunty Ben is a sensitive and
entertaining celebration of diversity, dignity, and marching to the beat of
your own drum.
Throughout our rehearsal
process, we have been inviting contributions from teachers, academics, theatre
makers, youth workers and parents, and the positive feedback and support so far
has been massive. We are confident that we have a great show, with a very promising
future and tonnes of potential for expansion – but first of all, we need to get
our Dublin show off the ground.
What We Need &
What You Get
We gratefully acknowledge the support of
IdeasTap, who awarded us the Brighton Fringe Award 2014, which is funding the travel and accomodation of our UK trip.  However, we still
need funds for essential costs in our Dublin show.  The Indiegogo money raised will be spent on… 

5 Weeks of Rehearsal
     Space Rental 
Insurance
Design, Props
     and Costumes (Despite our thrifty budgeting, dressing a 6’3’’ man in
     women's clothing and heels is surprisingly expensive!)
Printing,
     Flyer Distribution, Marketing and PR services
Photography
     and Documentation
Technical
     support for our Brighton shows
In
return for a donation to our fundraising campaign, we have a whole host of
rewards on offer – from signed programmes, recorded DVD’s of our performance,
and show tickets, to an invitation to Super Paua’s official launch party and
funders reception!  And of course - our eternal gratitude!
The Impact of Aunty
Ben

importance of a show like Aunty Ben was best summed up, we
think, by Dr Audrey Bryan, of St Patricks Teacher Training College, Dublin…

as a Teacher Educator, Aunty Ben complements beautifully a number of topics covered in the primary school curriculum,

and see how far we can take it!

Help
If you are unable to
contribute to Aunty Ben financially (we are in the midst of a recession, after
all!) there are other ways you can help! 
If you would like to come and see our shows, you can buy tickets on the
IDGTF’s website (www.gaytheatre.ie) or
at the Brighton Fringe Website (www.brightonfringe.org).
If you are interested in
working with us, talking to us, hearing more about our project, or if you know
of a school that might be interested in our drama workshops, please
contact Sian Ní Mhuirí at info@superpaua.org

Facebook would be a big help!  Our page
is www.facebook.com/superpaua 

Thanks so much for your time!

story:
The Beginning – It’s A-L.I.V.E.!

It all started with three Chicago-based friends who had a common trait: they loved to entertain. Whether they did it through theater, games, writing or improvisation, they loved to see people laughing, thrilling, and just plain old having a good time. They had oodles of zany ideas just chomping at the bit to become a reality, but they knew from the get go that they couldn’t bring their dreams to life on their own. So, in the summer of 2012, Shane Hill, Andrew Huttel and Derrick Gaetke started talking about getting together some like-minded folks and seeing what they could do with their powers combined… besides summoning a super-powered ecological PSA, of course (they could already do that). They shared some of their ideas with their friends in Chicago’s art community, and soon found themselves surrounded with fantastic, talented people who all wanted to join in the dream. Before they knew it, Locked Into Vacancy Entertainment, or “L.I.V.E.” for short, was born.

L.I.V.E.’s first project, the Bronson’s Lozenges Astounding Imagination Showcase Extravaganza, is a stage show performed and recorded in the style of old time radio serials. Filled with original scripts, songs, sponsors and sound effects – all of them provided by writers and performers in the Chicago area – what many have come to recognize as the “L.I.V.E. Radio Show” has met with overwhelmingly positive reactions. Audiences have been thrilled to experience brand new adventures and characters in a way many of them hadn’t before, where the audio gives them the backbone but their imaginations are free to fill in the rest. Soon after the radio show’s debut more talented people approached the members of L.I.V.E. asking how they could get involved, and the company grew. The BLAISE radio show continues to entertain and delight audiences on a bimonthly basis at the Public House Theater in Chicago, IL, with plans for a monthly show starting January of 2015. If you don’t live in or around Chicago and want to get in on the fun, podcast recordings of the live shows are available absolutely free for download via iTunes or at www.lockedintovacancy.com.

The Future – Not Just Any Dream Will Do

While the success of the radio show has been greatly encouraging, L.I.V.E. is looking to move onward and upward. We have a lot of exciting ideas for other projects we’d like to pursue, including (but not limited to):

-  Increasing the frequency of the radio show to a monthly event

-  Musical adaptations of pop culture icons

-  Board and/or card games featuring original L.I.V.E. characters

-  A comedy news web series performed entirely with puppets

This, of course, is just the tip of the iceberg, but in order to dive under the waters of real-life expenses and get one of those motivational poster pics that show you just how big the iceberg of possibility is down there, we’re looking to you for support.

You Go, I Go, We All Go IndieGoGo!

One of our strongly held values here at L.I.V.E. is to offer you quality entertainment at an affordable price (did we mention that the podcast is free?), and in our commitment to that value we saw an IndieGoGo campaign as the most fitting way to garner the funds we need for our current and future projects. We want you, the viewer/listener, to have a part in our journey and join us as an invested member of the L.I.V.E. family! Your support will give us the financial backing we need to:

-  Purchase our own recording equipment for the radio show

-  Cover our legal and incorporation fees

-  Improve and maintain our website

-  Fund those future projects we’re excited to bring you

-  Offer financial compensation to the hardworking artists and production staff that have been an integral part of our company (Paying artists? Ca-ray-zy, aren’t we?)

But no beggars are we! While any contribution made will automatically come with our eternal gratitude and an honorary place in the L.I.V.E. community, we’ve also got a plethora of fun and exciting perks/rewards for every pledge level as our way of saying thank you. Not to mention that going forward whenever something we do brings a smile to the face of you, your friends or your family, you’ll be able to proudly declare that you helped us do it.

Thank you for taking the time to check out our IndieGoGo campaign. We look forward to your support, and even more so to one day thanking you in person. After all…

IT’S ALWAYS BETTER LIVE!



(A moment of special thanks to everyone who is helping us here at L.I.V.E. put together this campaign: Cole Simon, Alexis Cohen-Pena, Arne Parrot, Liz Galindorf)

story:
Short Summary

We are group of belly dancers that are campaigning to fund a project of choreography and live music. We are local to Humboldt County in Northern California, Eureka area, and run as a collective. We choreograph and perform many different styles of belly dance from areas like Turkey, Egypt, Morocco and sometimes fuse them with modern western styles of dance. We are collaborating with local band Musaic (they perform various folk music from Hungary, Romania, Macedonia, Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece, Armenia, Turkey, Scandinavia, Ireland, Mexico & more) to make their songs come alive! We have excellent choreographers, dancers and musicians all collaborating to make a beautiful show. We are producing this event through a local non-profit, Mosaic Productions, a dreammaker project with the Ink People, but we need your help to pay for the venue rentals, insurance, and artists.

There will be three shows:

Friday March 27 @ The Eureka Women’s Club, Eureka CA

Saturday March 28 @ Redwood Raks, Arcata CA

Sunday March 29 @ Trinidad Town Hall, Trinidad CA

What We Need & What You Get

Our idea behind this campaign is to fund the project before the show instead of relying on tickets sales. Our goal is to get the community excited about our show by contributing; anyone donating will be helping to make this show happen! Our funding will pay for: renting the theaters, insurance, paying the non-profit fees, and paying the artists. If you contribute then you get to come to the show! 

We have really cool perks including CDs, belly dance and music classes, special performances and of course tickets to one of our three shows.

If we don't reach our entire goal, any of the funds we do receive will go towards renting the venues and paying insurance. That will be the biggest overhead.

The Impact

If you live in Humboldt, chances are you have seen Ya Habibi perform around town. We perform at lots of different events from festivals to charities and local shows. But we don't often get the opportunity to put on a full length belly dance concert, especially to live music.

This project gives us the opportunity to:

  • Collaborate with local artists and musicians
  • Work on choreography and present it in a professional setting
  • Showcase local talent

This project gives the community a chance to:

  • Support local artists
  • See a type of concert this is very rare to this area!

Instead of paying for the ticket at the show, pay for your ticket before the show and help us fund our art! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute there are still ways for you to help:

  • Get the word out about our project!
  • Share with your friends and family.
  • Share our campaign on your social media
  • Let us know about any promotional ideas you may have 
  • Volunteer at one of our shows as an usher or ticket taker

story:
Community Theatre needs help for kids production of Shrek The Musical

Beanstalk Community Theatre has been serving the High Country laughter and love since 2012. You all remember "Disney's Aladdin Jr?" and who could forget "Night at the Wax Museum?" Our most recent success "Christmas in Oz, Y'all" has really pushed our drive to create the best productions for you, our community, and our actors, both young and...seasoned. 

BeanStalk Community Theatre is dedicated to bringing quality theatrical experiences to the youth of the high country and their families. We involve members in all aspects of production from backstage to on stage! Our productions promote teamwork, commitment, and exceptional work ethic, allowing families to spend quality time together while creating an excellent theatre experience for our audience.


What We Need & What You Get

We want to make our next summer production our best yet! Our goal in this campaign is to raise enough money to rent and/or build professional costumes.

Our average budget for a show like this is $10,000.00! It costs more than you imagine to do all that we do to pull these shows off. With your help in raising just 1/4 of our budget we can outfit our cast with great costumes for a magical show. If we are able to build our costumes rather than rent them, we can generate income for years to come by renting them out to other theatre companies.

The Impact

We hope that you will find it in your heart to donate to this worthy cause so that we may continue to bring quality theatre to our community.

Involvement in the arts is associated with gains in math, reading, cognitive ability, critical thinking, and verbal skills. Arts learning can also improve motivation, concentration, confidence, and teamwork. A 2005 report by the Rand Corporation about the visual arts argues that the intrinsic pleasures and stimulation of the arts experience do more than sweeten an individual's life. According to the report, they "can connect people more deeply to the world and open them to new ways of seeing," creating the foundation to forge social bonds and community cohesion. 

Risks & Challenges

The economy has taken a toll on everyone. Arts programs are being removed from schools due to budget cuts. Stage musicals are being made into movies. If we band together, share our story, and each give a little, then our goal can be met easily. Please remember how much you have enjoyed each performance either as a performer or community member and consider donating. Any amount will help.

We hope we make our goal, but even if we don't remember The Show Must Go On!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot give now, maybe skip that latte tomorrow and give a little then. Perhaps, you have experience building costumes, props, or sets and would like to donate your time.

If not please share our campaign through your facebook or other social media outlets to help us bring more awareness to our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Created in June 2011, SKooJ CorE-O wanted to give desire performers an opportunity to come together and form The Boston Community Dance Project. Through Contemporary and Fusion based movement, BCDP strives to showcase the true art of story telling. Since premiering their "Power Struggle" set, BCDP has been a part of The Massachusetts Dance Festival, SoulDeSoul Dance Gala, NACHMO, and many charity events on the East Coast. They have also performed in New York City at NYC Dance Week, NYC Dance Parade, and Carnival: Choreographers Ball. Reaching out to the community with realistic concepts, that connect all viewers emotionally is a mission for BCDP to help spread the positivity and release dance can give towards all. Watch out for our “IMPROVIZE!” Workshops and our 2015 Summer Show at Boston University August 29th!

REVITALIZE! will bring movement to the Elements! COme see how Earth, Wind, Water, Metal, Wood, and Air(Heaven) moves! 

Proceeds od REVITALIZE! will go to our beautiful and hardworking dancers as well as a charity of BCDP's choice to bring dance to everyone! 

What We Need & What You Get

$20 part of one costume 

$40- Printing show flyers and event brochures

$50- travel reinbursement for one dancer

$150 Fabric to use for the routines

$175 Programs for the show

$200 Make-Up Artist for the dancers

$250 Studio rentals for rehearsals

$500  Lighting Director and Crew Payment

$1000 total payment for guest artist to perform and teach at our Intensive

$1200 Custom BCDP Apparel for the members and public

$1500 Costume reimbursement for all 19 dancers

$3000 rental of venue and insurance policies/liability agreements

As you can see our show needs more than $7000 however every dollar helps us get to our goal! 

The Impact

Dance is a vessel to peoples' souls! We are hungry to bring a show that is inspired by real life scenarios and gear to all viewers. We want to spark a human to free their movement and realize that there bodies are wanting to dance!  

Risks & Challenges

Our production is put together in 8 weeks! You can just imagine the excessive sweat, packed full rehearsals, and numerous meetings are needed to make this all be ready for when the curtain opens. 

Not only does Boston Community Dance Project have 11 fabulous Adult Company Dancers but there is also a Teen Apprentice Program that shows pre-professional dancers the real feel of being on a Dance Company! To mesh all the dancers into one cohesive product is always challenging but the process and ending result of seeing everyone mesh together is a true prize in itself! 

Other Ways You Can Help

But tickets to "REVITALIZE!" on Brown Paper Ticket starting July 15th!

Share our Facebook Page and "like" our cause! This page will keep you updating with our events,show sneak peak videos, and post pictures during our whole process! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Boston-Community-Dance-Project-BCDP/212977655454845?ref_type=bookmark

Chat about us on social media with #BCDP and #FollowTheArtistry

Come take out weekly Contemporary Class Thursdays 6-730pm at The Jeannette Neill Dance Studio in Boston, MA!

Not only does Boston Community Dance Project have 11 fabulous Adult Company Dancers but there is also a Teen Apprentice Program that shows pre-professional dancers the real feel of being on a Dance Company! To mesh all the dancers into one cohesive product is always challenging but the process and ending result of seeing everyone mesh together is a true prize in itself! 
Other Ways You Can Help
 
But tickets to "REVITALIZE!" on Brown Paper Ticket starting July 15th!
Share our Facebook Page and "like" our cause! This page will keep you updating with our events,show sneak peak videos, and post pictures during our whole process! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Boston-Community-Dance-Project-BCDP/212977655454845?ref_type=bookmark
Chat about us on social media with #BCDP and #FollowTheArtistry
Come take out weekly Contemporary Class Thursdays 6-730pm at The Jeannette Neill Dance Studio in Boston, MA!

story:
Truman Capote told her she was the face of the 70s. 

Trans icon and Warhol Superstar, Holly Woodlawn, died on December 6, 2015 at the age of 69. She starred in such movies as 'Trash', 'Women in Revolt' and 'Broken Goddess' and was recognized at the 88th Academy Awards, Oscars in Memoriam. 

Sugar High Productions is a small team of professional theatre makers living in Oxford: Tanner Efinger, Lizzy McBain, Matt Winkworth, Suzie Burlton & Emma Webb who came together shortly after Woodlawn's passing to create 'High as Sugar'. 

Writer and performer, Tanner Efinger says that "Holly's character and unsinkable attitude affected me. The paper trail of her life lauds her bold and unapologetic, spontaneous and honest. Her magnetism drew me to learn more and more and through that avalanche of Holly, we created 'Sugar'. This is the first solo show I've written and performed. I'm honored to have the talents of this creative team and the support of both my local community and extended friends.

Thank you for helping me create and hopefully capture even a fraction of the essence that is the fabulous and immeasurable Holly Woodlawn."

What We Need

The show has been written and composed and has been accepted into three prestigious theatre festivals and now we need your help to give this project wings.

Brighton Fringe, The Warren: Studio 2 - June 3-5
Offbeat in Oxford, BT Studio - June 20
#Festival46 at The Kings Head Theatre in London - July 20

We need to raise $2000 (about £1400) to make this project sustainable. This money will be spent on production needs such as costumes, set, rehearsal venue, transportation, liability insurance, accommodation, flyers/posters... Honey, theatre is expensive. The theatre makers will only earn a small stipend if the fundraising and ticket sale goals are met. 

The Impact

LOCAL IMPACT: The creative team are all professional theatre makers who work freelance in Oxfordshire and surrounding areas. They are all members of the Oxfordshire Theatre Makers and are working to promote and create professional theatre opportunities within the local community and strengthen the professional theatre scene in Oxfordshire. The creation of 'High as Sugar' is a small part of that process. 

THE STORY: We believe that Holly's story is important. It's a story not about gender identity, but simply identity. Holly Woodlawn told the New York Times in 1970, "I’m not afraid of playing a man; I was born a man. And I’m not afraid of being a woman. I love women. Too much is made of gender. I want people to say of me,‘Here is a person who has something to offer besides gender.’"

Video credit:

Music:
‘Banshee’ (99¢, 2016) © Santigold 
‘Walk on the Wild Side’ (Transformer, 1972) © Lou Reed 

Video interview with Holly:
© From 'Is There Sex After Death' (1971)

Images:
‘Dollar Sign’ © Andy Warhol
‘National Velvet’ © Andy Warhol
‘Marilyn Diptych’ © Andy Warhol
‘Ohhh...Alright…’ © Roy Lichtenstein
Cover art for The Velvet Underground & Nico, © Andy Warhol
‘Yarn’ © Andy Warhol
© Craven ‘A’ vintage cigarette advert
Holly Woodlawn © Jack Mitchell/Getty
Party at the Factory © Fred W McDarrah

story:
The Play

Splendid Notions is a two act play, which portrays the life and career of the fictitious actor, Maxwell Donegan. In two acts, the play chronicles the following:

  • Maxwell's rise to fame in the film industry of old hollywood.
  • Maxwell's broadway debut in his mid thirties.
  • The relationship with his alcoholic mother, and grandmother who suffers from Alzheimer's.

The Director

A little bit about myself and my experience.

  • I am currently a sophomore in high school.
  • I have performed in plays across the country in NC, CO, and CA.
  • I have written the play, am currently directing it, and will star in it.

The Impact

  • The rehearsal process for the play has given many new performers experience into the audition and rehearsal process, as well as giving more seasoned actors a new experience in creating a play collectively, working with the writer and director. 
  • It has provided an educational experience for all cast, crew, and company involved.
  • A portion of ticket sales will go towards funding further theatrical ventures by the students.

Risks & Challenges

We have secured a venue, and must raise money to pay for the theatre. If not enough money is raised, the venue cannot be rented. Worst come to worst, the play will be performed in the street with no sets, costumes,or stage.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate money, sharing the campaign and raising awareness about the play will help greatly.

Thank you again for donating! best wishes,

Sacred "Charlie" Swindell

writer and director of Splendid Notions

story:
Short Summary

ArasDance is excited to be presenting their newest work at the Capital Fringe Festival for the third year in a row. ArasDance will showcase a 50 minute piece that is unlike any previous repertory from the company, get ready to hear another side of what we have in store with "And 1! A Dansical"

What We Need & What You Get

ArasDance is seeking your support to help us bring lights and sound to our stage!
We have a lot going into this new "dansical" and we would love if you could see and hear us in person. We are giving away 5 tickets, at random, after the campaign ends to one of our shows in July. Please help bring our show to life!!

story:
A Taste of the Project:


An old church, decaying to the point that trees tower over gaping crevasses, in the stained glass and the cold stone, reaching their branches towards eight women inside. These women walk the crumbling staircases dragging their once white, now tattered dresses. Flash to experience these women in a cluster, their skirts morphing into one entity, pouring over the mud and broken glass floor. Slowly you realize their torsos are swaying with the slightest movement, their ribs move together, their abdomens move together.  You see their skirts blow in the cold winter air.  In a breath two women have swung onto fabric and their strength and unison as aerial dancers takes over the moment. Flash to the back of a man's head. He has a long black braid that falls down his spine. Now you can see over his shoulder. He is carving meat. Red. Flash to women..... skirts flying. They are circling, flying over the floor, white chalk puffing and dancing all around themâ€¦


We have gathered together thirteen energized artists to pool their talents and imaginations to create a short dance film centered around an odyssey of images . We have already rehearsed the dance movement. The movement is small and intricate to contrast with the grandeur of the location and the costumes. Other dance sections are bigger and draw more from our ballet/contemporary backgrounds. We will be filming at an old church which takes up multiple city blocks. It burned down many years ago and has never been cleaned up. We have three artists designing and creating long white, off-white, lace ripped dresses. The tops of the dresses will have a light, wispy romantic look. We have a couple tricks up our sleeves involving the release of chalk and a unique way to fly on aerial silks. :-) We have Chicago based DJ's creating original music in conjunction with the movement for this project. We will have a hair and make-up artist on set with us. And of course we have our cinematographer. We plan to submit this piece to film festivals in the spring. 


The Artists:


The Director:

I, Tara, studied dance at both Sarah Lawrence College (under the mentorship of Sara Rudner) and Prescott College. I continue to study and create dance in Chicago. I was part of Aerial Dance Chicago's Second Company last season and train at The Aloft Loft. I have choreographed works for Prescott College, Prescott Arizona's Tsunami Before the Flood Festival, Chicago Freelance Dance and Dance Chance. 


One of the things I love best in this life is to facilitate artistic collaborations. I love the energy that builds when a group of artists gets together and each person has the space to express what interests them about the project at hand. I am excited to be the person who makes this artistic pulse into a cohesive whole. 


The Dancers:

This project involves eight trained dancers. The dancers' training comes from at Pointe Park, University of Buffalo, Prescott College, Columbia College and Ballet Austin. In addition, four of the dancers are trained aerialists. They were part of Aerial Dance Chicago's second company last season and train at The Aloft Loft in Chicago. 


The cinematographer:

Evan is a film student at Columbia College Chicago. He is interested in using film as a medium to help as well as entertain audiences. 


The Musicians:

We are currently in the process of reviewing demos by two Chicago based DJs. 


Make up artist:

Currently reviewing portfolios of make-up artists.


Costume makers:

Carol is an award winning art quilter. She has exhibited and placed in shows such as the International Quilt Festival in Houston, Mid-Atlantic Quilt Festival, Austin Area Quilt Guild and the Dallas Quilt Show. She also designs and sells original work. In addition she has been making costumes for dance and theater for over two decades. 

I, (Tara), have taken fashion classes at the Art Institute of Chicago. I have designed and helped create costumes for three dance shows. 

Andrea is a skilled seamstress, who has been making garments for over ten years.



Why This Project is Important:


Projects like these are our way of offering our full potential to others. This project in particular has so much creative energy behind it, it is important that we get to share our vision with the world! In addition, many of us see this project as a jumping off point to continue to develop our careers as artists. 


The Nitty Gritty--The Money:


We will use funding for rehearsal space, a camera dolly, an extra camera battery (we will be filming in the cold where there is no electricity), costume materials, aerial silks fabric and equipment, and travel expenses. 


If we do not reach our goal the project will still run but we will not be able to fully express the vision of the piece (for example we might only have one aerialist instead of two, which compromises the theme of unison that runs through the choreography). We are asking for the bare minimum of what we need. We believe we can create an expansive, grande piece of art on this low budget. If you would like to see this vision realized, please support the project! 


Thank you all for your interest and for being part of this project! 



Photos curtesy of www.tripodvisuals.com and www.foreverboho.com/page/3/

story:
To all lovers of art and believers in magic,

Good news! AnimalParts is taking Tenderpits to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival August 3-27, 2012 - the largest and most exciting arts festival in the world!

As viciously funny as it is uplifting and life-affirming, Tenderpits is a one-of-a-kind solo performance piece combining physical theatre, stand-up comedy, multimedia, and performance art. It tells the completely 100% half-true story of a young wizard's immigration from the wilderness of Canada to New York City.

Critics have called Tenderpits "funny, strange, and above all entertaining" (Stagebuzz), "a dazzling display of versatility, charm, and energy" (nytheatre.com), and "an alternately hilarious and harrowing avant-garde autobiography" (Flavorpill).

Your donations will bring this fantastic show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and lay the groundwork for our future success. We will have the opportunity to network with producers and programmers from around the world, have creative exchange with international artists, and - most importantly - connect with global audiences!

By supporting us, you nurture unique and challenging art created by emerging Canadian/NYC artists, and foster a place for us on the world's stage.

We are raising $18,000 to bring Tenderpits to Edinburgh. Your contributions will pay for: airfare, accommodations, venue rental, production costs, publicity/marketing, insurance and more!

Our goal is to raise $10,000 here on our indiegogo campaign, and to raise the rest through other fundraising events between now and August.

ALL YOUR DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!

With love and gratitude,

Anthony, Nathan & Miranda

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU

PS. Forward this link with wild abandon! Send it to your friends & family, and to do-gooders and philanthropists! Help this project go viral! Click on the links below to Like us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter and visit our website! Spread the word about AnimalParts theatre co. and Tenderpits!

________________________________________________

AnimalParts is Anthony Johnston & Nathan Schwartz, a pair of Canadian theatre artists based in NYC. Along with general manager, Miranda Plant, they are dedicated to creating unique and vibrant new theatre always rooted in humor, heart and innovation.

story:
What We Need and What You Get


    • WHAT WE NEED

We hope to raise 22,000 dollars and the contributions you make will help us to:

  • Pay our lovely creative team who have worked hard for free so far!
     
  • Pay the cast of twenty plus actors
     
  • Pay the Venues hire
     
  • Pay for the five staff of the venues
     
  • Pay the few costumes and props
     
  • Pay our technical support staff which includes a set and costume designer, a sound engineer and a cameraman who will document the week long performance of Circles
     
  • Assist us in printing the Circles programmes and posters
     
  • Enable us to edit the footage filmed into a promo trailer which we will subsequently use to promote Circles abroad.
     

This workshop production of Circles will happen whether we reach our target or not but your contributions will enable us to mount the piece on the scale we would like.  


    • WHAT YOU GET 

In return for your generous contributions we have arrange an assortment of interesting and imaginative perks which will include:

  • A beautifully crafted programme of the piece

  • One of Circles beautiful posters

  • Access to the production blog space where updates from some of the characters will regularly appear

  • A copy of the original Circles CD written and performed by Lyra Laura Veroli

  • A Benefactor credit

  • A copy of Circles' script

  • Reserved seats

  • Specially written stories on any subject of your choice

  • A dinner with the production team and the cast

 

Others Ways you can Help

We know not everyone can contribute but for those who cannot it would help us so much if you could simply tell your friends about our Indiegogo campaign and use the Indiegogo SHARE TOOLs which are available.  

 

The Team

Circles is a collaboration between former Royal Shakespeare Company's resident director Vik Sivalingam, playwright and documentary film director Beverly Andrews, creative producer Esther Nissard, Bafta nominated filmmaker Dan Saul, singer/composer Lyra Laura Veroli, musical producer Bruno D'ambra and cameraman Paul Trenholme. 

This initial workshop performance will take place on the 6th of May at London's Arcola Theatre's tent and then continue on the 9th, 10th, 11th at various locations throughout the city with all four conclusions performed at the Baldwin Room at London's prestigious Tricycle Theatre. That performance will be followed by a Q and A with members of the cast, the director, the playwright and the audience. We also hope to have a representative from an HIV/AIDS support organization present.   

Short Summary

My name is Beverly Andrews and I'm a playwright and documentary filmmaker. My most recent project, completed with no funding, was a documentary on London's acclaimed Arcola Theatre called "I am Going to Make a Miracle".  The film premiered in the Dhaka International film Festival and will appear in Berlin in May and in Fountainhead's Black International film Festival.

Circles was inspired by my desire to try to examine the rise of homophobia in the African and Afro-Caribbean community.  But in the wake of both the London riots and the on-going banking crisis the project became much larger.  Circles is now a site-specific, multi-media theatre piece which looks at how theatre can take an audience behind our current newspaper headlines, into the heart of stories we are so greatly affected by today and in doing so perhaps alter how we see them.  All four stories will have a loose connection with HIV/AIDS but these are not HIV/AIDS stories per se but rather stories about our ability to feel compassion for others and our willingness to see the world through their eyes. The stories are

Michael's Story - set in New York's hedonistic mid 1970's. Located in a gay club we see a touching coming of age story of a gay teenager searching for his true idenity against the backdrop of the vicious homophobia endemic at the time.

Henry's Story - set in an investment bank, not unlike Lehman Brothers, where an executive has to choose between his loyalty to the bank and his own moral conscious. 

Jean's Story - set on the second day of the London riots, where an African immigrant teenager starts to see the true costs of gang loyality.

Pastor Mustapha's Story - set in present day Uganda, where a Christian minster feels the moral salvation of his country depends on the passing of a parlimentary bill which will make being gay an act punishable by imprisonment and then for repeated offenders death. Unbeknowst to him, his own son is both gay and  HIV positive.  

These four pieces will all be performed over the course of a week in  locations around London. The conclusions of all four stories will be influenced by the four adjectives audience members will be asked to text. And these adjectives will of course be influenced by the audience's ability to feel compassion for the characters they see. 


The Impact 

We hope that this initial workshop performance will lead to an opportunity to tour the show internationally.  We feel that the contributions contributors make will be absoltuely vital in helping to raise the profile of Circles. Something that everyone who is currently working on this project feels is absolutely crucial.  In an increasingly polarized world, your help will enable us to create a theatrical piece which does what we feel is so needed right now, i.e. allow groups traditionally opposed to one another have some kind of forum for dialogue and maybe, just maybe come away with some kind of understanding of each other's lives.

One of Circles beautiful posters

Access to the production blog space where updates from some of the characters will regularly appear

A copy of the original Circles CD written and performed by Lyra Laura Veroli

A Benefactor credit

A copy of Circles' script

Reserved seats

Specially written stories on any subject of your choice

A dinner with the production team and the cast
 
Others Ways you can Help
We know not everyone can contribute but for those who cannot it would help us so much if you could simply tell your friends about our Indiegogo campaign and use the Indiegogo SHARE TOOLs which are available.  
 
The Team
Circles is a collaboration between former Royal Shakespeare Company's resident director Vik Sivalingam, playwright and documentary film director Beverly Andrews, creative producer Esther Nissard, Bafta nominated filmmaker Dan Saul, singer/composer Lyra Laura Veroli, musical producer Bruno D'ambra and cameraman Paul Trenholme. 
This initial workshop performance will take place on the 6th of May at London's Arcola Theatre's tent and then continue on the 9th, 10th, 11th at various locations throughout the city with all four conclusions performed at the Baldwin Room at London's prestigious Tricycle Theatre. That performance will be followed by a Q and A with members of the cast, the director, the playwright and the audience. We also hope to have a representative from an HIV/AIDS support organization present.   
Short Summary
My name is Beverly Andrews and I'm a playwright and documentary filmmaker. My most recent project, completed with no funding, was a documentary on London's acclaimed Arcola Theatre called "I am Going to Make a Miracle".  The film premiered in the Dhaka International film Festival and will appear in Berlin in May and in Fountainhead's Black International film Festival.
Circles was inspired by my desire to try to examine the rise of homophobia in the African and Afro-Caribbean community.  But in the wake of both the London riots and the on-going banking crisis the project became much larger.  Circles is now a site-specific, multi-media theatre piece which looks at how theatre can take an audience behind our current newspaper headlines, into the heart of stories we are so greatly affected by today and in doing so perhaps alter how we see them.  All four stories will have a loose connection with HIV/AIDS but these are not HIV/AIDS stories per se but rather stories about our ability to feel compassion for others and our willingness to see the world through their eyes. The stories are
Michael's Story - set in New York's hedonistic mid 1970's. Located in a gay club we see a touching coming of age story of a gay teenager searching for his true idenity against the backdrop of the vicious homophobia endemic at the time.
Henry's Story - set in an investment bank, not unlike Lehman Brothers, where an executive has to choose between his loyalty to the bank and his own moral conscious. 
Jean's Story - set on the second day of the London riots, where an African immigrant teenager starts to see the true costs of gang loyality.
Pastor Mustapha's Story - set in present day Uganda, where a Christian minster feels the moral salvation of his country depends on the passing of a parlimentary bill which will make being gay an act punishable by imprisonment and then for repeated offenders death. Unbeknowst to him, his own son is both gay and  HIV positive.  
These four pieces will all be performed over the course of a week in  locations around London. The conclusions of all four stories will be influenced by the four adjectives audience members will be asked to text. And these adjectives will of course be influenced by the audience's ability to feel compassion for the characters they see. 

The Impact 
We hope that this initial workshop performance will lead to an opportunity to tour the show internationally.  We feel that the contributions contributors make will be absoltuely vital in helping to raise the profile of Circles. Something that everyone who is currently working on this project feels is absolutely crucial.  In an increasingly polarized world, your help will enable us to create a theatrical piece which does what we feel is so needed right now, i.e. allow groups traditionally opposed to one another have some kind of forum for dialogue and maybe, just maybe come away with some kind of understanding of each other's lives.

story:
Our Story

Bedlam Ensemble is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to staging theatre works of high artistic integrity. Bedlam aims to nourish an open an artistic community where artists are free to experiment and challenge themselves within the entertainment industry.


The Impact

GRANDPA WAS A BACHELOR is a show about a family - a modern family with traditional problems. The family as an institution is rapidly changing in our fast paced world and the myth of the nuclear family with the traditional mother, father role and 2.5 children is becoming more and more unconventional.

How can these new families avoid the pitfalls of traditional ones? Aging, loneliness, rejection are unfortunately part of the human condition. Can any family (no matter how traditional or avant garde) put a modern spin on an age old problem - what is the purpose of life?


Other Ways to Help Us


Please forward this page to your friends and family! Spread the word! Come and see our show bring your loved ones!
