story:
JULIUS CAESAR | MARCH 31st

Performed by SEVEN DAY SHAKESPEARE

 

Seven Day Shakespeare continues to be.

A collection of New York actors performing William Shakespeare's plays with no more than 7 days of rehearsals. Performances are FREE to the public and are performed in locations all throughout New York City. Our current project, Julius Caesar, will be performed in New York City on March 31st, 2013.

 
Julius Caesar marks the beginning of our second season in New York City. We have joined with Tale Told Productions to create stronger and more engaging performance opportunities.
 
www.taletold.org
 

Our needs.

We are looking to raise $500 for rehearsal space, props, costumes, and promotional material. By contributing to this unique experience, you are helping bring free, quality theatre to New York City and its diverse inhabitants.
 
Budget breakdown:
 
$25 - NYC Parks Permit
$150 - Costume construction and rental(costume design by Becca Freund)
$100 - Prop construction and rental(prop design by Marissa Bergman)
$75 - Printing and Promotional distribution
$150 - Rehearsal space rental
 
*all funds raised over our goal, or left over after production, are immediately applied to the next project in June.
 
 

The far reaching goal.

Our goal is to create quality, ensemble productions of Shakespeare's work that are unique and inventive for the New York public. Audiences are encouraged to bring friends and family of all ages to relax while watching a free performance in NYC. The performance space is tentative and more information on location will appear in early April. Permits are pending.
 

Can't donate? No worries!

Please help us get the word out by tweeting our Indiegogo page or posting it onto to Facebook. Also, "like" our page at www.facebook.com/sevendayshakespeare
www.twitter.com/taletoldNY

story:
The Deal:

The 2011 IMPULSE Improv Festival will be an amazing and exciting event that will bring together university-aged improvisers from across Canada and beyond. Teams that participate will experience world-class training, professional-quality performance opportunities, and the chance to meet and work with improvisers from all over the continent.

With your generosity, we can make this a reality. We're reaching out to the community (you guys!) to help us bring improvisers from across the country and beyond to Vancouver to put on some damned fine improv.

$2000 in 50 days is impossible you say? Nonesense! Improv is all about making the impossible possible. Does that make sense? I think it does...

About Us:

 

UBCimprov at the University of British Columbia organizes IMPULSE to connect with its peers from around the continent. We dream of using IMPULSE to facilitate a true (inter)national network of university improv.

 

More than a decade young, UBCimprov is an important member of the Vancouver improv community. Powered by the hearts and quick-thinking of like-minded individuals, UBCi dedicates itself to spreading the magic and marvel of improvised theatre.


Where you money is going:


We'll be using the funds collected here to help out of town teams make the costly journey to Vancouver.

story:
Project Girl Performance Collective create a safe space for girls to write and perform original work.

 

Project Girl Performance Collective (http://www.projectgirlperformancecollective.org) is a New York City based incorporated non profit theatre company that gives girls indispensable free training in writing, acting and directing allowing them to step confidently into the world and challenge the status quo.  

 

We need YOU to take part in the movement to empower women and girls around the world

 

No-one is turned away because of lack of funds from our unique human rights curriculum, which works to engage girls in thinking critically about personal, social and global struggles. For such a curriculum to exist, our staff works countless hours however, without your support and proper funding our work cannot continue.

 

Each and every contribution goes towards creating a fearless space for girls to write and perform their work.

 

In 2011 we used our limited budget to reach out to girls both near and far. We kicked off the year by exploring womenï¿½s access to education and jobs in the fields of technology and science through a performance at the United Nations Conference on the Status of Women. That same week Project Girls wowed a crowd of 1,400 at the New Jersey State Theatre in our regional debut, went on the road to help the Panzi Hospital Foundation USA to kick off our national art tour with a show about the rape epidemic in the Congo at the National Holocaust Museum in Richmond, Virginia, and supported Michelle Obamaï¿½s trip to Africa with a Project Girl: Congo performance at the White House. We concluded the season by joining forces with the Girl Up United Nations Foundation and launched a 5-city national tour in Chicago to raise awareness about forced child marriage in developing countries. Project Girls were featured on VH1, PBS, NPR, WBAI and in publications such as the New Yorker, New York Times and Time Out NY. That's not all - On November 23rd Project Girls will be giving a performance and presentation on "Violence Against Women" at the United Nations for United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon and Sebastian Pinera Echnique, President of Chile.

 

We have huge plans for 2012!  Weï¿½ll be making three more stops on the Unite For Girls Tour with the Girl Up UN Foundation while developing two new shows. The first, ï¿½Traffickedï¿½ has been commissioned by ECPAT (End Child Prostitution, Child Pornography and Trafficking) to commemorate their 20th anniversary and raise awareness about commercial sexual exploitation and domestic trafficking of children and youth. The second is a series of workshops and open mic nights that will spark inspiration for our spring performance, "GirlPower" ï¿½ a NY International Fringe Festival Favorite where the theme and material is devised entirely by members of Project Girl Performance Collective and based on personal experiences and explorations of issues facing young girls. None of this will possible if we do not receive funding to keep the work alive.

 

 

Join the movement:

Get Girl Power!

story:
Summary

The Matryoshka Doll is Constantine Lignos' senior thesis project at NYU's Experimental Theatre Wing.  The show revolves around a New Jersey housewife who recently got a hysterectomy and is having trouble identifying with her femininity.  In an attempt to rediscover her sexuality, she dreams of becoming some of history's most iconic females, including Cleopatra, Lucille Ball, and Cleo from Rio, a stripper reminiscent of Gypsy Rose Lee.

The show runs from April 18-21 at New York University's Shop Theatre on the 2nd Floor of 721 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

E-mail thematryoshkadoll@gmail.com for more information!

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown:

  • We need $500 to fund our show.  The money goes toward paying for costumes, sets, props, and lights.
  • You can get a whole bunch of really cool gifts for donating to our show.  Including a lap dance!

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise for our show!

story:
We’re at Fingers Piano Bar, Frederick Street (in Edinburgh) at 5.30pm to 6.30pm on August 6, 7, 9-14, 16-21, 23-27.

 

SUPPORTED BY THE LORD MAYOR OF COVENTRY, MIDLAND BUSINESSES AND SOME RANDOM YET SURPRISINGLY FAMOUS CELEBS!

The Show

We're a troupe of stand-up comedy performers with a fascination for baddies.

All funds being raised for a unique Edinburgh Festival Comedy show called 'Monsters'. Monsters: A History of Villainy is a sketch show featuring history and fiction's greatest villains.

Monsters aims to bring to life epic characters, portraying them in irreverent, human and silly situations. Our show aims to answer 'Are villains more important to us than heroes?'.

Think a lecture meets Loose Women meets Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure and you're sort of in the right territory!

Was Hitler pranked by his friends? What if Big Bad Wolf went on a dating show? Is Santa teased by his blokey mates for his wussy image? Were Polar Bears and Global Warming ever good friends?

Featuring rising comedians and starring Brian Blessed, each day will see a guest star comic grace the performance in a chat show segment.

Here's the core group -

Bob Fletcher

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9XRhMdl9t8&hd=1


Brian Blessed

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5__VFxOI99E&hd=1

The HQ for information is currently

http://www.bobversus.com/monsters/


Future?

We love history and literature and are fascinated by the role of villains. We aim to produce a fun and quirky show that brings to life great baddies, with a view to touring schools in the UK.

It will also be a platform for new comedians with budding writers providing material and a star guest cameoing each night.


Advertise and Contribute!

We need to pay for brochure fees, flyers, posters, rent, props and travel.

In return for helping fund the show, guest patrons will get a credit on the flyer as Producer ($30), Exec Producer ($100) or VIP Producer ($250). You will also become an honorary Monster!

We'll be inviting a variety of small businesses and arts organisations to be patrons, therefore their business name will appear on the flyer as a sponsor alongside individuals.

Each patron will be allocated a ticket to see any performance they wish as a gift in a VIP section.

We've already got funds from someone from Little Britain (whom has to remain nameless) and a huge British rock/pop band (also not supposed to name). Indeed, having these guys help, shows great faith in the cause.


Plus the Lord Mayor of Coventry!


Other Ways You Can Help

This is something that more than just a small group can be part of. It can be a huge project. So, spread the word and join us, help produce a show and unleash the monster inside of you!!!

story:
Our Story

Myles Malik McGee is the best man I have ever met in my life. I am Tim Crocker, one of Myles' best friends. When we met as freshmen at The University of Hawaii, I knew there was something different about Myles. He was impassioned. Pursuing his acting and dancing career energized Myles from his very soul. That energy spread like a sneeze or laughter to everyone Myles has ever touched in life.


The Impact

How many of us have ever had a dream, and how many of us have seen that dream fade and the real world kick in. Bills take priority over passion and vision. Myles doesn't allow that to hinder him and he encourages others to follow their dreams. If it weren't for Myles, I would be working as a server for the rest of my life. Because of his leadership, I am now actively pursuing my dream of a micro-lender to help people help themselves.


How You Impact Myles

The $1,000 dollar goal is a high aspiration. Myles would walk to New York if he had to, live on the street itself and sleep in a cardboard box if it meant he was eventually achieving his life-long goal, but as his friend, I would greatly like to try and help him out instead. Get Myles established in NYC, so he can amaze us all in the future.


Other Ways You Can Help

See that video posted, that's Myles' dance submission to LMFAO for a chance to represent on an international video. Please, watch the video and "like" it so Myles can go as far as possible with his talent and passion. Other than that, do you have any connections to acting/dancing in NYC? Check out all the videos posted and send your favorite to your network. Ideas spread like a wildfire, so passion should spread even quicker.

story:
The Performance

THE RECESSION CLUB

Free Stage Reading

PLANET CONNECTIONS THEATRE FESTIVITY


Wednesday, June 15, 2011

4 PM

Gene Frankel Theatre

24 Bond Street, Between Lafayette and Bowery

(Broadway and Lafayette Station: 6, F, M, B & D trains)


Reserve your seats today!

http://planetconnections.org/therecessionclub/

OR 866.811.4111


The Story

Yolanda loses her job as a petroleum engineer and forms a support group via craigslist. The unlikely cohorts, including a former college professor, a former retail employee and a woman of questionable background, face an identity crisis. Together, they learn that what you do is not who you are.


How You Can Help

All of your donations will go to cover our festivity participation fees, advertising, printing, shipping costs associated with our Dress for Success campaign (see below!), and compensating our wonderful cast and stage management team!


Community Outreach

THE RECESSION CLUB will be collecting in-kind donations to benefit Dress for Success, an international not-for-profit organization that promotes the economic independence of disadvantaged women by providing professional attire, a network of support and the career development tools to help women thrive in work and in life. Dress for Success has been providing clothing, confidence and career boosts to more than 550,000 women since 1997. We will be collecting nearly new women’s professional clothing and accessories before and after the performance. All in-kind donations to Dress for Success are tax-deductible!


The Team

Written By: Christina Quintana

Directed By: Tyne Rafaeli

Produced By: Christina Macchiarola

Dramaturgy By: Christina Hurtado

Stage Management: Ellen Mezzera


Featuring:

Dominique A. Toney as Yolanda

Elizabeth Gray as Rocky

Keith Boynton as Berto

Hanley H. Smith as Jean

Eric Whitten as Rowan



Special thanks to Keith Boynton for filming our video!

Special thanks to Keith Boynton for filming our video!

story:
Bootleg Theater is creating an original theatre piece and we need your support!

Founded in 2006 as the non-profit Rampart Theater Project Inc., we make theater, dance and performance events in a beautiful converted warehouse space that we have named Bootleg Theater.  Owned by theater artists since 1998, the space has evolved into an inclusive performing arts space where the most exciting Los Angeles artists perform and commune.  Our Artistic Director, Alicia Adams, had been researching the women of Toulouse Lautrec's paintings for years, fascinated by these women who were pioneering artists of their own.  Inspired by the exciting theater happening at Bootleg and all over Los Angeles,  the people who run Bootleg have come together to offer up their own ante.

An original dream play that links the world of women in Toulouse Lautrec's paintings to the men who loved them. Through words, movement and love the divine feminine of the past gains strength as a surreal absinthe night of drinking opens up a world that will enchant, challenge, frighten and inspire. 

Based on research of the period by Bootleg Artistic Director, Alicia Adams, and on the writings of Bob Dylan, Jane Avril, Yvette Guilbert, Suzanne Valadon, Steve Connell, and Alphonse Allais, the letters of Toulouse Lautrec, interviews with David Lynch, Scott Shepherd, William Styron, Alexis Rockman and the words of Brene Brown from her TED conference.

Bridge the Gap between waking and dreaming. A Fried Octopus.

In order to make this piece, we are turning to our own Bootleg community, one that has evolved and grown over the past seven years.   The theater pieces we make are entirely funded by donations and grant money.  The Bootleg Bar is a separate entity that cares for the venue, but it doesn't fund the art.  Art needs patrons and we're looking to you to jump on board this ride with us. 

Artists creating this project include: Alicia Adams, Justin Zsebe, Jessica Hanna, Kirk Wilson, Jason Adams, Kate Robertson, Michael Dunn, Lulu Brud, Will Watkins, Kera Arman, Licia Perea, Adam Flemming and Francois-Pierre Couture.

We are going to raise $12,000 and all of that money will go toward materials, artists & designer fees, production crew and all the other little details that are needed to make a piece of theater.  Any amount that you can give will be incredibly useful.  It will all go into the project.

Bootleg Theater has never attempted a major donation campaign.  We have been able to keep making Art for 7 years through box office, space rental and grants, just squeeking by, yet still making some of the most successful theater in Los Angeles.  Bootleg produced theater is consistently nominated for Ovations, LA Weeklies and the LADCC Awards.  We've produced hundreds of productions and worked with thousands of amazing artists.  We make the most of the resources we have and we give artists the space & support to do their best work.  Now we want to give the artists who make Bootleg Theater a chance to work on a piece of theater of their own.  And we want you to be a part of it.

Your generous donations will put you in the mix, you will be part of the process...a part of the Bootleg team!  There are all kinds of levels to be included with rewards of all sorts: mentions in our program and on our website, all the way to a year long VIP pass to Bootleg events. 

Please look at the contribution levels and perks and decide what works for you. A contribution of any amount will help bring this show to life.

Don't have the money to contribute right now, but you want to support and be a part of the process? There are lots ofother ways to help!

  • Share this campaign or like us on Facebook! You can do it right on this page, just click on Share.
  • Buy tickets to the show at www.bootlegtheater.org
  • Bring friends to the show!
  • Do you have skills & resources you would like to contribute as an in-kind donation.  Send us an email at info@bootlegtheater.org and we will gladly accept your help.

story:
**note from Jackdaw Pike playwright STEVE BELLWOOD...

 

 

Our premier production of The Specials concluded a few weeks ago, and our fund-raising juice seems to have got up and gone. A plea to raise expenses that have already been expended lacks a certain current of sizzle and spark. Various pre-production curve-balls - including a necessary re-casting and the sudden loss mid-rehearsal of our stage-manager, plus the initial lack of a promotional person, meant our campaign kicked off at the same time our show did. We need to cherish it as a learning-process. However, the production itself was a su bstantial success, well-received (by an audience of 400 plus, well-reviewed and outstandingly ensembled. And it did inspire the JP core to begin planninfg future production (incl. a revival of The Specials) in the Spring. Also in planning are ongoing workshops, presentations and dialogues. Possibly under the non-profit rubric of Rainbow recycling, my own company, whose original mission statement was "to promote sustainability and environmental awareness through inspiring, entertaining and educational arts programs. We look forward to activating such a mission in the very near future. And we vouchsafe any past or future donations will be used to this purpose. Meanwhile we'd like to sincerely thank all who contributed to us, with money, time, talent or encouragement, and we trust in your future support which we will continue to strive to earn.

we may always be contacted at manwithwords@aol.com

or you can always friend us on Facebook, Steve Bellwood or David Pilot.

 

 

 

 

We're a new source of live theater and brand new plays in Connecticut

New Haven, Conn. has long been a not-so-secret place for great theater at reasonable prices. Many plays born here have gone on to become national favorites while new collaborations and loyal theater-goers continue to make New Haven a vibrant theater town.

“The Specials,” a new drama by playwright Steve Bellwood, has emerged from just such a collaboration.

This contemporary American story was created by a new partnership between Bellwood, Director James Leaf and Producer David Pilot under the auspices of nine-year-old underground theater company Jackdaw-Pike.  It is the first in a series of theater events being planned by the company.  

The world premiere of "The Specials" is September 14, at the Whitney Arts Center in New Haven, CT. There will be five performances, from Sept. 14 to 22. (See full dates and times below) A dozen inspired professionals have worked for months to bring it to the stage and it has paid off with a play that is tightly written and a cast we are very proud of. 

We have worked hard to arrange the best possible terms to keep costs low and have received generous help from the community: Long Wharf Theater and The New Haven Theater Company have helped with some of the props, costumes and lighting; rehearsal space was generously donated by Bob and Susan Frew of Frew Management in New Haven and Never Ending Books has provided unending encouragement.The Whitney Arts Center in New Haven has offered generous terms for a 99-seat theater, agreeing to split the door with us 50-50.

And most important, we are committed to making theater accessible to everybody by setting the price of admission at FREE,  with a suggested donation of $15 per ticket for those who can.

Our fundraising goal of $8,500 will pay talented actors and cover the remaining costs for props, costumes, lighting, transportation, insurance required by both Equity and the venue, publicity, sets and crew.  It's what our out-of-pocket costs will be by the end of September.

If you’re reading about our campaign you’re likely already a member of the choir. But if you’ve wandered off in recent years, maybe you’re here because you remembered that  good live theater is like food and without it we are culturally starved. Welcome back and thanks for your support!



  “The Specials” is about the accidental meeting of two very different couples set in a contemporary American landscape.

Tom and Diane, two bickering academics on a cross-country road trip, experience car trouble in an unfamiliar suburb far from home. They are rescued by Ivan, an elite military veteran, and Ruth, his young, ex-stripper wife. So begins an uncomfortable encounter that becomes ever more unpredictable as boundaries are broken and new identities emerge. 

“It’s a passionate story about the splitting of the American soul,” Producer David Pilot says.  “It’s about a ritual of healing and confrontation.”  




MARIAH SAGE*, "Diane," is a member of Actors’ Equity Association, and has performed in theaters across the country and in Europe including: The Public Theater, The Cleveland Playhouse, The Trinity Rep, Imago, and The Apollo in Dusseldorf, Germany. Mariah earned her BFA in drama from NYU/Tisch School of the Arts and her MFA in acting from Brown University/Trinity Rep. She is Co-Founding Artistic Director of New Haven's Theatre 4. Mariah has taught acting and coached actors at Brown University, NYU/Tisch School of the Arts, Fairfield University and Quinnipiac University. Through her company Present & Perform she coaches actors who are preparing for college admission auditions as well as presentation skills for business people. www.presentandperform.com



JAMES LEAF, Director, “Tom” has directed Samuel Beckett’s “Catastrophe” for The Young Mechanics, and Clifford Odet’s “The Big Knife” for Eastbound Theatre.  He has acted in productions at Square One Theatre, New Haven Theater Company, and Long Wharf Theatre.  At the American Repertory Theatre’s Loeb Drama Center, he directed productions of “Danton’s Death,” “Marat/Sade,” “Lysistrata,” and “Cloud 9.”  He holds a BA in Theatre Studies from Harvard College, and has taught theater at University of Michigan, Amherst Summer, Harvard Comenius Project, Elm Shakespeare and Barnard College.  



IRINA KAPLAN, "Ruth," is delighted to be part of “The Specials.” She is currently in her third year of training at The Actors Studio Drama School, where she will graduate in the Spring with her MFA in acting. Recent New York credits include “Eat the Chicken” at Manhattan Repertory Theatre, and “Black Milk” at Classic Stage Company. Before moving to New York, Irina was a kindergarten teacher in Austin, Texas (a job that taught her a lot about patience and a lot about puppets). In 2010, Irina graduated with her BA in American Culture from Vassar College.




DANIEL J. WHITE, "Ivan," is excited to be performing in “The Specials.” White has acted and directed in more than 20 productions at the Downtown Cabaret Theater and the Polka Dot Playhouse in Bridgeport, the Westport Community Theatre, and elsewhere.  He studied acting at the Strasberg Institute in New York. He thanks Lance Corporal Michael Nachin, USMC, for his insights on being a marine.




STEVE BELLWOOD, Playwright, Co-Producer,  is renowned for his poetry, plays and improvised musical monologues he calls ‘stand-up storytelling.’ He is a veteran of the London Fringe and NYC Off-Off Broadway. He is devoted to the New Haven Fringe and is an active member of Theatre Artists Workshop in Norwalk.  Recently, he performed solo shows at theater festivals in London, Boston, California and northern UK.  Nine years ago he founded underground theater group Jackdaw-Pike. www.stevebellwood.com



DAVID PILOT, Producer and Assistant Director, is a writer, director and filmmaker whose plays have appeared at the Collective Unconscious, New York International Fringe Festival, Ontological-Hysteric Theater, the Williamstown Theater Festival, the Women’s Project, The Religious Society of Friends and elsewhere.

He has written more than a dozen plays, including "Hans: A Case Study,” last staged at New York’s West End Theatre;  “Rebecca Bonnie Bob,” at New York’s Theater For The New City, “American Slave Code,” at the New York International Fringe Festival; and “Malleus Maleficarum” at Ontological Hysteric Theater.

He is currently screening two films: “Saving Manhattan,” a feature series (w/ Amy Poehler) & “Skin In The Game,” a documentary about the rise of internet adult star, Raven Riley.


ANNIA BU, Co-Producer, received her BFA in Acting from the Instituto Superior de Arte, Havana, Cuba. She held leading roles in major Cuban films,“Los Dioses Rotos,” “El cuerno de la abundancia,” & “Larga distancia.” She received Best Actress awards in important international film festivals, GIFF, USA; Ceará, Brazil and Premio Llauradó, Havana, Cuba. She is a graduate of the Escuela Internacional de San Antonio de los Baños, Cuba, where she studied the Meisner Technique and collaborated on several films.  In theater, she acted in “Fedra,” at Teatro El Público (La Habana, 2009) and in “Una Caja de Zapatos Vacía” at the University of Miami. On IMDB



MARGARET CARL, Co-Producer, is pleased to be working again with Steve Bellwood after a long hiatus. She was a founding member and production stage manager of Algonkuin Players Theater Company in Hamden, Connecticut. She has stage managed for Yale Baroque Opera Project Cheshire Youth Theater, Cornerstone Productions, the Arts and Ideas festival in New Haven, the Shoreline Alliance for the Arts, Elm Shakespeare Co., Projects for a New Millennium, Jackdaw Pike, Puppetsweat Theater, and many other theater and dance companies and special events over the last 25 years.


BEATRIX ROELLER, Stage Manager, grew up in East Germany where she gained a respect and love for the arts as a form self-expression and freedom.  Over the past 10 years, she has used her background in engineering and passion for the arts to benefit various community productions. From creating elaborate props and scenes, helping countless children get their cues on time, to production fundraising and marketing, Beatrix has proven to be an asset to New Haven’s art scene. Beatrix is a professional photographer for Yale University. For the past two years she has served as president of Art Centered Education at Educational Center for the Arts (ECA) in New Haven


Saturday, September 14th @ 8:00 pm
Sunday, September 15th @ 3:00 pm
Friday, September 20th, @ 8:00 pm
Saturday, September 21st @ 8:00 pm
Sunday, September 22nd @ 3:00 pm

The Whitney Arts Center
591 Whitney Ave (near Cold Spring Street)
New Haven, CT 06511

TICKETS
$15 suggested donation (it’s a steal!)
To reserve seats, call 203-676-9685

Directed by:
J A M E S  L E A F

Starring:
M A R I A H  S A G E  *
J A M E S  L E A F
I R I N A  K A P L A N
D A N I E L  W H I T E

Produced & Assistant Directed by:
D A V I D  P I L O T

Co-Produced by:
A N N I A  B U
M A R G A R E T  C A R L
S T E V E  B E L L W O O D
J A M E S  L E A F

Stage Manager:
B E A T R I X  R O E L L E R
   
*Appearing Courtesy of Actors Equity Association


                   Join us

                   on Saturday, October 5, from 7-10 pm

        for a FREE evening of FILM, LIVE MUSIC, POETRY  & 

     PERFORMANCES 

      at Luck & Levity Brew Shop, 118 Court Street, New Haven, CT. 

                                 Crazy prizes and a theater quiz accompany the

               culmination of our Indiegogo Campaign!  


T h a n k s   f o r   s p r e a d i n g   t h e   w o r d


Find  “The Specials” and Jackdaw-Pike on the web here: webpage

And on Facebook here: Facebook

Email us at: 4thespecials@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?


What We Need & What You Get
Break it down for folks in more detail:

Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.



The Impact
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
Make it real for people and build trust.



Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!


And that’s all there is to it.

story:
＊Korean version is below the English version.＊

The Project

My First Musical is a pr Prooduction company dedicated to allow a flesh breeze into musical theatre by the international collaboration beyond the border of countries, cultures and genre. With a Korean director, a Japanese producer, a French writer and composers from UK and Cyprus, Flatmates V Zombies is a truly international experience.

Flatmates v Zombies to be performed at Camden Fringe Festival in August 2013 and also in the West End as part of the Final Showcase of MA in Musical Theatre, Goldsmiths in September 2013.

 

The Musical

LONDON- whole world in one city. A place where unskillful thoughts about other races get rubbed off you as you jostle through the rush hour. But what if London broke? What if all Londoners became ZOMBIES and strangers remained okay? How would you cope?

Flat V Zombie is a new zombie musical sitcom. Looks at what it is to be foreign in London, a city which now boasts 52% of inhabitants are from another country. Cross-cultural communication and the alienation of international students and immigrants will be the theme of the show.

The aim of our show is to celebrate the individuals beyond their cultural stereotypes. With 7 zombie dancers, singers and a small zombie orchestra, we believe we can create a musical about London.

The story started in Croyden, London. There are five international students who have came to London to follow their dreams. For them London is a place of harmony, a place that gives them permission to something that they can't in their country. Then, the disease, the virus spread steadily from place to place, all native Londoners had became zombies. The five students have no choice but to escape London if they can…

 

Our Story

MyFirstMusical Production is the fruit of a company of the people who have completely different background in terms of nationality, culture and field. Everyone working on it has never made a musical before. We are professional in own fields (writing, music, dance, design, etc.), but hasn't actually put a musical, so the piece we are making is truly new and unique.

 

Budget Breakdown

This is non-profit production and the producers invest their own money into the production to create new musical piece in London. All members of crew including creative team, actors, production team are working for same aim without getting any salaries. While, we still need your support to develop the show. Our fundraising goal is £1500, not a huge amount of money, but it does means a lot to us. We do appreciate your help!

We need your support to develop the show especially for the physical production, which is stage set, costume, props and SFX, and the transportation fee for the actors and crew. It is the majority of the budget.

Materials: 30%      Stage set, Costume, Props and SFX

Transportation fee 30%      Actors 6, Crew 17

Rental Costs: 25%      Venue hiring fee, Camden Fringe Festival registration fee

Publicity: 10%      Script copying, Poster/Flyer, Audio Recording, Video Recording

Other: 5%

 

The team

Flatmates V Zombies is directed by White Hyun Ju Beak, a musical-theatre actor in her own right in her native South Korea, and produced by Shiori Hirota, a project manager who has the background of musical theatre director and company manager, from Japan. Stage and co-costume designer is Hiroko Matsuo, who has designed more than 40 productions in the UK and her native Japan. Writer Chris Hogg from France is a scriptwriter, poet and internet specialist enjoying his first foray into musical theatre. Musicians Michael Neo, from Cyprus, and Julia Sukan Del Rio, from UK, have not collaborated before this project but have decades’-worth of composing experience between them. Ayaka Takai is versatile choreographer who had worked the unique collaborative works which are body percussion and dance movement psychotherapy in UK and Japan.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share share share!!! Thank you!

 

For more information

https://www.facebook.com/FlatmatesVZombies

http://myfirstmusicalcom.wordpress.com/

Twitter: @myfirstmusical  #zombiemusical

Camden Fringe Festival:  http://camdenfringe.com/index.php?id=1

Tristan Bates Theatre:  http://www.tristanbatestheatre.co.uk/Goldsmiths_2013.asp

Press coverage (Comden Review)

http://www.camdenreview.com/reviews/theatre/camden-fringe-highlights#.UfqqlxLhUYA.facebook


일년 전 처음 런던에 왔을 때, 모든 것이 낯설고 두려웠습니다. 사람들은 알아들을 수 없는 말을 하는 외계인 같았고, 길을 건너는 일, 물 한병 사 마시는 일도 내게 새로운 도전이었습니다.

그렇게 영어 한마디 하는 것조차 두렵고 무서웠던 한국인 유학생으로, 저는  스물 네 명의 사람들과 첫 프로덕션을 만들었습니다. 영국 친구들은 기적을 만들고 있다고 얘기합니다.

이 뮤지컬은 ‘나의 이야기’ 입니다. 한 명의 한국인으로, 공연 예술인으로, 런던의 이방인으로 보고 느낀 것들을 지난 육개월 동안 영국인 작가, 크리스와 함께 써나간, 저의 이야기 입니다. 그리고 이것은 ‘우리 이야기’ 입니다. 서울이라는 도시가 그러하듯이 런던도 많은 문제점들을 감추고 아무렇지도 않은 척 하고 있다는 것을 크리스를 통해 배웠고, 그런 점에서, 나라나 국적, 문화와 상관 없이 우리 모두는 비슷할지 모른다는 생각이 들었습니다.

적절한 페이도 받지 못하고 전 스탭들, 배우들은 모든 에너지, 재능과 시간을 이 프로젝트에 쏟아붓고 있습니다. 그 덕분에영국의 가디언, 캠든 뉴 저널 그리고 캠든 메이어가 180개 캠든 프린지 페스티벌 작품 중 대표작으로 저희 작품을 대표작으로 추천하기도 했습니다.

이 이야기는 결코 한 번에 끝나지 않을 것입니다. 작품 속 유미가 런던에서 고군분투 하는 모습에서 조금씩 조금씩 발전해 나가고 플랫 메이트들의 영웅이 되어 가는 모습처럼, 이 작품도 시간을 두고, 다듬고 고쳐서 더욱 더 노력하고 발전 시키고 싶습니다.

여러분이 도와주신다면 그렇게 어려운 일만도 아니라고 생각합니다. ‘코리안 좀비 뮤지컬’이라는 부제에 이렇게 많은 사람들이 관심을 갖는 다는 사실은 우리 작품에 많은 잠재력이 있다는 것을 보여준다고 자신합니다.

열심히, 최선을 다하겠습니다. 에딘버러 페스티벌에도 출품하고 그리고 언젠가는 웨스트 엔드에도 가고 싶습니다! 도와주세요!!!

story:
Who We Are:

Wishbone Theatre Collective is a supportive community of artists based in Chicago IL. Wishbone began as a group of Clemson University graduates and one University of Virginia graduate, but has since expanded to include some pretty amazing people from a variety of places. Wishbone is dedicated to producing plays that explore the thrill of chance. Recently, Wishbone's devised plays have become the backbone of the company, and Wishbone is very excited to take one of their most successful shows to Edinburgh Fringe Festival this fall!

What Our Play Is About:

SPANDEX is an ensemble-devised play that investigates the image of the American Superhero through the eyes of young children. Dealing with issues of justice, revenge, and responsibility, SPANDEX asks what it means to be super in the world today. As young children present a project on their ideal superhero, a group of adult characters are desperately debating the fate of a young man convicted of killing a police officer. SPANDEX explores the notion that superhero stories are often not far from our own as a nation dedicated to justice. The question is...is there anyone really there to save us?

Where The Money Goes:

  • $11,000 (Covers airfare.)
  • $2,300 (Covers ground transportation.)
  • $1,600 (Covers the cost of Greenside Venue 231.)
  • $1,500 (Accomodations in Edinburgh.)
  • $800 (Covers International and Fringe Insurance policies.)
  • $500 (Covers festival costs.)
  • $300 (Covers marketing materials.)

The Team:

Writer: Laurie Jones

Director: Katie Jones

Ensemble: Andrew Bailes, Elizabeth Finley, Brandon Little, Erin Lovelace, Mandy Stertz, Paul Vonasek, and Kim Van Ness.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you're unable to donate, we completely understand. You can still help us, though, by spreading the word and sharing our campaign with others!

story:
Short Summary

What happens when 2 children's book authors meet up with an acclaimed children's theater director and Broadway publicist? Magnificent Productions is what happens! Mary Cashman & Cynthia Whipple had just published their first children's book, Merrilee Mannerly & Her Magnificent Manners, when they were approached by director Ryan Ratelle with the idea of turning their book into a musical. Ryan teamed the authors up with the wildly talented composer/lyricist team of Jeffrey Lodin and William Squier. The rest, as they say, is musical theatre history!

We couldn't be prouder of our new show, Merrilee Mannerly, a Magnficent New Musical! And we are so happy that others love it too! At our first New York City reading of the play for industry insiders, our musical was picked up by the prestigious Summer Theatre of New Canaan for their 2014 season! Next stop, off-Broadway! Your support will help us cover some of the necessary costs of development and production to bring us to New York City!

What We Need & What You Get

We are so fortunate to have some wonderful people supporting our pre-production efforts, but the costs associated with development and production rise with every step. With some help from all you wonderful people out there, we are ready to make our next big move to bring Merrilee and her friends to Manhattan!

And you can be sure we won't forget OUR manners! From a BIG thank you on our Facebook page, to a handwritten note from the authors, to school visits,  we will remember to give each one of you a big THANK YOU for every contribution!!

The Impact

Merrilee Mannerly isn't just another children's musical. Not only does Merrilee teach kids (without them realizing it!) the importance of kindness, respect and gratitude, it does it in a really fun and funny way! Adults will love this show just as much as the kids. We promise you, once you hear our show tunes, you won't be able to stop humming them!

Move over Pinkalicious, Freckled Face Strawberry and Berenstein Bears, there's a new girl in town and her name is Merrilee Mannerly!

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope you will consider donating to our show- no amount is too small! If you find you can't make a monetary donation at this time, please help us by spreading the work about our indiegogo campaign and be sure to LIKE us on our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/merrileemannerly.)

story:
Who am I?

Hello, my name is Omar Forrest. I am a Bard college graduate who has been involved in theatre since I was four or five years old. I have acted in everything from Shakespeare to the BFG. In high school, I fell in love with the ability to build worlds and tell stories and have been writing and directing ever since. Theatre is a truly vast art form in which we start with an empty stage and mold it into a dream, an art form that can change the very fabric of how physics works.  Despite the limitless possibility that is theater, we creators find ways of constraining ourselves to a single perspective art form in which the audience is looking through a window at actors who are standing before them. We put these artificial start and stop times on the experience as if the whole world of the show was created as the audience sat and destroyed when they stood.

It’s time to throw off these chains!

We live in a world where Amazon, Facebook, Uber, and the web in general, allows us to sit in one place and interact with the world at large in a way that generations before us could never have dreamed possible. If theatre is meant to be the voice of the day, why does it feel a need to limit itself to what is physically in the space the theatre?  It can… no, must learn to use the technology that the rest of the world is using and view the very notion of space in the way that its audience views it if it ever wants to be relevant in the modern world!

How YOU Can Help!

For this project to work, we need your help. We call on you to do two tasks:

1) In mid-November we will begin asking you if murder can ever be justified. It is your answer to this question that will influence the end of the play. Yes, you read that right. The actual scripting of the play will change according to your votes! The play’s experience need not wait until curtain to begin we invite, need, you to BE A PART of the creative process.

2) We also need your donations to make the show run.  We need to buy costumes, props, and set pieces as well as pay our actors. It is far too often the actor is not paid or that he must put up with less than adequate pay. The actors of this show need to be compensated for their time.  To make the show run smoothly we need $1500. Every dollar matters

Also, remember what I said about that vote? If you donate 20 or more, you will get an extra vote. What is the difference between a politician and a merchant really?

100 or more gets you a recorded video of the show. A multi media live show about technology made not live the use of technology, what more could you want?

Those lucky few who donate $200 or more will get the option to have coffee with the show’s creator and ask him any questions about the show that are on your mind.

What Stands in Our Way

Any theater production is hard to pull off, but I am confident in my experience and skills that with proper funding this The Dialogue will be a success. Through Northwest High School, Bard College and The Hamlet Project I have gained experience directing from Shakespeare to modern to just straight up bizarre shows 

The main obstacle at the moment is the cost of props and recording equipment. this show uses a lot of recordings and this equipment is anything but cheap. We also need to pay to rent a space during tech week but with your help, we can make this a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, we understand. However, please share this campaign with your friends and family. The more people we reach, the closer we will get to our goal. Every little bit helps.

We need your help to show what the modern theater could be. We need your support to show how the modern theater could interact with people on their terms. We need your generosity to make our show a reality.

We look forward to seeing you at the performance!
story_txt:
Who am I?
Hello, my name is Omar Forrest. I am a Bard college graduate who has been involved in theatre since I was four or five years old. I have acted in everything from Shakespeare to the BFG. In high school, I fell in love with the ability to build worlds and tell stories and have been writing and directing ever since. Theatre is a truly vast art form in which we start with an empty stage and mold it into a dream, an art form that can change the very fabric of how physics works.  Despite the limitless possibility that is theater, we creators find ways of constraining ourselves to a single perspective art form in which the audience is looking through a window at actors who are standing before them. We put these artificial start and stop times on the experience as if the whole world of the show was created as the audience sat and destroyed when they stood.
It’s time to throw off these chains!
We live in a world where Amazon, Facebook, Uber, and the web in general, allows us to sit in one place and interact with the world at large in a way that generations before us could never have dreamed possible. If theatre is meant to be the voice of the day, why does it feel a need to limit itself to what is physically in the space the theatre?  It can… no, must learn to use the technology that the rest of the world is using and view the very notion of space in the way that its audience views it if it ever wants to be relevant in the modern world!
How YOU Can Help!
For this project to work, we need your help. We call on you to do two tasks:
1) In mid-November we will begin asking you if murder can ever be justified. It is your answer to this question that will influence the end of the play. Yes, you read that right. The actual scripting of the play will change according to your votes! The play’s experience need not wait until curtain to begin we invite, need, you to BE A PART of the creative process.
2) We also need your donations to make the show run.  We need to buy costumes, props, and set pieces as well as pay our actors. It is far too often the actor is not paid or that he must put up with less than adequate pay. The actors of this show need to be compensated for their time.  To make the show run smoothly we need $1500. Every dollar matters
Also, remember what I said about that vote? If you donate 20 or more, you will get an extra vote. What is the difference between a politician and a merchant really?
100 or more gets you a recorded video of the show. A multi media live show about technology made not live the use of technology, what more could you want?
Those lucky few who donate $200 or more will get the option to have coffee with the show’s creator and ask him any questions about the show that are on your mind.
What Stands in Our Way
Any theater production is hard to pull off, but I am confident in my experience and skills that with proper funding this The Dialogue will be a success. Through Northwest High School, Bard College and The Hamlet Project I have gained experience directing from Shakespeare to modern to just straight up bizarre shows 
The main obstacle at the moment is the cost of props and recording equipment. this show uses a lot of recordings and this equipment is anything but cheap. We also need to pay to rent a space during tech week but with your help, we can make this a reality.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, we understand. However, please share this campaign with your friends and family. The more people we reach, the closer we will get to our goal. Every little bit helps.
We need your help to show what the modern theater could be. We need your support to show how the modern theater could interact with people on their terms. We need your generosity to make our show a reality.
We look forward to seeing you at the performance!

story:
Who is Saint Fortune, and what is "One Small Step"?

We are a group of collaboratively-minded artists devoted to new forms of performance practice created through radical collective creativity. We seek to dissolve the boundaries between reality and performance by creating bold and unconventional performances that encourage new ways of looking, listening, and experiencing the world around us.

"One Small Step" is our latest adventure and will be landing at the New Ohio Theater on July 4th! An auspicious date for an ambitious show! What's more, NEXT YEAR is the 50th Anniversary of Apollo 11! July 20th, 2019.

The piece is created by a team of actors, directors, designers, dancers, writers and musicians. It is a hallmark of our ensemble that no one person specializes or does one thing; we all share inspirations and create together because we believe that the best ideas emerge when one is allowed to explore outside of their comfort zone and challenge themselves. This piece is created by Gavin Price, John Gasper, Natalie Mack, Emily Pacilio, Emily Craver and Jack Frederick, with costumes by Parron Allen and lights by Evan Anderson.

This show first appeared at La Mama's Sound Departures in January 2017 as an audiovisual exploration of the Apollo 11 Moon Landing. We were fascinated with the level of ambition, technology and risk that it took to complete this famous journey, and were also curious as to what might have happened had the mission gone completely wrong. As we did more research and learned about the moon hoaxes of the 19th century, and took a deep dive into the physics and metaphysics of inter-dimensional realities, we emerged with a show that uses performance as time-travel in an effort to tell a story about what could've happened had Neil, Buzz and Michael Collins entered an alternate reality from the one we all know too well.

We performed a version at the Bushwick Starr for Elevator Repair Service's "No Great Society and Friends" in June 2017, took the show on the road to the No Theme Festival in Poughkeepsie, NY, in October 2017, and were then curated by ERS to perform at this season's 25th Anniversary of New Ohio's Ice Factory Festival! Ice Factory has served as the launchpad for many of downtown theater's most restless innovators, and we are honored and humbled to present this work at a festival with such a rich and experimentally-focused history.

With this campaign, we hope to raise the funds that will allow us to pay our collaborators for their awesome work, rent the rehearsal space necessary to create live performance, and realize an immersive audiovisual design that will utilize live video feeds, audio and visual synthesizers, avant-garde dance, and light shining through buckets of water.

This is Saint Fortune's most ambitious project yet, and we can't do it without your help!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $3000 with this campaign:

  • $2000 artists fees
  • $600 for design elements
  • $400 for rehearsal space

We are incredibly excited to offer some amazing perks if you choose to be so generous and donate to our campaign:

AN OUT-OF-THIS-WORLD T-SHIRT DESIGNED BY OUR COSTUME DESIGNER PARRON ALLEN​​

Show your support for Saint Fortune and alternate dimensions by sporting this t-shirt that shows what it's like if there was life on the moon! Printed on American Apparel shirts, these are guaranteed to be stylish, comfortable and conversation-starting. 

A CASSETTE OF THE SOUNDTRACK TO ONE SMALL STEP'S MAIDEN VOYAGE

That's right, Millennials, cassettes are back and better than ever. This one features recordings made by Gavin Price and John Gasper for the first iteration of "One Small Step", presented at La Mama's Sound Departures series. Released by our dear friends Dead Definition out of Philadelphia, PA, you will be able to take the otherworldly sounds of the show with you wherever you go.

MAJOR MAGICS WILL COME TO YOUR HOME OR PARTY AND PLAY JUST FOR YOU!

Major Magics is a dream pop band whose members are John Gasper, Natalie Mack and Gavin Price. Their music will take you through your summer months with ease and cool down your hot house. They are ready to play a live concert for you including a PERSONALIZED jingle! https://soundcloud.com/majormagics

How Can I Support Beyond The Campaign?

We appreciate you taking the time to read our campaign and for considering a donation to make "One Small Step" happen! Of course, anything you can contribute is greatly appreciated, but what would make us most happy is for you to come see the show at New Ohio Theater, opening on July 4th and running for four nights. Details about the show and to purchase tickets can be found here: 

http://www.newohiotheatre.org/onesmallstep.htm

Thank you for supporting Saint Fortune's "One Small Step"!

story:
P A S T |

szalt is an emerging collection of Los Angeles movers, collaborating with musicians and visual artists, artistically led by dancer/choreographer, Stephanie Zaletel. Within the three years, Zaletel has produced and set over seven new works across Los Angeles with szalt, including flowersallawomansbody, an evening-length performance that debuted at ARC Pasadena in late 2012, and tuesday., an installation piece for the Hammer Museum’s Made in LA series in collaboration with James Kidd and the Pieter Performance Space Council. 

P R E S E N T |

In 2015, szalt began offering weekly open company classes (sOCCs) featuring teachers within szalt, and regularly hosting professional movers from both coasts. We want to share and surround ourselves with high quality artists of every variety, to learn and grow from the resources around us, and build a stronger sense of community as Los Angeles based artists.

szalt is a highly collaborative quintet and encourages all varieties of artists to be involved in the process.

Frequent Collaborators Include:

  • Louis Lopez - Music & Sound Design
  • GRAMPUS - Electro-Acoustic Sound Trio 
  • Andrew Munie - Lighting Design
  • Alex Gaines - Set and Lighting Design
  • Nebras Hoveizavi - Photography
  • Samantha Shay - Video and Photography
  • Nadav Heyman - Video and Photography
  • Adam Costa - Art & Design
  • Scotty Zaletel - Art & Design
  • Brigette Lopez - Graphic Design

F U T U R E |

szalt is raising funds to present, Artistic Director, Stephanie Zaletel's world premiere of FLWRS in Los Angeles on May 23 and 24 in a new and uniquely renovated warehouse space in the heart of Downtown LA called HNYPT. This evening-length interactive dance experience will feature a brand new sound score by electro-acoustic composer Louis Lopez, as well as an original set and unconventional lighting design by Alex Gaines built within this one-of-a-kind venue. This highly collaborative event will create a sense of intimacy and inclusion for the audience as the dance will happen close, all around, and with the guests. Gaines and Zaletel intend to transform HNYPT into an alternate universe for the dance to exist and thrive. 

szalt aims to bring excerpts of FLWRS across the country to New York City in August of 2015 as we apply for the Summer Current Sessions Residency. While in NYC we will be hosting workshops and showings with local choreographers, sharing our art with as many humans as possible!

$12,000 will fund

  • $3000 - Performance Venue Rental in LA | rehearsals and (at least) 2 performances 
  • $3,000 - Set Materials and Storage
  • $800 - Paying 4 Dancers $100 Per Performance (LA) 
  • $600 - Composer Fee 
  • $600 - Set and Lighting Designer Fee 
  • $1,500 - Per Diem for 6 LA Humans in NY for 1.5 Weeks
  • $2,500 - $3,000 - 6 Round Trip Flights | NY to LA and Back 

Any surplus of funds will go towards: 

  • Submitting and Bringing FLWRS to Other National and International Festivals!
  • Paying our Dancers (much more fairly) for Rehearsals and Performances!!!!!
  • Paying our Videographer/ Photographer! 
  • Marketing our 2015 Performances!
  • Paying Louis Lopez's Musical Collaborators!
  • Bringing Select Set Pieces to NY!
  • Costumes!
  • Artistic Director Fee!
  • Additional Rehearsal Space Rentals!
  • Hosting Guest Artists for our Dance Community Class Series: sOCCs!
  • Hiring Administrative Team Members!
  • A Savings Account for szalt's Future Endeavors!

Donations to our Indiegogo Campaign will be considered a generous gift to our dance troupe. szalt is currently fiscally sponsored by the Dance Resource Center of Los Angeles (DRC). If you prefer to make a tax-deductible donation to szalt, please click here. All contributions are sincerely appreciated and necessary! 

Thank you for investing in your artistic community. It means the world to us to be able to share our art with you.

We cannot do it without YOU! 

<3 from all of us at szalt.


L.A. | C A S T | F L W R S 

Born and bred in Las Vegas, NV, Stephanie Zaletel completed her BFA in Dance Performance/ Choreography with a minor in Humanities at the California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) in 2012. Upon graduating, Zaletel has performed for locally and internationally renowned choreographers including Barak Marshall, Stephanie Nugent, Colin Connor, and most recently in Danielle Agami’s Ate9 dANCEcOMPANY. Along with dancing in Ate9, Zaletel worked closely with Agami as the company’s stage manager, administrator, and rehearsal director in 2013-2014. Zaletel has performed and presented her own creative work at REDCAT, ARC (Pasadena), Highways, Live Arts L.A., The Electric Lodge, Pieter Performance Space, and ArtShare L.A., and has performed in the Benicassim Festival in Spain. Zaletel has taught contemporary/ modern dance for all ages as well as movement classes for children with Down Syndrome at Lineage and is on the Pieter Performance Space Council. Stephanie Zaletel is the founding Artistic Director of szalt.

Alyssa Alden, a Minnesota native, began training in gymnastics and competition-dance as a child. She later grew into contemporary dance while attending Saint Paul Conservatory for Performing Artists. In 2013, she received a BFA in dance and choreography from CalArts. Since then Alden has studied at Impulstanz Dance Festival in Vienna, as well as The Henny Jurriëns Stichting summer program in Amsterdam. Her professional dance career has included performing in the works of choreographers Ohad Naharin, Julie Bour, Uri Sands, Andre Tyson, Colin Connor, and most recently Danielle Agami’s Ate9 dANCE cOMPANY. Alyssa Alden joined szalt in 2014.

Lindsey Lollie, of Altadena, CA, attended CalArts where she received her BFA in Dance in 2012. Lollie has presented work at REDCAT Studio, ARC Pasadena, Diavolo Dance Space, and the Calarts Commuter Festival. Since her commencement, Lollie has been commissioned to create a new work for Los Angeles Contemporary Dance Company as well as for Jamie Nichols’ CELEBRATE Dance at the Alex Theater. She frequently collaborates with New York based film maker, Victoria Sendra, on creating visual movement projects in addition to her live work. Lindsey Lollie is a founding member of szalt.

After graduating with a BA in Dance from Sarah Lawrence College, Julia Planine-Troiani lived in New York City for seven years, where she danced, researched, and taught: movement and stillness. She has performed nationally as well as in Israel and Austria. In 2013, Julia vaulted into Los Angeles to join Ate9 dANCE cOMPANY. She currently teaches yoga at Hot 8 Yoga and holds her own private practice. Julia joined szalt in 2014.

Jordan Saenz, of Denver, CO, is a freelance dancer and choreographer based in Los Angeles. She came to California to study at Sharon Disney Lund School of Dance at CalArts where she graduated with her BFA in 2012. She has shown her work at REDCAT Fall Studio, Live Arts L.A., Pieter Performance Space, Highways Performance Space, and ARC Pasadena. Most recently, Saenz has been commissioned by Loyola Marymount University and Synapse Dance Theater. She continues to teach and perform for Lollieworks and No(one. Art House, while pursuing her own creative endeavors. Jordan Saenz is a founding member of szalt and acts as the company’s Rehearsal Director.

Louis Lopez is a trumpet player, performer/composer, improviser, and educator. His music making centers around the integration of acoustic and processed sounds in live performance through the signal processing language of Max/MSP/Jitter. His ensemble Grampus, an interface driven trio based in Los Angeles, released their debut album "ILK ILK" on pfMENTUM records to wide acclaim. It appeared on KDVS TOP Ten Jazz Chart amongst the likes of Henry Threadgill and Ravi Coltrane coupled with radio play across the US and Europe. Their music, along with Louis's solo work, has been featured in the work of Stephanie Zaletel's dance company, szalt. Their collaborations have been performed at the Sharon D. Lund Dance Theater, Live Arts LA, and at the Walt Disney Concert Hall's REDCAT Theater. He now is a Professor of Audio at The Art Institute- Inland Empire in San Bernardino where he teaches a variety of subjects including electronics, audio technology, and computer music programming. Louis continues to perform and teach privately in the greater Los Angeles area and abroad. Louis obtained his Master's degree from California Institute of the Arts in Performance/Composition: African American Improvisational Music in 2012. There he studied with such notables as Wadada Leo Smith, Mark Trayle, Edward Carroll, Vinny Golia, Robert Wannamaker, Alfred Ladzekpo, Clay Chaplin, Sara Roberts, and John Fumo. Lopez is a founding member of szalt as a core musical collaborator.

Alex Gaines was born in Houston, Texas. He currently lives in Los Angeles, working as a freelance designer and art director for theatre/film/TV. He is also passionately invested in the promotion of a space elevator as an essential component to the success of the growing industry for deep space travel and  commercial tourism and the colonization of space. He has an MFA in Scene Design and Integrated Media from CalArts and a BFA in Set Design and Tech Direction from Webster Univ. in St. Louis, MO. Some recent credits include co-set design for LATC’s 2014 world premiere HIT, and art director for Live from the Red Carpet for E! Entertainment for the 2015 award show season, the feature Kicks (produced by Animal Kingdom,) and the feature film Excess Flesh, which was recently selected to screen at SXSW 2015.

Nadav Heyman | Film and Photography

Nadav is an LA-based writer and filmmaker.

nadavheyman.com

L.A. | V E N U E 


www.hnyptla.com
Risks & Challenges

Anything worth doing comes with an array of risks and challenges. If we are unable to fully fund FLWRS in Los Angeles we will have to work within the budgetary constraints - create something on a much smaller scale, and keep it local (no NY). We would also have to post pone the May premier to a later date - due to venue costs. 
However, if we DO raise the funds (which we WILL!), we have much to plan in a short span of time. It will be a great deal of work, but worth every minute and every dollar. We will need to secure rehearsal space in Los Angeles and New York, officially book and promote our performances, finish CREATING the hour-long, interactive performance, and get people in the seats! My cast, collaborators, and I are committed to szalt, and have faith that we can soon become a sustainable entity the more we share with the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come take class with us Saturday mornings at Live Arts Los Angeles! 

Come see our shows!

Like us on Facebook: facebook.com/szalt !

Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @_szalt_ !

Spread the word!

Every little bit helps a whole lot! 

Thank you very much <3

Saenz has been commissioned by Loyola Marymount University and Synapse Dance
Theater. She continues to teach and perform for Lollieworks and No(one. Art House, while pursuing her own creative endeavors. Jordan Saenz is a
founding member of szalt and acts as the company’s Rehearsal
Director.


Louis Lopez | Composer

Louis Lopez is a trumpet player,
performer/composer, improviser, and educator. His music making centers
around the integration of acoustic and processed sounds in live performance
through the signal processing language of Max/MSP/Jitter. His ensemble Grampus, an interface driven trio
based in Los Angeles, released their debut album "ILK ILK" on
pfMENTUM records to wide acclaim. It appeared on KDVS TOP Ten Jazz Chart
amongst the likes of Henry Threadgill and Ravi Coltrane coupled with radio play
across the US and Europe. Their music, along with Louis's solo work, has been
featured in the work of Stephanie
Zaletel's dance company, szalt. Their collaborations have
been performed at the Sharon D. Lund Dance Theater, Live Arts LA, and at
the Walt Disney Concert Hall's REDCAT Theater. He
now is a Professor of Audio at The Art Institute- Inland Empire in San
Bernardino where he teaches a variety of subjects including electronics, audio
technology, and computer music programming. Louis continues to perform and
teach privately in the greater Los Angeles area and abroad. Louis obtained
his Master's degree from California Institute of the Arts in
Performance/Composition: African American Improvisational Music in
2012. There he studied with such notables as Wadada Leo
Smith, Mark Trayle, Edward Carroll, Vinny Golia, Robert Wannamaker, Alfred
Ladzekpo, Clay Chaplin, Sara Roberts, and John Fumo. Lopez is a founding
member of szalt as a core musical collaborator.



Alex Gaines | Set and Lighting Designer


Alex Gaines was born in Houston, Texas. He currently
lives in Los Angeles, working as a freelance designer and art director for
theatre/film/TV. He is also passionately invested in the promotion of a
space elevator as an essential component to the success of the growing
industry for deep space travel and  commercial tourism and the colonization
of space. He has an MFA in Scene Design and Integrated Media from CalArts
and a BFA in Set Design and Tech Direction from Webster Univ. in St.
Louis, MO. Some recent credits include co-set design for LATC’s 2014 world
premiere HIT, and art director for Live from the Red Carpet for E!
Entertainment for the 2015 award show season, the feature Kicks (produced
by Animal Kingdom,) and the feature film Excess Flesh, which was recently
selected to screen at SXSW 2015.



Nadav Heyman | Film and Photography
Nadav is an LA-based writer and filmmaker.
nadavheyman.com
L.A. | V E N U E 

www.hnyptla.com


Risks & Challenges


  Anything worth doing comes with an array of risks and challenges. If we are unable to fully fund FLWRS in Los Angeles we will have to work within the budgetary constraints - create something on a much smaller scale, and keep it local (no NY). We would also have to post pone the May premier to a later date - due to venue costs. However, if we DO raise the funds (which we WILL!), we have much to plan in a short span of time. It will be a great deal of work, but worth every minute and every dollar. We will need to secure rehearsal space in Los Angeles and New York, officially book and promote our performances, finish CREATING the hour-long, interactive performance, and get people in the seats! My cast, collaborators, and I are committed to szalt, and have faith that we can soon become a sustainable entity the more we share with the world.  Other Ways You Can Help Come take class with us Saturday mornings at Live Arts Los Angeles! 
Come see our shows!
Like us on Facebook: facebook.com/szalt !
Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @_szalt_ !
Spread the word!
Every little bit helps a whole lot! 
Thank you very much <3

story:
Anthem Theatre Company presents

Season 2016: FAVORITES!

This season marks an exciting new adventure for Anthem Theatre Company. We have been chosen as a Boston Center for the Arts' new Resident Performing Arts Company, or "ResCo"! This wonderful opportunity provides us with mentorship from established Boston companies and artists, help with marketing, and discounted performance space for the next three years! We are honored to be a part of such a prestigious group, and have worked hard in and out of the theatre for the last few years to get here. 

In order to make our mark as a ResCo, Anthem Theatre Company has decided Season 2016 should be spent sharing some of our favorite works with Boston, in our aptly titled SEASON 2016: FAVORITES! 

THE DARE PROJECT: BOSTON, September 15-17, 2016--Anthem introduces New York's "The Dare Project" to Boston Center for the Arts. This ten-minute play festival, co-created by Bryn Boice with taxdeductible theatre company in 2006, is a unique way to engage our growing Boston audience; seven playwrights are DARED to write plays based on audience suggestions. Beloved companies Zeitgeist Stage Company, Office of War Information (Bureau of Theatre) and Moonbox Productions, among others, will participate.

12TH NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD by Brian MacInnis Smallwood, October 27-November 5, 2016--Anthem presents a campy, bloody, gory, romantic Shakespearean comedy just in time for Halloween. This trip to Illyria follows the plot of Twelfth Night until, quite literally, all hell breaks loose. Bryn and Mike are still laughing about the production they saw in the East Village nine years ago, so it definitely belongs in our season of FAVORITES. Featuring a cast of 15 Boston artists, including Johnny Kinsman as Sir Toby Belch, and Bryn Boice as our fearless, blood-soaked director, this twist on a classic is bound to go down in Boston history as the best Halloween adventure ever.

What We Need & What You Get

Anthem Theatre Company's last fundraising campaign in 2013 had incredible impact. We got creative and stretched your generous funding for three years; your support helped us to produce FOUR plays and to win this residency! We believe that with your renewed investment in us, we will launch to a new level in 2016. 
  • We are seeking $8,000 to offset our costs for rehearsal and performance space, artists' fees, promotional costs, insurance, and technical & design elements. Although we get a discount and help with exposure from the BCA, this is a bigger venture than we've ever undertaken, and we need a boost to help us put on these HITS. 
  • Where does the money go? A look inside--> Performance Space (rental and season deposit): $3839; Rehearsal Space: $750-1200; Actor, Designer, Tech, and Playwright Fees: $6275; Sets, lights, costumes, props (and fake blood and guts): $3000; Insurance: $330;  Promotions, PR and advertising: $1560. These are the things we are saving for and fundraising for, and any amount of support you can give will help us to fulfill our mission: to do excellent work that compels our audiences to seek out more theatrical experiences and to make theatre a part of their lives. Support the art form of theatre by supporting us!
  • Perks include: tickets to our Season 2016: FAVORITES!; official Anthem rain ponchos for 12NOTLD front row Splash-Zone supporters; walk-on zombie roles; official Anthem baseball shirts (as seen in Romeo VS. Juliet last summer); Anthem ringer tees; and Anthem grocery totes! Also, if prizes aren't your thing, we are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501 (c)(3) company, so your donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Impact

Your contribution will make a valuable difference in our first season at Boston Center for the Arts. It's an impact that will be felt for years to come:

  • THE DARE PROJECT is a community builder. People who are new-to-theatre or theatre-skeptics absolutely love this project because it's fresh, it's new, and you have the chance to commission a play based on an idea in your head! Audiences from each of the ResCos will join us, and we will introduce ourselves to each others' fans, creating a larger web of art seekers and an expanded audience. This new venture is in tune with our mission and can have an impact on all seven small companies. This kind of good will is priceless, as we believe theatre is not a competitive sport, but an art form to be shared.
  • 12TH NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD is more than a catchy title, it's a holiday show. Halloween is a time for adult fun, too, and we want to put on this theatrical comedy event to draw new, curious audiences to Anthem Theatre Company. This piece showcases our strengths: physical comedy, word play, and showing off Shakespeare's limitless possibilities to a modern, fun-seeking audience. 12NOTLD also has many technical elements that we are excited about building, inventing and exploring, the cost of which your donations will help to offset.
Your donations go a LONG way with Anthem Theatre Company. We use donations wisely and with care, and for the love of this craft. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand this campaign may meet you at a time when you are unable to give. If that is the case, we would sincerely appreciate you sharing this page on social media: make some noise using the Indiegogo share tools! 

If your company does corporate matching, or if your company would like to be a season sponsor, we are always looking for creative ways to partner. Help us help you, and vice versa. We are anxious to make connections and form relationships with sponsors who share our goals!

We'd also love to see you at our shows. There is truly nothing better than your friendly faces in the house.

story:
World, Meet Swing Dance Palestine: 

We are the first swing dancing community in Palestine – located in the Bethlehem suburb of Beit Jalla in the West Bank. We have been learning how to swing dance since May 2014 and we love it. We just had our first birthday a couple of days ago!!!


Being the first is not always easy, and especially being the first swing dancing team in Palestine has not always been a smooth ride.

Learning swing dancing in Palestine sometimes feels a bit like training to play football without ever having or playing a football match. With our small swing community here, we practice together but we rarely get the chance to actually participate in dance parties, this is one big reason behind this campaign.  But we have been so lucky to be invited and take part in the LINDY EXPRESS 2015 in the city of Cork, Ireland. This was a great experience for all of us, and the amount of love, support and encouragement we got by the dancers there from all around the world near and far pushed us to go further and further.


This brings us to the story of the Orient Lindy Express: 

The organizers of the Orient Lindy Express, a big swing festival in Turkey, have invited us  to come to their festival in September 2015 and experience what it’s like to be part of the global swing community and dance together. 

We are super excited about the invitation! This is the only way in which we can meet dancers from all over the world.

This is the link to the festival. Please come and join us there as well!!! http://www.orientlindyexpress.com/



However, we do not have the financial means to go all the way to Turkey. We have to fly from Jordan, as we can't travel through the airport in Israel. As Palestinians, we also need visas in order to go to Turkey. These are all big challenges, but also as Palestinians we don't take "No" for an answer, and so we are looking for your helping hands to give Swing in Palestine a push that it needs.  

So here we are trying to get this crowd funding going and we hope that this will enable us to make our way to Turkey - where maybe we can dance with you too!


What We Need & What You Get


with your donation we are financing this trip. In order to make it happen, we need money for: 

Flights, visas and transport to the airport in Jordan 

Our group consists of 16 members - mostly Palestinians,  two Germans an American and one French. Some of us would like to come to the Festival Istanbul -Turkey. With your help, seven Palestinian members will be able to go to Orient Lindy Express in Istanbul -Turkey. The wonderful organizers of Orient Lindy Express have offered some of us free tickets to the festival, so we mainly need to cover travel costs.

Each flight from Amman costs around 350 Euros. The visas for the Palestinians members each cost 50 Euros and the Travel to Jordan costs 80 Euros each.

In total we need a sum of about 3000 Euros in order to cover all the travel costs for part of the group.

The more money we can get together, the more of us can go. We see ourselves as one group, so we want to go together and we hope we can raise enough money to do this, with your help.


  • Our blog 

 for more words and photos from our group

click here:

http://swingdancepalestine.wordpress.com/about/


  • Risks & Challenges

Although not all of us may travel due to insufficient funding, at least some of us can can go. But we feel as one group and we really hope that we will get enough money together for us to all go together. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give money, you can still help us 

by sharing this campaign... 

Share this campaign on facebook or other social media sites, send it to your friends by email or tell people about it in real life :)


Drop us a line!

For any questions about the swing dancing group in Palestine, please write to:
swingdancepalestine@gmail.com
