story:
A Brief Play Synopsis

     

     Five bottles of centuries old wine are unearthed in a forgotten Paris cellar, wine believed to have been owned by...Thomas Jefferson. This amazing discovery pulls together a cast of disparate characters in a web of comedic intrigue. Denise LeMay, down-on-her-luck adjunct professor, finds herself drawn into the shadowy world of enigmatic Russian wine dealer Rudy Karpov and his scheme to sell the bottles to billionaire energy magnate Arthur Drake. Meanwhile, Ron Johnson, loyal but conflicted agent of the NSA, is assigned, for reasons of national security, to investigate the impending sale by his monomaniacal bureau chief, Connor Bix. As Johnson gets closer to Denise, he becomes more and more uneasy with the NSA’s methods of dragnet data surveillance. Equal parts political satire, espionage thriller, and raucous black comedy, The Jefferson Bottles will have you laughing while pondering the delicate balance between individual privacy and national security.


OUR MISSION

Why is Block St Theatre Co taking on the challenge of producing The Jefferson Bottles? First and foremost because we love this play. Several of us have worked with Todd on developing new work before, and this play is a great example of what makes it so compelling. With a unique voice and a deft comic sensibility, he’s demonstrated an uncanny ability to write plays that are both thought provoking and funny. This is the type of material that actors love taking on.

We’re also doing it because The Jefferson Bottles is play that needs to be performed now. Not in ten years, not in five years, but now. The issues of individual privacy versus national security have never felt more urgent or more relevant than they do in this moment. And, hey, we love the classics, but there’s just something about producing the world premier of a new play. It generates a special kind of excitement that we know the audience will feel as well.

We’re doing it because we love showcasing all the theatre talent—writing, directing, acting, and designing—that resides right here in Fayetteville. That’s why we’re calling ourselves Block St Theatre Co. Not because there’s a physical performance space on Block Street--there’s not.  It’s because we’re all affiliated with the University of Arkansas in some way, but we’re also residents of Fayetteville. Block Street represents the metaphorical heart of a city we love calling home, and this performance represents a way to strengthen the theatre ties between Fayetteville and the UofA.

Our goal of $2,500 represents the bare minimum at which the play can be produced at a professional level. Anything donated above that amount will go to the Humane Society of the Ozarks, located right here in Fayetteville. There are some great perks at each donation level, and you’ll feel good knowing you’re supporting both the development of an exciting new play and the growth of local theatre artists.

Take a look, Northwest Arkansas, at some of the talent we’ve assembled:

Jason Shipman (director) is a recent graduate of the UofA’s MFA program and a veteran of regional professional theatres including The Warehouse Theatre, Cortland Repertory Theatre, and TheatreSquared.

Bill Rogers (actor) will be easily recognizable to area play-goers as a long-time fixture of the local theatre scene. Currently a third-year MFA candidate, Bill is fresh off his triumphant portrayal of Arthur, the lead role in TheatreSquared’s production of Superior Donuts.

Laura Shatkus (actor) is an import from the Chicago theatre scene and a newly minted Razorback MFA grad. She has appeared locally as Elizabeth Poe in The Fall of the House for TheatreSquared and has been seen in productions at The Gift Theatre, Muse of the Fire Theatre, and the Mariposa Nocturna.

Bob Hart (actor) is a theatre polymath with MFAs in both acting and playwriting from the UofA. He created the role of used-car salesman Sonny Dixon in The Gravedigger’s Art, another Todd Taylor original play, and was recently seen in "B-Side Myself, another original play, at TheatreSquared.

Chris Hecke (actor) is a third-year MFA candidate from Brazil. Chris has recently been seen in productions at The Warehouse Theatre and working with the Upstate Shakespeare Festival.

Grant Hockenbrough (actor) will enter the MFA program at the UofA this fall but is no stranger to the Fayetteville theatre scene. He directed a production of Nothing Is the End of the World (except the end of the world) last summer for Broken Branch Theatre Company in addition to numerous university acting credits as an undergraduate.

Todd Taylor (playwright) is an MFA grad whose last play, Flamingo & Decatur, received a reading at the Alabama Shakespeare Festival and was performed in a summer new works collaboration between the UofA and TheatreSquared.  He was the dramaturg on Bob Ford's The Fall of the House for T2.

The Jefferson Bottles will be performed July 17-19 in the university’s black box studio space on the fourth floor of Kimpel Hall. Admission will be free. Don’t miss the chance to be a real part of making this project happen by contributing today.

story:
What is the Hollywood Fringe Festival?

The Hollywood Fringe Festival is a performance art and theatre festival, that includes over 380 shows and 2,000 performances, June 7th - June 23rd. 

http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/

 

My Background

I've studied the craft of acting over the last 15 years, and in that time I've earned my bachelor's degree in Theatre from Portland State University, and continued to work in film, tv, and theatre through out that time. I am passionate about bringing people laughter, and The Actor's Nightmare by Christopher Durang is the show I wanted to perform for my very first Hollywood Fringe Festival.

 

The Financial Breakdown

Pico Playhouse Rehearsal Cost: $240 ( $15 per hour x 16 hours or rehearsal time)

The Lounge Theatre tech & dress rehearsal costs: $120

Sound & Lighting Tech : $120 

Misc. (Water Bottles, etc) $20

IndieGoGo has an approximate 9% take. 

Total Cost $500

Total Funds asked for: $550

 

I certainly understand if money is tight, and I wouldn't ever want anyone to contribute if it put them in a financial bind. Spreading the word about our campaign is another form of support, and I appreciate any support you can give!

 

Evan

story:
Terence gives - Artist: Mesloes

 

Eschatology (noun) - The study of The End. From the
Greek eschatos (the last) and -logy (the study of)

 

"The Eschatology of Terence McKenna" is a new play by Jonathan Fitts scheduled to premiere as part of In/Visible Theatre's Boone Solo (BOLO) Fest 2018. Huzzah!

Described as the "Timothy Leary of the 90s," McKenna made a name for himself as a figurehead of the pre-Millenium psychedelic movement, an art historian, an anthropologist, an author, a philosopher and, perhaps most of all, a storyteller.

With a Shakespearean grasp of language, Terence captivated people across the world with his accounts of the psychedelic experience and his mind-bending philosophies of the nature of reality. The springboard for all of these discussions was his own life experiences, from smuggling hash into Kathmandu and exploring the Amazon with his brother in search of ayahuasca, to becoming a world-renowned psychedelic thought-leader and battling a highly aggressive form of brain cancer.


Terence as a young man in the Amazon
 

In "The Eschatology..." Fitts uses stories from his own life, anecdotes from history, philosophy, and modern science, and tales from McKenna's life to explore Terence's psychedelic dreams that are now at the cusp of our waking reality.

Jon is a dramatist, director, and composer living in Los Angeles, CA. He graduated from Appalachian State University in 2011 with a BA in Theatre, and this marks his first work of theatre produced in Boone since his award-winning play The Pursuit of Mr. Rockefeller in 2010 and In/Visible Theatre's reading of his play Lobotomobile in 2013.

Since then, he graduated from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts with an MFA in Dramatic Writing. Currently, he lives and works as a ghostwriter in Los Angeles while trying to get a foot into the television industry.

"The Eschatology..." marks Jon's first solo show, and his first return to the stage in nearly five years. He's super excited and nervous in all the ways that make theatre fun :)

 

_______________________________________


Artist: Mesloes

 

What We Need & What You Get

Like most of Jon's plays, this show doesn't need a whole lot with regard to production elements. A few articles of clothing, a table, a couple chairs, a few practicals, a guitar, and some music. And Jon. That's it.

The real trick in this cold, capitalist world is everything outside of the art itself --namely, getting from Los Angeles to Boone and back again. He's been able to snag housing, but the travel is still an issue.

  • Economy flights to and from North Carolina are around $300 round trip with tax.
  • An economy car rental to get to and from Boone for a couple days is about $200 with tax.
  • A few final production elements (costume pieces, practicals, etc.) cost around $100.

On the off chance we're able to raise more than $600, the funds will be used to enhance production elements.

For perks, Jon has teamed up with local North Carolina Artist MambiMumbo Art (who happens to be Jon's mom) to create a variety of psychedelic-themed pieces of artwork ranging from digital images to one-of-a-kind works of art.

Check out the perks section for more info!

 

_______________________________________

 


Digital Art based on Shipibo-Conibo Icaros

 

Risks & Challenges

Like most artists, Jon doesn't have a disposable income that allows him to produce his own plays out of his own pockets (would that he did!). If he's unable to raise the funds to attend BOLO 2018, there is a very real chance he will not be able to go and present this show.

The world will keep spinning, but it won't have this play in it for at least another year.

If he's able to go, the show will happen; it's one of the great benefits of producing a solo show!

 

_______________________________________

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, that's okay! You can...

  • Come see the show and attend BOLO 2018! All ticket proceeds will be donated to In/Visible Theatre, so you're supporting a vitally necessary arts organization in Watauga County! Plus, there will be other performers and shows that are certain to be stellar!
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign or the links below via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram...

-"The Eschatology..." Facebook Event
-BOLO 2018 Facebook Event
-In/Visible Theatre's Facebook Page
-In/Visible Theatre's Website

  • Send good vibes!

Finally, THANK YOU for visiting this page! You're an awesome person :)

story:
Hello! My name is Sabina Petra, and I am an actor, singer, composer and writer based in New York City. I've been writing since my graduation musical in kindergarten, but I've finally written my first fully original new musical. It's called MERCURY, about the courageous Jerrie Cobb, who wanted to join the Mercury Space Program in the late 1950s. She got denied because she was a lady, but the extremely shy Jerrie stood up for herself and took her appeal to Congress.

I learned about Jerrie by actually portraying her in an episode of ID Discovery's Mysteries at the Museum. Being an outspoken space-enthusiast myself, I immediately connected with her. I've always been composing separate tracks but this is the first time someone inspired me to write a complete musical story. Her life has been full of courage and a determination to fulfill her dreams - her destiny. With this show, I would like to honor the intense inner struggle she had to face to be able to do so.

The musical is in its final stages of being created. I would love to fund a much needed workshop, which will give the actors, my director Tracy Michailidis (successful actor and director in both the USA and Canada) and our musical director Wiley DeWeese (currently working on the Bob Dylan musical at the Public Theater in New York) and me the opportunity to see the show on its feet and make its final alterations before giving two public readings in New York City on November 12th and 14th. After those readings, we are applying to several festivals, so that we can get the whole musical officially on the launching pad.

The funds will go towards fairly paying the actors, director, musical director, stage manager and venue. It will go towards the studio we will rehearse in, the scripts, scores and re-writes that will have to be printed out and the time and effort that we have to put into the PR (invites, playbills, save-the-dates, video campaigns) for the show - to make sure the right people come see it so Mercury will continue to throttle on - hopefully to the great white (milky) way!

When you contribute you will be able to come and see us perform at Cornelia Street Cafe on November 12 or 14. There will be a ticket waiting for you at the door!

This show is of immense importance to me. Apart from the great message that Jerrie can teach us in this day and age, her personal will-power, curiosity and heart for the great beyond has sparked a fire in me which I would love to pass on to the audience. Also, this show is told in such a different way. It is not your average biography - it doesn't sound like you're listening to a WikiPedia page set to music. It's about her clashing beliefs: the scientist, the activist, the believer and the astronaut all struggling for foothold within her mind. I cannot wait to share this story with you.

Our only challenge is the funding. Casting, musical direction, direction, planning, outline, future structures...everything is accounted for. All we need is your financial support and we can do it. Bring it to Broadway!

Please share our story with everyone! The whole world needs to hear about Jerrie Cobb!

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Our $2,500 indiegogo campaign goal bridges the gap between our anticipated expenses and projected ticket sales and sponsorship revenue. This funding will be divided among all the essential aspects of the Maine Playwrights Festival: publicity, technical staff, tech materials (such as costumes, props, paint, lighting gel, and glowtape for backstage safety), and most important compensating the actors and directors bringing these 6 brand new plays to life!

CONNECTION, by David Vazdauskas

Following a horrific event, the struggle between forgiveness and revenge is complicated by the possibilities of the future.

ELWOOD’S LAST JOB, by Elaine Ford

After forty years of doing menial jobs in a small Maine town, Elwood is about to change his life—and the local laundromat—in dramatic and surprising ways.

MIRACLES, by Ron Kanecke

Two characters who operate a shady business trafficking in miracles are left asking themselves if there may be more truth than they thought in their operation.

THE THING CAROL SAW, by John Manderino

On a contentious car ride home, sometimes it can be hard to know where the line between reality and the imagination really lies.

THE WILD HUNT, by Lynne Cullen

When retired military bomb-sniffing dog Woltan is adopted by an affluent socialite, his former army handler fights to reclaim him.

WALTER LIKES HENNY JUST FINE, by David Susman

During a chance encounter in a ladies’ restroom, an elderly woman counsels her young counterpart on love, life, and the importance of a good lipstick.

Your donation not only helps with this year's specific festival performances, which take place from April 27 to May 6 at the Portland Ballet Studio Theater and May 7 at UMO, but also keeps the festival viable to ensure its long-term stability.

(Planchette, by Carolyn Gage)

Here's what your donation helps to fund:

  • Your $25 donation buys a sheet of plywood to help build the sets
  • Your $50 donation pays the stipend for one actor
  • Your $100 donation rents rehearsal space for one of our six plays
  • Your $250 donation covers the rental cost for one performance
  • Your $500 donation pays the stipends for a stage manager and assistant stage manager for production

Every donation at every level makes a big difference.

Your contribution is important to us, but we don't want that to be the end of your association with the Festival. We want you to see the plays you support, so we are offering rewards ranging from a ticket to an MPF performance of your choice, acknowledgement in the program and/or curtain speech, and an invitation to the MPF cast party!

(Creation, by David Vazdauskas)

The Impact

The Maine Playwrights Festival has been a consistent part of the state's cultural landscape for the past 16 years.  Every year, we inspire dozens of playwrights to write, polish, and submit new plays, and those that are selected receive extensive opportunities to revise their piece with the help of MPF Artistic Director Daniel Burson and our Playwright-in-Residence.  We also hold open auditions for the festival, introducing new actors into the community each year.  Your donation helps Acorn Productions, the MPF's producer, ensure that this annual event is financially stable so that we can continue to offer this unique opportunity to Maine-based theater artists.

(Olive Shrineshade, by Richard Sewell)

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributions of all kinds are needed to get us to our fundraising goal and make the Maine Playwrights Festival a success.

  • Tell all your friends! Pass along the information about this campaign and the Festival. Encourage them to get involved.
  • Volunteer! Contact Michael Levine at acornacting@gmail.com if you would like to usher, help with publicity, or volunteer in some other way.
  • Share this fundraising campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
HERE WE GO: 2020 LAUNCH

__________________________________________________________________________________________

 

The next step in HERE WE GO's journey is to become an LLC. We are here to humbly ask for your help in us taking two vital next steps to becoming a production company:

Funding our Summer 2020 Festival

and

Becoming "HERE WE GO, A Site Specific Production Company LLC"

__________________________________________________________________________________________

YOUR IMPACT ON SUMMER 2020 AND BEYOND

 

JUNE 2020 FESTIVAL ($3,500)

*

HERE WE GO is blasting off this year! Your contribution will first and foremost help fund our Summer 2020 festival, in which we will present  four original pieces out of the 300 submissions that we received last season.

This will be the third iteration of our fully produced bi-annual festival, showcasing the work of early career New York City based artists. We work to make all aspects of production accessible to our artists, as well as to provide all artists with stipends for their important work. We also seek to make our presentations accessible to diverse audiences. In order to do all of this, we need funding for sets, props, lights and venue, as well as stipends for actors, directors, writers, designers and producers. We have always had the philosophy that it is important to financially support early career artists so that they can continue to bring their work to the world and support themselves in the process, which makes this a very important element of what we seek to accomplish through this campaign.

*

LLC FUNDS ($2,500)

A portion of the funds will also go towards the costs associated with becoming an LLC in New York. These funds will help us pay the fees associated with our application, and will also help pay for our LLC status to be published in two New York State publications, giving our status as an LLC legitimacy, as is required for the application. This is an important next step in HERE WE GO's trajectory, as work toward a future where we can seek more consistent, substantial funding, allowing us to continue and expand our support of early-career artists in New York City.

__________________________________________________________________________________________

PERKS

Every little bit counts! All donors, no matter the amount will receive a "Thank You" email from the HERE WE GO producers!

For $25, you will receive the "Thank You" email listed above!

For $50, we will send you an official HERE WE GO sticker, and a "Thank You" email.

For $100, we will send you an official HERE WE GO sticker,  a personalized "Thank You" email, and a listing on our website as a "Ascending" donor!

For $300, we will send you an official HERE WE GO sticker, a personalized "Thank You" email, and a listing on our website as a "Rising" donor!

For $500, you will receive TWO reserved tickets to the Summer 2020 festival before tickets are open to the public, a personalized "Thank You" email, a HERE WE GO sticker, and a listing on our website as a "Soaring" donor!

For $1,000, you will receive a HERE WE GO Annual Membership, which will gain you two free seats at any of our 2020 shows, just email to reserve! You will also receive a  HERE WE GO sticker, personalized "Thank You" email, and a listing on our website as a "Skyrocketing Sponsor"!

__________________________________________________________________________________________

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Follow us on instagram @herewegofestival or visit us online at herewegofestival.com

Come attend our Summer 2020 festival, which you can learn more about on either one of the above platforms.

story:
ABOUT GRITTY CITY REPERTORY YOUTH THEATRE

and

Why You DEFINITELY Want to Invest in Our Work!

If you’re one of the thousands of audience members who has attended a GCRep show, you KNOW that our hallmarks are high energy, unique physicality, and dynamic, powerful, impactful content. We aim to keep y’all on the edge of your seats! 

Gritty City Repertory Youth Theatre is Oakland's rigorous, pre-professional theatrical training program for youth of color. GCRep inspires young adults to risk and explore, developing their leadership, confidence, and compassion for the human family through the production of powerful theatre. We take artistic risks. We do not shy away from difficult subject matter. Our work is both relevant and accessible. By creating a welcoming and safe space for youth and communities of color to experience and process profound and impactful theatre, GCRep is engaging a new and diverse generation of theatre-goers.

We have been performing live theatre in Oakland with an ensemble of youth of color from Oakland public schools for the last 7 years. Every year our audience grows, our budget grows, our programming grows, but our training for youth performers stays 100% free and our ticket prices stay low. Know why? This is theatre by and for the community, and that means no one is turned away for lack of funds. 

Here’s what folks have been saying about the last four GCRep shows:

Caught Up – December 2018

“I haven’t been able to stop talking about this play since I saw it last week. I am still processing days later after seeing such a painful and real story told and held by young African American men and women. The players illuminated how our American system and way of life has been dependent upon dehumanizing people, Africans in particular.  I am still sitting on the edge of my seat, trying to figure out what direction I need to run in to help create change.  This story needs to be told, over and over again.  Especially on Broadway. #ILOVEGRITTYCITYREP.”

 --Janine Greer, Mental Health Specialist, Berkeley City College

A Midsummer Night’s Dream – May 2018

“Massively entertaining, wildly funny, nuanced and electrifying - I haven’t laughed so hard at a show EVER! It was truly, truly brilliant. And my friends absolutely loved it too. Said GCR's A Midsummer Night's Dream was the best Shakespeare they’ve seen.  Top-notch performances by these young and incredibly talented actors.”

--Cara Phillips, graduate student

New World Disorder – December 2017

"For the past 4 years, I've brought my students to see the GCR winter production and once again, with their new show, my students have been blown away. New World Disorder is not just funny, exciting and entertaining, but like so many of Gritty City's productions, it feels necessary."

--Norman Patrick Johnson, theatre artist and Berkeley educator 

The Comedy of Errors – May 2016

"Thank you so much for the tickets to see your FANTASTIC-KICKASS-SHOW. I loved it and so needed to be in Miami, even just for 2 1/2 hours, in Oakland, lol. The cast of Comedy of Errors were phenomenal! The direction was flawless and the play was funny as hell. I couldn't stop laughing. You are definitely top on my list of kick ass directors in the Bay. Looking forward to seeing MORE!  BRAVO. BRAVO. BRAVO!"  

---Kehinde Koyejo, Actor and Business Owner, Kalm Korner and the Artist Self-Care Guide, Oakland 

WHY DID GRITTY CITY REP COMMIT TO FUND THIS PROJECT?

Folks come back to GCRep shows time and time again not only because of our unique perspective, our phenomenal acting ensemble, and our culturally specific story-telling, but also, because our incredible level of professionalism, polish, and high production values create an irresistible night at the theatre, and make our audiences completely forget they are watching youth theatre, and just get lost in the story.

Professionalism matters. Polish matters. High production values matter.  And not just in the play!

We seek to improve your theatre experience as a whole.

How can you suspend your disbelief when you have to shift around on your uncomfortable seat? How can you relax into a story when your booty and back ache so much you can’t even focus?

Help us help you have an amazing audience experience every time you step into a GCRep show! 

GIVING BACK TO OUR WHOLE FLIGHT DECK COMMUNITY

GCRep has started selling out our shows – which is completely thrilling – hosting about 1600 audience members per season. That’s a lot of people!  But even more thrilling is the fact that between all the Flight Deck resident companies, and all of the individual rentals happening throughout the season, more than 10,000 people sit in the Flight Deck audience each year.

That’s right. 10,000.  

And we believe that all of you deserve a much better, more comfortable viewing experience.

HOW WE’RE MAKING IT HAPPEN

It will cost $16,000 to purchase all new seating for the Flight Deck theatre. We have written a $3000 grant, and are committed to support this project with another $3000 from our general organizational funds if YOU, our AMAZING COMMUNITY, will come together and contribute $10,000. Production takes 12 weeks, so help us make this happen and you will be sitting in amazing professional theatre seating at the Flight Deck in fall of 2019!

THE PERKS

We love to show you our appreciation! Here’s what you get – in addition to an amazingly comfortable seat in the audience – for contributing to this campaign:

$1000 – the GCRep ensemble will make you a hilarious, fabulous, personalized singing thank you video and post it on social media!

$500 – a stylish original Captain Unimpressed t-shirt by resident GCRep artist Marc-Éddy Loriston!

$250 – the soundtrack – in advance – for our Nigerian/Argentinian The Taming of the Shrew!

$100 – a copy of our The Taming of the Shrew poster signed by the cast!

$50 – a Gritty City Repertory bumper sticker!

$25 – a shout-out on social media!

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!

We know you believe in the power of art to transform our society. If a donation isn't in the cards right now, you can still make a huge difference by helping us get the word out to as many people as possible! Share the link to this campaign with your friends, family and supporters of the arts. Post on facebook! Tweet about us and use the hashtag #KeepArtinOakland.  

Tell your mom, your neighbor, your church community, your best friend, your teacher, your student, and your pets!  OK, maybe not your pets, but you get the idea!

We are grateful. 

Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ

We do not shy away from difficult subject matter. Our work is both relevant and accessible. story:
Thank you for taking the time to stop by and take a look at our project.  It is only with your help that we can produce our work.  We appreciate your consideration and generosity!  Please consider asking your employer if they participate in matching donations as this is a great way to make a larger contribution.  Our fiscal sponsor is able to meet all 501(c)(3) requirements for tax deduction purposes.  

ACW Dances' mission is to engage with and contribute to the community, with the vision that art should be accessible to all demographics.  Through performance of new modern dance work, collaborative projects with artists of all disciplines, and open discussions, the company aims to entertain and educate while furthering the artistic discipline of modern dance.

We launched this campaign specifically to help pay for our appearance in this summer's DC Capital Fringe Festival.  ACW Dances will be appearing in The Interpersonal Underworld on July 12, 18, 20, 23, and 25 (tickets available June 19 on the Capital Fringe website!).  The show investigates issues of group behavior and interaction through two 20-minute dances linked by common threads.  The title comes from behavior scientist William Schutz who studied interpersonal relations through inclusion, control, and affection.  His hypothesis is that developing groups must move through those three stages in that specific order, and that groups may devolve to earlier stages if they are unable to resolve issues at a particular stage.  Because this deals with issues largely unseen and beneath the surface, he called these dynamics “the interpersonal underworld.”  This production will be presented as a part of the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe.

The primary campaign goal is to earn at least $8,000 for company use.  The "extra" $560 represents the 7% Fractured Atlas fee on our goal amount.  Any amount earned toward our primary goal will go to producing the Fringe show, specifically:

Artist (dancers and musician) project fees
Travel budget for our artists
Technical manager (lights and sound) fees
Capital Fringe participation and insurance fee
Rehearsal space
Publicity, marketing, and other promotional materials
Photography and video
Show necessities such as programs, props, and costumes

Once we hit $8,000, our goal is to keep funding growing.  Should the company earn $10,000 or more, we will be able to give per-performance payments to our involved artists instead of simply one set production fee.  This helps get ACW Dances closer to its goal of paying artists a living wage, something typically outside the reach of small dance companies.  Should the company earn $14,000 or more, we will be able to pay for the Capital Fringe production and also put money toward next season's expenses.  The 2014-15 season is already filling up, with two free performances at The Athenaeum and an appearance at Holiday for Hope (Dreams for Kids) scheduled already, and several more shows are in the works.  Please consider helping us make next season a reality and carry us past our primary goal!

More about us:

ACW Dances is a collaborative venture lead by Abigail Wallace.  Current dancers include Kerry Doyle, Paula Giammarco, Ayelet Haran, and Liz Naro.  Our musicians are Mark Charles Smith (classical guitar), Clara Wallace (voice), and Dan Perszyk (flute).  Jason Allen is the company's resident photographer and video editor, whose work can be seen in our gallery and in every video release of this campaign.  For more information on these artists, please check out the company website!

story:
"Arthur's Stone, Merlin's Fire"

***We aspire to double our goal and with your help we can do it! Funds raised above and beyond the goal of $1200 will go to future OCEAN programs.***

Local professionals team up for a 4th year of high-caliber youth theater. Artistic elements like stage combat, puppetry, original music, and dance will give students technical training and will surprise & entertain viewers.  

  • This play features K-12th grade students from Port Townsend School District’s O.C.E.A.N. (Opportunity, Community, Experience, Academics, Navigation), program which offers independent study for kindergarten through 12th grade. Established in 1996, it is part-time classroom and part-time home based learning with experiential opportunities and high-standard academics. 
  • YOU PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE!
    Because O.C.E.A.N’s theatre program does not receive financial support from the school district, it is entirely supported through donations. 
  • GIVE WHERE IT COUNTS
    Your donation: 1. supports a “pay-what-you-can/no-one-turned-away” box office, making art accessible to all. 2. Creates scholarships so every student, regardless of economics, can participate. 3. Supports the cost of technical elements like props, lighting, costumes, and sets.

Our Goal & Your Gift

Having received a grant from the Port Townsend Arts Commission, we still need $1,200 to make the play a success. Help bring the legend to life!

  • With EVERY donation of $10+ a dance of utter joy and gratitude will commence in your honor!
  • We know it's fun to receive gifts so here are some other things you get by giving to our fundraising campaign: a personal thank you email from the directors, a behind the scenes tour of the making of "Arthur's Stone," a professional copy of the play, and for those who give $250+ you also get a handmade "6th century" relic from the show -- sure to be a conversation starter at your next party!

The Impact

Through theater, students cultivate a love for literacy, history and legends, and strong public speaking skills. They learn teamwork and develop confidence.

  • Six public shows will attract 800+ people of all ages. Copies of professional videos of the show will be donated to the local public libraries, and the show is being publicized regionally as well as internationally. 
  • The involvement of local professionals, educators, families, and a cast ranging in age from grades K-12 creates a meaningful community impact and shared learning in a multi-generational exchange.
  • Past OCEAN productions of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” (2011), “Conference of the Birds” (2012), and last year’s “The Odyssey” (2013) wowed both adult and youth audiences with memorable performances. Highlights included larger-than-life puppets, fantastical handmade costumes, and original music and choreography. “Arthur’s Stone” will be no less amazing with elements like stage combat, life-sized raven puppets, a Stonehenge inspired stone circle, a magical forest canopy, and gorgeous original music by Laurence Cole.    

                             


The Scylla from "The Odyssey" (OCEAN 2013)


"Arthur's Stone" Stage Combat Choreographer, Nathan Barnett, works with student, Bodie LaBrie.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out about the show and make some noise about our campaign!

  • Forward this campaign to your friends and family, invite them to the show, post it to Facebook, like the video on YouTube.
  • Six performances over two weekends will be presented in the Mountain View YMCA gym (1925 Blaine St, Port Townsend): Friday, March 7 & Saturday, March 8 at 7 PM, Sunday, March 9 at 2 PM, also Friday, March 14 & Saturday, March 15 at 7 PM, and Sunday March 16 at 2 PM. Concessions will be available at intermission. All proceeds support the O.C.E.A.N. program.
  • Admission is pay-what-you-can at the door with a suggested donation of $10/adult; $5/children. No one will be turned away. Appropriate for all ages. All proceeds benefit the Port Townsend School District’s O.C.E.A.N. Program. For more info, contact 360-344-3435 or visit www.mandalaforchange.com.

    Thank you for your support, see you at the show!

For more info, contact 360-344-3435 or visit www.mandalaforchange.com.Thank you for your support, see you at the show!

story:
I am SO STOKED to have been voted #1 for "Best of Bawdy!"

MAN there area LOT of amazing storytellers who have (dis)graced the Bawdy stage! And I am so stoked to have been voted to come back!
However, as you know, broke-ass artists don't actually get to jet-set around the country being cool. But it would be so great if we could!
If you have a few bucks to spare & would like to see me at Bawdy, please help out! All proceeds go towards getting my curvy black ass to SF for the show!
love

Mo

story:
Murder by Music is an interactive karaoke murder mystery. It's got songs you know and love, an incredibly talented cast, and needs some money to make this show happen!

What We Need & What You Get

We've got to pay for rehearsal space (that's $15/hour) and while these guys are super talented, the show is complex and needs lots of rehearsal. $750
 
We need costumes for 7 people and props. $1000
 
We need to print flyers and advertise: $650
 
We need to find a permanent location - and locations cost! (hopefully $1500.)
 
We've gotta pay the A/V tech - $500
 
We've gotta record songs for the show: $250

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show! Tickets are only $15!

story:
Our Story

Founded in 2009 with a mission to create an accessible dance experience, Spark Movement Collective (Spark) has quickly established itself through its ability to impact the New York City community with site-specific work and through in-house performances. 

Coming up on its second anniversary, Spark is thrilled to present its first full-length evening work. The work will be given two presentations - Friday and Saturday, April 13th and14th, 2012 - at University Settlement's Speyer Hall in New York City's Lower East Side. 

This exciting evening titled "Push to Play," is composed of two diverse concepts. The first half of the evening explores the many "games" that we experience in the world of dating. Using interviews with friends of Spark, Artistic Director and choreographer Chelsea Koenig weaves together the familiar and, at times, not-so-comfortable "comedy" of romance. The second is a compilation of collaborations with local musicians and artists.

 


The Impact

Like the performance it supports, this campaign is divided into two phases. The first phase is allocated to the performance space, while the second phase will contribute to various production costs. We have achieved our first phase and are now working towards our second phase!

What We Need & What You Get

Spark is supported through a variety of funding sources, including, but not limited to, special events, an annual giving campaign, and in-kind donations. All funds raised through this campaign will go directly to the outlined presentation, as well as to the continuation of Spark's mission.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! Let them know that you donated on Facebook, Twitter, and/or email.

Like the performance it supports, this campaign is divided into two phases. The first phase is allocated to the performance space, while the second phase will contribute to various production costs. We have achieved our first phase and are now working towards our second phase!


What We Need & What You Get
Spark is supported through a variety of funding sources, including, but not limited to, special events, an annual giving campaign, and in-kind donations. All funds raised through this campaign will go directly to the outlined presentation, as well as to the continuation of Spark's mission.


Other Ways You Can Help
Tell your friends! Let them know that you donated on Facebook, Twitter, and/or email.

story:
Well hello there!

We, at Another Theatre Company, need your help to get our double bill of Chekhov's THE BEAR/ LADY WITH A LAP DOG up and running for the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival. We're a group of young, emerging artists from Toronto, Montreal, Windsor, Peterborough, Stratford and Manitoulin Island who have come together to create a contemporary staging of these great Russian classics. The translations are new and fresh, done by our very own Lisa Hamalainen. By utilizing the exciting elements of live improvisational music and the magic of theatre, we highlight and evoke the romantic substance and poetic quality of Chekhov's original texts from the late 1890's.

Another Theatre Company was founded in 2011 by Ellen Hurley, Warren Bain and Michael Iliadis.  Our mandate is simple - we put on plays we like.â€¨  With that as our guide, we navigate the wild waters of the independent theatre world.

As we are all young, emerging artists we need your support to make this show happen. Donations will allow us to fulfill the creative vision through costuming, set, props and to help us build a puppet. Your support will allow us to have all of these things that transform the space and take the audience into the worlds of these wonderful stories.

Help us to tell these beautiful stories and please join us at the Toronto Fringe Festival from July 6th-15th!

Our warmest thanks!

Sincerely,

Another Theatre Co.

story:
Welcome to the Fear Myself campaign page!!

 

We will be performing 'Fear Myself', our devised performance based upon Shakespeare's 'Richard III'. The performances will take place between the 2nd and 4th August 2012 at St. Andrew Church Crypt in Central London.

 

What is 'Fear Myself'?

'Fear Myself' is a surrealist nightmare that takes it's audience deep into the mind of Shakespeare's greatest villain. In the crypt of St. Andrew Church, Pandemonium Performance will take you to a place where morality and redemption are forgotten amongst the dead and the decieved. 

Who We Are

Pandemonium Performance formed in London in 2010. Initially made up of students from Middlesex University and Havering College. The company’s first performance was the devised piece ‘Nocebo’ which premiered in August 2010 at the Meeting of Minds festival in Slovenia.The company seek to create a vast and diverse output that will be acknowledged worldwide and have already performed across Europe and beyond, including performances in Russia, Lithuania and France. Members of Pandemonium Performance all have wide and diverse interests and goals that they wish to achieve through the company. They believe that working together they can create performance that deeply effects not only the audiences they perform to, but themselves also. The company create diverse, challenging work that demands to be seen. Their output is formed from new writing, devised work and the deconstruction and rebuilding of classic texts to breath into them new life and new ideas. Constantly evolving and provoking audiences, Pandemonium Performance are on their way to becoming a bold new name both in the United Kingdom and beyond.

As a company we recieve no form of funding and your generous contributions will enable us to secure funds in the future and to create a show which will break boundaries and help us to establish our artistic vision. 

What Are Our Costs

Our costs currently stand as follows:

Venue- £1520

Advertising- £293

Costume- £270

Make Up- £150

Rehearsal Space- £650.50

Travel expenses for staff- £76.50

Website maintenance- £40

Why Should People Contribute

We are living in a society where both financially and artistically people are struggling to get their voices heard. Pandemonium Performance believe that the arts are a way of bringing people together through expression and with your help we can bring our performances to people without compromise.

Spread The Word

As well as helping our funding people can make a real difference through word of mouth and spending some time telling pople about us and what we are striving to achieve. We would greatly appreicate people directing others to our website and also our Twitter and Facebook pages. We're a friendly bunch and would love to hear from you about our shows, or even if you are interested in any of our themes or ideas.

Please visit our website for more information about us and previous show details:

http://www.pandemoniumperformance.co.uk

 

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!!

 

PLEASE NOTE (in regards to Perks): Postage outside of the UK will be subject to extra charges. We will aim to supply you with a ticket to the performance of your choice, however if demand is great you may have to be allocated an alternative performance time.

story:
OUR STORY:

DELIRIUM began back in the fall of 2012 when I was in my freshman year of college. Then, I was at a university where I was learning a lot, but wasn't fully happy. There was one point around October when a depression took me and I had to release all of the inner emotions that hindered my life, so I decided to write out one simple scene just to clear my head. After it was done, a friend of mine read it and highly recommended that I continue with it. And within a couple months the first draft of the script was written. So I rattled up some friends, and after a long period of editing and rehearsals,  we put on a terrific show that the audience loved so much that they spread the word and others begged for more performances.

I have a deeply personal connection to the story being told that I feel is a prime reason as to why I ended up where I am today; why I am now succeeding as becoming the artist I enjoy waking up every morning to. Life is great! And I owe it to the people who helped bring it to life and to the show itself a great production.

And now after transferring to Columbia College Chicago, I've brought this new, revised version of the show forth to a terrifically talented production team and cast of my fellow classmates that were immediately drawn to it. We had decided to take the show outside our school to allow ourselves more freedom to do what we wanted with it. The passion and ambition for this production is evident when you see us. It's an exciting thing that we are taking this original story to the Chicago public, and we're confident that DELIRIUM will blow people's minds and give them something they'll never forget.


SYNOPSIS:

When Jennifer Mullins is given the chance to prove that she can be the reporter she’s dreamt of becoming, the New York Times sends her to interview a severely disturbed little girl in an asylum who supposedly murdered her entire family in one night. As Jen uncovers the secrets of this child’s past leading up to the murders, she unknowingly plummets into the impeccably disturbing, psychological nightmare of her own mind. This breathtaking thriller takes you into the depths of your darkest imaginations with suspense, horror, and an emotionally absorbing story that will leave you speechless.


PERFORMANCES:

The Den Theatre, Studio 2A--2nd Floor, 1333 N Milwaukee Ave, Chicago, IL 60622


Friday, August 29th at 7:30 pm
Saturday, August 30th at 7:30 pm
Sunday, August 31st at 6:00 pm
Friday, September 5th at 7:30 pm
Saturday, September 6th at 7:30 pm
Sunday, September 7th at 3:00 pm

Tickets available online August 1st


ENSEMBLE:

Director and Writer--Jacob Huddilston

Co Director--Jacqueline Wills

Stage Manager--Makena Metz

Technical Specialist--Alex Avery

Lighting Designer--Pauli Dandino

Costume/Makeup Designer--Tracee Bear


Jennifer Mullins--Julia Henning

Molly O'Brien--Mary Lumley

Dr. Josef Jovovich--Jeffrey Entwistle

Pepper Warner--Catherine LaRocca

Sister Marah--Kris Tori

Kimberly O'Brien--Hana Rickert

Det. Tony Dunn--Kiefer Otto

Lillian O'Brien--Al Vaughn

Paul O'Brien--Ethan Mole

John Porter--Patrick Deal

Peter Mullins--Ulises Pico

Debbie--Zoë Sapienza


SO WHERE DO THE FUNDS GO?

  • Paying for our rehearsal and performance space
  • Costumes and makeup
  • Set construction
  • Any extra technical requirements needed

story:
Lucky Lamour Presents!
            Folies Pastiche: Un Cabaret Extraordinaire! is a dazzling new show full of the captivating glamour of vaudeville and the electrifying ideas of today.
            This cast of exquisite, strong, and sexy women light up the stage with dancing, theatre, and a few fun tricks up their thigh highs. From the art of burlesque, to perfect comedic timing, and just the right shimmy n' shake, these women have a voracious appetite for entertaining.
            Come get lost in a melange of colorful and alluring feats. A show of varieties that's not to be missed!
                                                            Vivre La Danse!

                                      -----------------------------------------------------

The Story:
      My name is Jessica LeCheminant, but everyone calls me Jess, and the stage has often called me Lucky Lamour. I find the stage to be a home to me and the audience to be a part of my story. I am a dancer...I am a performer, creator, and  lover of all things theatrical. I have trained since the age of 3 in various forms of dance and theater and fell in love with it. Amazingly, I still fall in love with a new form every time I try it. I have trained in some of the nations top dance studios, with some even more incredible instructors. My background in dance ranges from teaching ballet to 5 year old children, bellydancing for royalty, combining contemporary and theater in whimsical settings, and performing burlesque to sold out houses.

     This campaign takes my life of training and performing, and gives it a home. It is a combination of everything I love about dance and theater. LUCKY LAMOUR PRESENTS! will be a touring show bringing the beautiful combinations of bellydance and burlesque, jazz, comical skits, hip hop, and maybe even a circus act or two, if you're lucky. The first round of tours will bring you 'Folies Pastiche: Un Cabaret Extraordinaire!'. LUCKY LAMOUR PRESENTS! is a home to showcase amazingly talented professionals, who I am lucky enough to call my dear friends. And 'Folies Pastiche: Un Cabaret Extraordinaire!' is an opportunity for us to entertain like only we know how. This production is a monumental opportunity to bring all of me to the stage, as well as the hearts of each performer.

     Every single penny that is contributed to this campaign is a penny expressing your belief in me, advocacy for art, and love of a good time. Each contribution is more than just one or one hundred dollars. It is a set and prop that brings life to the stage, a costume that ignites the imagination, and a home where anyone and everyone can come get lost in the pure art of entertainment.

    

What We Need & What You Get

     Because it is the performers job to put on a great show against any and all odds, many don't realize the cost it takes to not just put on a show, but a PRODUCTION.

     'Folies Pastiche: Un Cabaret extraordinaire!' has the goal of raising $10,000.
                 Where is all that dough headed you ask? Here's the breakdown...

--Costuming:
           Rhinestones, beads, and fringe, OH MY! Proper costuming for a show
           that keeps you on your toes (and the dancers in their sequins) is an
           incredibly large part of what takes a production from drab to fab.
           It is important to have perfectly fitting, well built costumes that stand
           the test of time and bring a huge bang for your buck! Everything from
           custom made pieces, to homemade embellishments, and specially
           ordered morsels all fall under this parasol.

--PR/Mareketing:
          We do it for the audience. Without people in the seats, we may as well
           just keep dancing in front of our bathroom mirrors. The energy and
           love of a house full of supporters is beyond essential to a live show.
           May I repeat, YOU are beyond essential to a live show. The need for
           a website, flyers, cards, online presence, publications, and every
           other form of marketing we've got up our sleeves to get people in
           those seats, is part of where your contribution is going.

--Production:
           There are sets and props to be built, a crew to run the show, venues to rent,
           and that's just the beginning!! It's quite the production putting on a
           production. We've got to cross every t, and dot every i. Your
           contribution helps in that preparedness.
    
*** In the "perks" section, we have formulated some very special ways to send a big THANK YOU your way for contributing to this dream. You will find some items that will eventually become "merch" at our shows, which means, you are getting it before ANYONE else! You will also find some other thank you's that have been specially tailored just for you. ***

The Impact

     LUCKY LAMOUR PRESENTS! is valuable to you and your contribution because you are supporting  the arts. You are helping to bring joy, thrill, intrigue, laughter, and pure entertainment to EVERYONE! The art of dance and theater- the way it used to be- is a dying form, and one that everyone should get to experience once in their life. A live show full of beautiful and talented dancers, riddled with the theatrics of the days of vaudeville and cabaret. This show/your contribution will lift hearts and bring smiles to all who partake. And that's not the only impact you are making...

          GIVING BACK!
                      LUCKY LAMOUR PRESENTS! is more than just a knock your socks off
        live show full of dancing, laughs and beautiful women. We are about putting
        the good, great, and fantastic that we've received right back out there. As
        we "speak", paperwork is being filled out and processed, phone calls are
        being made, and plans are moving forward to create what will be known as,
                                          ~THE LAMOUR FOUNDATION~
                        This is an organization that believes in sharing the wealth and
        spreading the love. Your contribution is putting together a show that will donate
        a portion of the proceeds from EVERY SINGLE PERFORMANCE to The Lamour
        Foundation. And The Lamour Foundation?... Well, it will be helping charities
        from all walks, holding events to raise awareness for these charities, and     
        bringing people together. Your contribution is your good deed for the day in
        more ways than one! GO YOU!!!
     ----------------------

Other Ways You Can Help

   Unable to contribute monetarily? That's okay, there are lots of ways to contribute! You can share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, through email, and even word of mouth! Contributing is about creating a community and helping it thrive. The more people that know about this project, the more we can help this campaign succeed.

   Indiegogo has made it really easy to spread the good word. Just use their share tools and there you have it!

story:
The Joy of Dancing!

Hello,

Thank you for visiting our page and reading about us!

We are dedicated to providing and influencing our children with art through ballet dancing. We need your help and support.

Our students range in age from 4 to 11 years old.

We believe that providing ballet to our children is essential for the development of their character, personality, manners, grace, discipline, charm, poise, musicality, elegance and performance skills.

My name is Juneta Ozolina. I was born in the city of Riga, capital of a small country, Latvia, in Europe.

I've been a professional ballet dancer since age 5. I graduated from the prestigious Riga Academy of Ballet, from where the most famous ballet dancers have graduated as well: Mikhail Baryshnikov, Alexander Godunov, John Markovsky, and Maris Liepa, to name a few.

I had professionally performed for over 25 years the world's famous and prestigious Giselle, The Nutcracker, Kosar, Don Quixote and Swan Lake; in Sweden, Norway, Italy, Germany, USA, Latvia, Russia, Denmark and Israel.

We opened the first ballet school for children in our community 1+ year ago. Since then, we were able to develop our ballerinas in such way, that we had our first production last June of 2012, called "Voices of Spring", which you can watch in 4 different videos, in our official channel in youtube.com. We trained these beautiful children from scratch to stage, in 6 months only. Please visit our links below.

As we grew into teaching in 2 elementary schools, both school stages are too small for this perfomance. Our dream is to perform our production on a larger professional stage.

Now, I'm ready to lead these ballerinas to a higher level of ballet performance: Swan Lake; and at a professional large theater stage.

Your support will impact all these little ballerinas that dedicate their time and their love to dancing ballet. It will be one of the most remarkable memories in their lifetime.

Our production is set for April 11th 2013, at the Pepperdine University in Malibu, and it's FREE ENTRANCE event for everyone.

We want to set a remarkable milestone and create beautiful memories; and I need your help.

We will be very thankful to you, forever!

About SWAN LAKE

Swan Lake (Russian: Лебединое озеро, Lebedinoye ozero) ballet, Op. 20, by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, was composed in 1875–1876. The scenario, initially in four acts, was fashioned from Russian folk tales[1] and tells the story of Odette, a princess turned into a swan by an evil sorcerer's curse. The choreographer of the original production was Julius Reisinger. The ballet was premiered by the Bolshoi Ballet on 4 March [O.S. 20 February] 1877[2][3] at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow, billed as The Lake of the Swans.

For more history, visit the link below:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swan_Lake

Expenses budgeted for our production:

* Theater rental

* Theater crew: Lights, Sound, stage, reception.

* Videographer

* Photographer

* Editor

* Costumes

* Craft Services

* Equipment

* Insurance

Your contribution makes a positive impact in the influence of art for our children and their generation.

THANK YOU!

Juneta Ozolina

story_txt:
The Joy of Dancing!
Hello,
Thank you for visiting our page and reading about us!
We are dedicated to providing and influencing our children with art through ballet dancing. We need your help and support.
Our students range in age from 4 to 11 years old.
We believe that providing ballet to our children is essential for the development of their character, personality, manners, grace, discipline, charm, poise, musicality, elegance and performance skills.
My name is Juneta Ozolina. I was born in the city of Riga, capital of a small country, Latvia, in Europe.
I've been a professional ballet dancer since age 5. I graduated from the prestigious Riga Academy of Ballet, from where the most famous ballet dancers have graduated as well: Mikhail Baryshnikov, Alexander Godunov, John Markovsky, and Maris Liepa, to name a few.
I had professionally performed for over 25 years the world's famous and prestigious Giselle, The Nutcracker, Kosar, Don Quixote and Swan Lake; in Sweden, Norway, Italy, Germany, USA, Latvia, Russia, Denmark and Israel.
We opened the first ballet school for children in our community 1+ year ago. Since then, we were able to develop our ballerinas in such way, that we had our first production last June of 2012, called "Voices of Spring", which you can watch in 4 different videos, in our official channel in youtube.com. We trained these beautiful children from scratch to stage, in 6 months only. Please visit our links below.
As we grew into teaching in 2 elementary schools, both school stages are too small for this perfomance. Our dream is to perform our production on a larger professional stage.
Now, I'm ready to lead these ballerinas to a higher level of ballet performance: Swan Lake; and at a professional large theater stage.
Your support will impact all these little ballerinas that dedicate their time and their love to dancing ballet. It will be one of the most remarkable memories in their lifetime.
Our production is set for April 11th 2013, at the Pepperdine University in Malibu, and it's FREE ENTRANCE event for everyone.
We want to set a remarkable milestone and create beautiful memories; and I need your help.
We will be very thankful to you, forever!
About SWAN LAKE
Swan Lake (Russian: Лебединое озеро, Lebedinoye ozero) ballet, Op. 20, by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, was composed in 1875–1876. The scenario, initially in four acts, was fashioned from Russian folk tales[1] and tells the story of Odette, a princess turned into a swan by an evil sorcerer's curse. The choreographer of the original production was Julius Reisinger. The ballet was premiered by the Bolshoi Ballet on 4 March [O.S. 20 February] 1877[2][3] at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow, billed as The Lake of the Swans.
For more history, visit the link below:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swan_Lake
Expenses budgeted for our production:
* Theater rental
* Theater crew: Lights, Sound, stage, reception.
* Videographer
* Photographer
* Editor
* Costumes

* Equipment
* Insurance
Your contribution makes a positive impact in the influence of art for our children and their generation.

Juneta Ozolina

story:
****Update from the producers:**** 


To everyone who has supported us thus far,

We are so grateful that with the support of our incredibly generous donors, we were able to meet our online fundraising goal already. Thank you so very much! However, our overall fundraising goal has not been met yet, and anything you are willing to give would be deeply appreciated. Again, we are so appreciative of the support we've already received and we cannot wait to open the show this weekend. Thank you!

Best,
Jacob and Lucy


About JEWISH THEATRE ENSEMBLE:

The Jewish Theatre Ensemble (JTE) was founded in 1995 by a group of five students who were intent on expanding the university's student-theatre community by producing plays and musicals involving Jewish themes. Since its first season, JTE has presented over fifty of these productions to students at Northwestern as well as members of the Evanston community. In addition to producing work by established playwrights, JTE is committed to the creation and development of new plays and in the past has sponsored a playwriting festival for aspiring writers at Northwestern. And you do not need to be Jewish to be involved! The Jewish Theatre Ensemble exists to provide the Northwestern community with high quality entertainment and exposure to Jewish involvement in the arts. The organization aspires to challenge common perceptions and generate conversation relating to issues that fall within the resonance of the Jewish experience through artistic media with particular relevance to the Northwestern community. JTE will be involved in the celebration and education of Jewish culture on campus. In order to do this, The Jewish Theatre Ensemble will operate at a level of artistic excellence as well as encourage and support creative endeavors that promote Jewish themes in the arts.

The Show:

NEXT TO NORMAL is a poignant show about a family shattered by loss. The musical is grounded in the Goodman family household -  which from the outside would appear to be your everyday suburban home. However, the Goodmans have been touched by tragedy and are working each day to hold it all together, despite how painful it may be to do so. NEXT TO NORMAL explores the gritty parts of life; highlights how individuals cope with issues such as death, grief, and mental illness; and illustrates the power and shortcomings of modern-day relationships. 

The Help We Need:

Because the Executive Board, Production Team, Cast, and Crew are made up entirely of Northwestern undergraduate students, our resources are limited. Any amount you are willing to contribute would truly make an impact on our ability to afford to produce a spectacular show.

Your donation will help tremendously in a variety of ways:

  • Purchasing lumber, paint, and scenery to construct our set.
  • Renting sound and lighting equipment for the productions.
  • Obtaining fabric and accessories to be used as costumes.
  • Collecting props from thrift shops and rental stores.
  • Paying for the rights to perform the show.
  • Assisting our publicity campaigns as well as marketing in and around the Northwestern and Chicago area.
  • The possibilities are endless!


The People Involved:

Cast

  • Diana: Laura Winters
  • Dan: Ben Barker
  • Gabe: Kyle Sherman
  • Natalie: Jessie Klueter
  • Henry: Aaron Simon Gross
  • Dr. Madden: Max Rein

Band

  • Piano/ Conductor: Michael Kaish
  • Guitar: Conor Keelan
  • Violin: Lena Vidulich
  • Keyboard: Casey Reed
  • Bass: Isabel McPherson
  • Drums: Thomas Fagan
  • Cello: Geirþrúður Guðmundsdóttir

Executive Team

  • Producers: Lucy Ahlborn & Jacob Trauberman
  • Director: Brendan Flynn
    • Assistant Directors: Justine Gelfman, Dan Leahy
  • Stage Manager: Sam Garrott
    • Assistant Stage Managers: Lindsay Maron, Sarah Anderson
  • Music Director: Michael Kaish
  • Choreographer: Zoe Nadal

Artistic Team

  • Artistic Producer: Lucy Ahlborn
    • Assistant Artistic Producer: Maddie Ambrose
  • Set Designer: Ford Altenbern
  • Lighting Designer: Megan Wines
  • Sound Designers: Conor Keelan & Josh Light
  • Costume Designer: Hilary Flynn
    • Assistant Costume Designer: Brooke Weisman
  • Props Designer: Bit Meehan
    • Assistant Props Designer: Maddy Kelly
  • Technical Directors: Alex Shaffer, Brad Hardmeyer
  • Dramaturg: Daniel Chenard

Business Team

  • Business Producer: Jacob Trauberman
    • Assistant Business Producer: Rebecca Elowe
  • Publicity Director: Emily Fishkin
    • Publicity Team: Katie Incardona, Hale McSharry, Drew Guerra, Olivia Probetts
  • Digital Media Director: Catherine Reid
  • Fundraising Director, Outreach: Sam Freedman
    • Assistant Fundraising Director: Isaac Sims
  • Fundraising Director, Local: Daniel Bender Stern
  • Graphic Designer: Juli Del Prete
  • Photographer: Justin Barbin
  • Promotional Videographer: Nate Bartlett

JEWISH THEATRE ENSEMBLE EXECUTIVE BOARD:

  • Artistic Director: Gavi Keyles
  • Business Manager: Jacob Trauberman
  • Production Supervisor: Maddy Low
  • Development Director: Maddie Kriger
  • Development Director: Lily Goldstein
  • Technical Director: Jack Eidson
  • Technical Director: Brandon Nadig
  • Special Projects: Aaron Simon Gross
  • Special Projects: Russell Kahn
  • Publicity Director: Bridget McNamara
  • Publicity Director: Emily Fishkin
  • Directing Chair: Dylan Pager
  • Stage Management Chair: Sean Buckley
  • Freshman Board Representative: Julie Busch
  • Freshman Board Representative: Weston Jacoby


    • Thank you so much for your generous support. We truly appreciate it!

    Sincerely,
    Jacob Trauberman and Lucy Ahlborn,
    Co-Producers

    nexttonormalnu@gmail.com

story:
Hi!  My name is Eli Skelton and I love to dance.  I am also gymnast, wrestler and a straight “A” student.   My parents took me to see “ Singin’ in the Rain” when I was six years old and I knew right then that I was born to dance.  I’m seventeen years old now, and it’s time for me to take the next step and go to a professional development program.  I’ve been accepted into the Summer Intensive Dance Program with the Texas Ballet Theater, but the program is expensive. The program runs from June 17- July 19 with a performance at the end.  I have a part time job and I’ve been saving up money to go but will still need help.

The program will cost $4275 which covers the classes, housing and food. Donations of any amount  are welcome and much appreciated!  All donors will receive an email expressing my appreciation with an attached photograph taken during the program.  Donations fifty dollars or more will receive a personal letter of thanks with a photograph  and a description of what  I’ve learned at the program.

My experiences in dance so far have taught me that the Arts are our best hope for bringing people together.  I have met dancers from all over the world, and no matter how different our backgrounds have been, we are all united in the love of ballet.  I believe that this makes a popular support for the Arts of key importance to the creation of a healthy world community.  And…I love to dance!

If you’d care to contribute to my campaign, even if all you can do is pass my request on to friends and family, you’ll have my gratitude.  If you choose to pass my campaign information along, be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools attached to this site!  Thank you for taking the time to read about my campaign!

story:
Hi! I'm Rik Deskin, an Actor/Comedian and the Artistic Director of Eclectic Theater Company (ETC). That's me above hosting one of our weekly shows, The Comedy Workshop. ETC is the Resident Company at Odd Duck Studio, a 49-seat black-box theater located right on the border of First Hill and Capitol Hill in Seattle. As Artistic Director, I've curated nearly 6 years of Classic, Contemporary, Original work for the Stage and Screen in the form of Plays, Improv, Stand-Up & Sketch Comedy as well as Play Readings and Screenplay Readings of new work in development and location and general production support for independent films. I want to continue to bring innovative, interesting programming to Seattle audiences and need sustained support for operational costs such as rent, utilities and insurance.

 

The Impact

Continuing a sustainable operation provides an affordable theater to itinerant Theatre Artists and Groups that might have a difficult time finding an accessible space for their projects. Some of our programming is free for audience members that might not be able to attend a show due to their own economic situation. If we don't succeed in raising the needed funds to continue, then Seattle might lose a theater venue that has a rich history dating back to 1997, where new, alternative work is created amidst many adaptations of classic and contemporary works. No other venue in Seattle generates the amount of original work year-round that we curate.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5050 that will go directly to paying our rent, and enabling us a little cushion as we generate box office and rental revenue from pending projects. For helping us, we have perks that range from show tickets to being able to produce your own show. For every dollar you contribute, you will get value that equals and surpasses your support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please join me by sharing this campaign with people you know can help. Even if you can't contribute, sharing with others and spreading the word will help!

story:
In the midst of the holiday season a little levity may be in order.  On the Winter Solstice, come join us as we present our version of Dickens' 'A Christmas Carol' a rock spoof on our favorite holiday show.  This is our annual fundraiser and our way of saying thanks to our patrons - plus it's an excuse to have Dolly Parton, Bob Marley and Elvis play the ghosts! Join us at on 12/21/13 at 7pm at Evviva Bar & Eatery - 1017 Front Street Lisle, IL 60532, tickets are $30 or a table of 4 for $100 including complimentary beer and wine. 

Who is Theatre-Hikes?

We began in Chicago Almost 15 years ago combining our love of theater and nature as we perform live shows while hiking in great locations like Grant Park, Millenium Park, Pulman State Historic Site, University of Chicago (Rockefeller Chapel) to name a few.  We've grown to include Theatre-Hikes Colorado and Theatre-Hikes Los Angeles (slated to begin productions in 2014).

story:
Who We Are

Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre, produces female centered theatre that challenges the perception of women. At Artemisia, we pursue our mission to equalize the playing field for women both onstage and off, effectively mirroring the strides that women have made around the globe as leaders, innovators and entrepreneurs, and we bring to mainstream attention the social ills that continue to undermine women’s equality and autonomy. Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre, is a 501(c)3 Not-for-Profit organization. Your donation is tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

At Artemisia, female centered means that the play’s leading character is a woman and it is through her experience that the story unfolds, and through her reversals, changes and discoveries that the play reaches its catharsis.

Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre, is named for Artemisia Gentileschi. Though Artemisia Gentileschi was a woman painting in the 17th century, for three-hundred years she was remembered mostly for being raped and participating in the successful prosecution of the rapist, an event that long overshadowed her great achievements as an artist. It is in Artemisia’s name that we strive to make great theatre and shake the world up a bit while doing it.

Why We're Fundraising

Our 2013 Season includes our Fall Festival of Six Staged Readings that are presented free to the public. September's Fall Festival Audience will choose its favorite and that's the play that will be produced in 2014.

The plays are produced under the Actors' Equity Staged Reading Code and all Equity Actors and the Writers, Directors and Crew are paid. Your generous contribution will help with the costs of rehearsal space, lighting and sound equipment, marketing, venue rental and the talents' salaries.

Your contribution will also help us mount the World Premiere of Gambit, by Ross Tedford Kendall, which was chosen for production by last year's Fall Festival Audience.

To thank you for your support, we've come up with some fun perks. No pledge is too small! Perks include Artemisia's Salute of the Extraordinary Woman in Your Life, virtual hugs, high-fives and photo opportunities. And if you're in Chicago, come to the shows and we'll thank you personally for helping us tell her story.


Ross Tedford Kendall's smart and uncompromising examination of the relationship between an ambitious US Attorney and her violently rebellious niece won the audience vote at Artemisia's 2012 Fall Festival of Staged Readings. This World Premiere will open for an exclusive, limited run in November 2013 In Chicago. Julie Proudfoot will direct Suzanne Petri and Miriam Reuter in this entertaining, insightful two-hander that challenges the perception of women. Gambit opens November 8, 2013, at Signal Ensemble Theatre in Chicago and will run through November 24, 2013.

    Our Impact

    Artemisia is deeply committed to a vital, daring and risk-taking contemporary theatre. The new works selected each year from open submissions and staged as readings during our Fall Festival reflect our commitment to find new voices that effectively mirror the “here and now.” Artemisia’s aesthetic is that great stories are not bound by political correctness or a conformist sense of morality, but rather are defined by their ability to raise existential questions that can inspire audience members to experience a new awareness of themselves and their contemporary culture.

    Artemisia was incorporated in April of 2011. Eleven staged readings and one full production later, we continue to seek out plays that are driven by and focused on women. Artemisia maintains an open, no-fee play submission policy and submissions have increased a hundred-fold since we first began. Consistent with the mission, women hold 90% of our creative and executive positions.

    Each year, we select six plays that reflect Artemisia’s mission from open submissions. These plays are staged as readings for a public audience. We invite artistic leaders in Chicago Theatre to act as moderators to guide the audience discussion after every performance. A vote is taken and our audience chooses the play we fully produce the following year. Artemisia’s annual Fall Festival is offered free to the public and all of the donations received go directly  to fund production.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you're unable to contribute, you can still help tell her story:

    • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools to post on Twitter, Facebook and send emails.

    The Artemisia 2013 Actors, Writers and Directors

    Thank you kindly for your generous support of Artemisia and Female Centered Theatre. You Rock!

    For Reservations or for More Information www.artemisiatheatre.org
