Perks include Artemisia's Salute of the Extraordinary Woman in Your Life, virtual hugs, high-fives and photo opportunities. And if you're in Chicago, come to the shows and we'll thank you personally for helping us tell her story.


Ross Tedford Kendall's smart and uncompromising examination of the relationship between an ambitious US Attorney and her violently rebellious niece won the audience vote at Artemisia's 2012 Fall Festival of Staged Readings. This World Premiere will open for an exclusive, limited run in November 2013 In Chicago. Julie Proudfoot will direct Suzanne Petri and Miriam Reuter in this entertaining, insightful two-hander that challenges the perception of women. Gambit opens November 8, 2013, at Signal Ensemble Theatre in Chicago and will run through November 24, 2013.



Our Impact
Artemisia is deeply committed to a vital, daring and risk-taking contemporary theatre. The new works selected each year from open submissions and staged as readings during our Fall Festival reflect our commitment to find new voices that effectively mirror the “here and now.” Artemisia’s aesthetic is that great stories are not bound by political correctness or a conformist sense of morality, but rather are defined by their ability to raise existential questions that can inspire audience members to experience a new awareness of themselves and their contemporary culture.
Artemisia was incorporated in April of 2011. Eleven staged readings and one full production later, we continue to seek out plays that are driven by and focused on women. Artemisia maintains an open, no-fee play submission policy and submissions have increased a hundred-fold since we first began. Consistent with the mission, women hold 90% of our creative and executive positions.Each year, we select six plays that reflect Artemisia’s mission from open submissions. These plays are staged as readings for a public audience. We invite artistic leaders in Chicago Theatre to act as moderators to guide the audience discussion after every performance. A vote is taken and our audience chooses the play we fully produce the following year. Artemisia’s annual Fall Festival is offered free to the public and all of the donations received go directly  to fund production.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you're unable to contribute, you can still help tell her story:

Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools to post on Twitter, Facebook and send emails.
The Artemisia 2013 Actors, Writers and Directors


Thank you kindly for your generous support of Artemisia and Female Centered Theatre. You Rock!
For Reservations or for More Information www.artemisiatheatre.org

story:
About God of Carnage:

When four parents get together to discuss their sons' playground scuffle, they intend to be reasonable, brief, and, above all, civilized. But as their conversation barrels along, their facades unravel until the line between child and adult has been completely erased. In a story full of hamster-murders, medicinal recalls, vomit, cellphones, African art, and dessert pizzas, will civilized discourse prevail? Or are we all just slaves to the God of Carnage?

How your support will be utilized:

Student theatre at Northwestern is completely funded by outside donations from generous supporters, like yourselves. Your contributions will help us:

  • Purchase lumber, paint, and other supplies to construct a set.
  • Rent lights
  • Buy clothing for costumes
  • Buy necessary props for the show
  • Create publicity materials such as posters, videos, and banners. 
Who is starring in God of Carnage:

  • Brandon Powers will be playing Michael
  • Lucy Ahlborn will be playing Veronica
  • Josh Kohane will be playing Alan
  • Laura Winters will be playing Annette
The fearless leaders:

Every show requires a talented and dedicated production team ranging from designers, to fundraisers, to general moral support. Each team and cast is led by a Director and a Producer. Our Director, Meghan Stanton, and Producer, Jack Eidson, will guide this team and cast through a wonderful and challenging journey that will allow us to create a memorable experience for the team and audience. Jack and Meghan will be supported by the Jewish Theatre Ensemble at Northwestern University who will help guide and support them through this process.

story:
WE ARE GOING TO AACT FEST 2013!

Dakota Fine Arts Consortium's production of Ken Ludwig's Leading Ladies has been chosen as one of the 12 best plays across the United States! We are honored to be representing Region V at the American Association of Community Theatre's National Festival! This is DFAC's first trip to National's and we could not be more thrilled, BUT...

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

DFAC is itself a homeless theater, a volunteer organization with a small membership, and a limited budget. We continue to use rented, borrowed or donated space for performances, rehearsals, storage, and construction.

Our Fundraising will cover:

  • Transportation and Gas. (We need to get 8 actors, 7 crew members, a large box set, around 50 costumes, and 7 wigs, to Carmel, IN, which is about 1,200 miles round trip!)
  • Hotel rooms for our cast and crew for 6 nights.
  • Festival Registration for cast and crew.

A few things to remember:

We are a cast and crew of volunteers, all of the money we are looking to raise is going towards expenses for this show.

and

DFAC is a non-profit theatre organization, so all payments go through FirstGiving, who will send you a tax-deductible receipt for your contribution! 

one more thing...

We actually need to raise $7,200 for all of the expenses, but decided to start out with a more reasonable $5,000. So don't worry, if we are able to exceed our $5,000 goal, anything over that will still be going towards the festival expenses!

 

You can also help support us by attending one of our local performances before we head to Indiana!

Friday, June 14, 2013 @ 7:30pm

and

Saturday June 15, 2013 @ 3:00pm

 

Shakopee Senior High School, 100 17th Ave, Shakopee MN

All seats are $10 per person

 

Thank you for any help you can provide!

******** 

ABOUT LEADING LADIES

Cast:

Meg: Donna Heaston

 

Leo: Scott Swanson

Jack: John Flannagan

Audrey: Willow Bousu

Duncan: Michael Lambert

Florence: Stephanie Weiss


Doc: Pat Hammond

Butch: Shawn Rowan

 
Crew:

Director: Mary Beth King

Lights: Carla Shutrop

Sound: John Seipp

Dressers and Crew: Richard Silverman-King, Mark Steffer, David Poeschel, Janelle Swanson

Set Design: Janet Steinberg, Robin McIntyre

Costumes: Mary Beth King, Linda Straub

Properties: Mark Steffer

Administration: William P. Muchow

 

The Show:

Set in 1958, two unemployed actors Leo and Jack are stuck playing Shakespeare on the Moose Lodge circuit in the Amish country of Pennsylvania. They hear of a wealthy widow from York, Pennsylvania who has died before finding her long-lost heirs, Max and Steve. To improve their cash flow and run back to civilization, they decide to impersonate the nephews and claim the inheritance. But nothing in York is as they expect, resulting in chaos and laughter!

 

Fun Facts:

* Leading Ladies is a full two act play shortened to 55 minutes

* Out of 10 shows, Leading Ladies was chosen as one of two best Minnesota plays at the 2013 Minnesota Association of Community Theatre's Festival.

* Leading Ladies was chosen as Best Play at the Region V AACT Festival (MN, ND, SD, KS, IA, NB, KS)

*After being advised that Leading Ladies was on Samuel French's “no cut” listing, we sent Ken Ludwig a personal note requesting permission to edit his show down to 55 minutes. Happily, he said yes! His participation in the AACT Recognition program “Act Locally, AACT Nationally” was helpful in obtaining his permission to cut the show down. To our knowledge, we are the first Minnesota community theater to be given this permission. Rumor has it, Ken Ludwig may be attending the AACT Festival. And if he does we will be Waiting for (Mr.) Ludwig.
*DFAC has been competing at the state, regional and national level for 8 years, entered 5 productions in festivals, and won a total of 20 individual and ensemble awards.

story:
The Winter's Tale 

     Anon it Moves is delighted to introduce our upcoming Production of The Winter's Tale, a story of the hard-edged kingdom of Sicilia and the freewheeling circus of Bohemia. This play is especially dear to our hearts because 'Anon It Moves' is taken from a line in the final scene. These words are spoken in anticipation of a moment of theater so alarming it takes an unspeakable tragedy, an improbable comedy and sixteen years before the royal audience onstage is ready for it. We, too, have been waiting since our company's inception for the right time to tell this story--of jealousy and regret, of magic and renewal--and we are so excited to share it with you! 

      The Winter's Tale is our most ambitious undertaking to date, and we need your help to fund the show's most exciting elements:

  • The Music! Devan Wardrop-Saxton has composed and curated almost 20 songs and tunes which are played live on stage by the ensemble. Funds raised will go to the extra rehearsal space for musicians and the cost of a professional recording. 
  • The Circus! In true Anon it Moves fashion, we are collaborating with another local arts organization to help bring the world of Bohemia to life. This production features performances by The Circus Project Training Company. Funds will go towards safety equipment and gear, as well as a coach on site at each performance.
  • The Costumes! All of the costumes will be hand made by company member Ginnie Loomis. Funds will go towards the cost of fabric and the time spent by Ginnie and her crew to design and build each individual costume piece to the specifications of each actor's body and each character's needs.
  • The Lights! We will be the fourth show in the new Shaking The Tree space, a brand new venue in town that is not yet fully equipped for high power lighting fixtures. Funds will go towards the rental of LEDs and dimmers. 

The show is already well underway but your contribution will pay for our the work and time of the many (many) artists and performers in our ensemble and team. It will also allow us increase our production value with confidence as we move into our season's second show, Cymbeline, which runs July 17th through August 8th. 

Budget

    This production builds the two distinct cultures of Bohemia and Sicilia against one another, while maintaining their place in the same world. Your donations will allow us to create a depth to these cultures. 

The total cost of these additional elements is $6000. Below you can see some of the other line items in our budget. 

  • Actor Stipends: $4,500
  • Rehearsal Space: $400 (mostly work exchange or donated)
  • Performance Space: $4,500
  • Costumes: $2,000
  • Music: $500
  • Lighting: $500
  • Set: $1000
  • Production Team Stipends: $2000
  • Printed materials and marketing: $500
  • For every $1000 raised above our goal we will increase each actor's stipend by $50.00

We do Shakespeare... Differently 

We know the Portland Shakespeare scene is saturated. Here is why we think we are worth your precious time and money:

  • Anon it Moves is committed to nontraditional interpretations of Shakespeare's plays. We believe that leaning away from what is rote and familiar allows us to make discoveries in the text that we might not otherwise make. 
  • We challenge type and gender stereotypes in our casting in order to aid in these discoveries and to provide opportunities to performers who would traditionally be overlooked for certain roles. 
  • We believe that theatre should have magic in it. We invite our audiences into worlds full of revelation and surprise, using voices, live instruments, the miraculous human body (and a trick of the light or two) to make magic onstage, old-school.
  • Anon It Moves is a female-led company, with some of the only female artistic directors in town, and female designers and technicians making up the majority of our production teams.

The Hard Ask

The funding for our projects comes directly from you. In the past we have been able to end the run of each show with money in the bank to jump-start the next production. 

  • We ended last season with a profit, and are asking for only a third of our last campaign's goal to bring The Winter's Tale to life, even though this production is much larger and much more ambitious that last season's work.
  • We need your help to make this show what we know it can be! To pay our artists for their tireless and exceptional work, and to make magic that Moves our audience all the way from Sicilia to Bohemia and back again!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share our video with a tag line like "Check out this video for a taste of Anon's upcoming production!".
  • Join us in the house by purchasing tickets at Anonitmoves.org
  • Remember to also use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • For every $1000 we raise beyond our goal we will increase each actor's stipend by $50.00!

Thanks for reading! We hope to see you soon.

story:
Hello friends!

I am thrilled to let you know that Regina Nejman & Company will premiere “…and this is the story thus far” a new multimedia dance/ theater piece, at the prestigious Dixon Place Theater on Wednesday, December 11th and Thursday, December 12th at 7.30Pm.

This project consists of six dancers, a guitar player, a costume designer, a videographer/editor, and tech support. Everyone has been working very hard since May AND WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT!

Your contributions will go directly towards paying artists’ fees!
(Ticket sales only cover a very small amount of the total production’s costs)

I am very excited about this ambitious new dance!  In the piece, the stage is approached as a “site”, the live music is interacted with Brazilian popular music, and a film created by myself will be projected as well. The movement has been carefully constructed and deconstructed to fit the nuances of the piece, and it is intertwined with improvised moments. We are exploring themes such as memory, desire, real and fictional life stories. We recently performed an excerpt of the piece and it was described as AN INCREDIBLE PHYSICAL MANIFESTATION – DANCE AND MUSIC LITERALLY ENGULFING ONE ANOTHER by Theo Boguszewski from The Dance Enthusiast.

You will laugh and you will be moved, excited and inspired, and probably will want to get up and dance too! And you can do that at the reception on Wed, Dec 11th! And of course after the show on Thursday too! I am looking forward to meeting all of you then! Please share our campaign with your friends!

THANK YOU SO MUCH! 

XO, Regina

Dixon Place, 161 Chrystie Street
New York NY 10002
Tickets: $15 in advance, $18 at the door, $12 students / seniors.

www.dixonplace.org  (212) 219-0736.

Get tickets here!
Wednesday: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/9830943
Thursday: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/9830944

story:
About our Project

Award winning playwright/composers Lindsay Warren Baker & Amanda Jacobs are so excited to be putting together a NYC 29-hour STAGED READING and DEMO RECORDING of their new musical, "LILY: A Musical Portrait."

Inspired by "The House of Mirth" by Edith Wharton and the theatrical tradition of Tableaux Vivants, Baker & Jacobs have created a beautiful new musical about Lily Bart, a beautiful woman living in the American Gilded Age who must choose between money and love as she pursues a life of wealth and privilege.

A 29-hour reading will allow us work with a talented creative team and 10 wonderful actors to bring the story to life -- to show us what is working, what needs improvement, and what kind of future theatrical life "LILY" will have.

Our project also includes recording a demo of some of the music which will allow us to promote the show as we continue to develop it.

We are asking everyone who believes in our work to help us. We know that we have a worthy goal, and with your help we can achieve it!

What We Need & What You Get

Having successfully produced our show, "Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE, A Musical" at the 2011 New York Musical Theatre Festival (WINNER: Most Promising Musical) and other demo recordings of our work, we know what it takes to develop and promote a new work. We also know how important it is to spend money wisely.

Our total budget for both the reading and the demo recording is $10,000 which includes:

  • Stipends for our director, musical director, stage management and actors. ($2,200)
  • Rental fees for the rehearsal and presentation studios. ($1,500)
  • Printing of scripts and scores and administrative costs. ($800)
  • Writer transportation and housing -- we don't live in NYC and need a place to sleep! ($2,000)
  • Stipends for the demo recording. ($2,500)
  • Recording studio fees. ($1,000)

We are happy to offer a variety of perks for those who help us reach our goal, including:

  • Acknowledgement on the LILY Facebook page.
  • Your name included in the presentation program.
  • A copy of the newly recorded demo.
  • A signed copy of the presentation program.
  • A special invitation to attend the presentation and a special personal acknowledgement before the reading begins.
  • Tea with the writers.
  • For everyone, we will send email updates about LILY as it continues to develop.

The Impact

Every little bit helps; no amount is too small.

We love creating beautiful work and we will love collaborating with you to bring this new work of art to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially we will sincerely appreciate:

  • Help spreading the word about "LILY: A Musical Portrait"
  • "Like" the LILY Facebook page! www.facebook.com/LILY.A.Musical.Portrait
  • Share the information about our Indiegogo campaign with the world!

From our hearts, we thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute financially we will sincerely appreciate:

Help spreading the word about "LILY: A Musical Portrait"
"Like" the LILY Facebook page! www.facebook.com/LILY.A.Musical.Portrait

Share the information about our Indiegogo campaign with the world!

From our hearts, we thank you.

story:
Kinitiras Studio(www.kinitirastudio.com) and Vicky Adamou present the new Project TimeLine! A work written by Christina Sampaniku and 6 guest writers (http://timelineproject.gr/?page_id=21)

Kinitiras Studio has presented more than 15 complete production works, has taken part in big events, like Athens 2004, has performed works in Megaro Mousikis, Athens and has represented Greece in well-known festivals abroad. It is the first artistic residency centre in Greece with continuous art projects since 1996 and has cooperated with well known Greek and international artists.

Vicky Adamou after her work "Foreign Language" and the online foto romance series "areyousirius.gr" which successfully continues until today, presents the performance Timeline,which is based on devised theatre techniques,where the final piece occurs through improvisational techniques and the creative contribution of all the team members. The initial idea by Vicky Adamou aims to look through a peephole the lives of 6 people as they are presented through the social media. The visible and the invisible parts of their lives through this very specific communication form of the social media. The work is written by Christina Sampanikou and the surprise monologues are written by Kostas Giannakidis, Chara Giannakopoulou, Lucretia, Christos Polymenakos, Thanasis Rokanas and Grigoris Kapsalas.

 

Project TIMELINE description

6 roles taken from the real life, the social media. What? Do you think that social media are not the real life? I guess you are right! They are not; they are more real than life itself, they are the true version of ourselves.

They are the space where you can be free, to reveal whatever the daily conventions try to censor. The space where you can pretend to be what you wish you were and make it believable. We communicate, learn, share, fall in love, make a revolution, psychoanalysis, politics, we advertise our work, we challenge our insecurity, we release ourselves through them.

Social media are a big part of our life. An exploration that unfolds into a work with two parts:

The first part is an online experiment that starts on 11th March and develops in front of you, in the screens of your lap tops/pcs with you as participants and observers. 6 imaginative but at the same time totally recognisable characters are born through the social media.  They have a status and they are formed through the social media platforms, giving you at the same time the opportunity to get to know them.

The Mother Troll, www.facebook.com/mana.manam.735

The Hipster – Active citizen who faces emotional dead ends, www.facebook.com/nefeli.markou.16?fref=ts

The Sleepless Yap woman who has a sleeping libido, www.facebook.com/mirto.timeline

TheFlirtatious Bakery Man who has a vision, www.facebook.com/K.Ntakos?hc_location=stream

The Ruined Narcissus whose best friend is silence, www.facebook.com/johnny.fabriano?fref=ts

The Ex Fat Boy who has escapism syndrome, www.facebook.com/stamatis.tsakanikas?fref=ts

Three men and three women send you an invitation to follow them, to add them as friends, to flirt them, to poke them, to find the relationship among them if there is one, to influence them and to build an online relationship with them. A relationship which will lead into a face to face meeting, when you will have the opportunity to discover if each one of them is what you imagined he/she will be

That lead us to the second part of the project which is the actual performance TIMELINE, a black comedy, which will be on Kinitiras Studio on 17th May and will be the confirmation or the defeat of whatever you have been watching online. Or just the live illustration of the world we have built all together.

 Look for them, then. You might find parts of yourself in them. They might have been made by parts of yourself.

The performance is appropriate for over 18

The money that would be collected through indiegogo will be used for the expenses of the performance, like video, musicians, flyers – posters printing, electrician, light technician, performance space and actors.

The project's team:

Concept - Director : Vicky Adamou

Text: Christina Sampanikou

and 6 monologues by  Kostas Giannakidis, Chara Giannakopoulou, Lucretia, Christos Polymenakos, Thanasis Rokanas and Grigoris Kapsalas

Performers: Violeta Gyra, Efgenia Deliali, George Nikolaidis, John O., Spyros Perdiu, Christina Sampanikou

Videos : Konstantinos Pilavios

Music : George Bitsikas

Lights – Photography : Pavlos Mavridis

 Blog Photography : Spyros Perdiou

Graphic Design : Spyros Kontogiorgis

Thank you very much for your support!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Alison Richards I am a graduated Youth worker and passionate about break dancing (Bboying) as it kept myself a rebel teenager from falling into a bad crowd. I have used my love for Bboying to get thru to dissaffected young people i have come into contact with through my years experiences.

I saw a need in my community as the government made more and more cuts to the youth sector, and started closing clubs, centres cutting funding in disadvantaged areas.Where i live Birmingham is the second biggest city and there is only 1 youth centre in my area.

The young people had no where to go and boredom set in, then they started to entertain themselves in a destructive competitivness leading straight in to crime. I  decided to act as small as it may seem to start a tournament for young and old with a love for breakdancing or dance in general to come together 2-3 times in the year and celebrate what dance had and is doing in our lives and the lives of the children in our community, and make classes and workshops from the celebrities in our field accessable to them.

If you decide to help us today and contribute you will be helping to change the lives confidence and attitudes of many disadvantage kids and young people who want to achieve with Breakdancing and life its self.

these children work hard when training for tournaments and are more than aware of the discipline it takes to become one of the best and they feel a sense of belonging and achievement.

It is important to us because too many young ones are on a path of no return and the juvenile age bracket is getting younger and more frequent in my town.

 Please go to our website and look through our gallery and videos so you can see what we do.

Please consider us helping us . Thank you kindly.

 

We would like to raise 15,000 for our campaign but any help is appreciated. We will hosting 3 tournaments for the year one of which is international and based in italy which would allow their qualifying dancers to come to the uk and compete with the uk dancers.

 Each tournament costs around £4,500

which makes up of judges fees and flights and accomodation , venue costs,prizes and trophies Deejays and Hosts , and staff etc.

We are giving advertising perks away to those who have donated specific amounts. Including advertising on our facebook, twitter, and official websites, also banners of your brand or company at the events. We do not have much to offer but will kindly do so in appreciation for your help.

If we do not reach our campaign goal the money will still be used towards the event. Depending on how much our campaign raises we may do only 1-2 tournaments.

The Impact

I feel this project is very important as a whole as it targets a group that if not given acess to outlets for them to enjoy themselves  may very well get themselves into trouble. Also that does not put pressure financially on parents who may not be able to afford weekly activities for their children. It is also a project that is very current with young people right now and major events like Battle of the Year in france and IBE in holland are aims for our young people to aspire to compete at.

We are very experienced in this kind of event organising and your funding would be put to good use and a great cause.

At present we are funding this project out of our own pockets and the faces and comments of the people we reach make it all worth the effort, we only would like to make this project sustainable as we would hate to take it away from them through lack of funding.

If you cannot contribute with donations please help us to spread the word of our project and what we are trying to achieve all your help is appreciated.

Please use the indigo share tools.

story:
The Waiting... Story

Waiting... is the exciting new musical about the life of GG, a young Latino graffiti artist - and his faltering and blooming in the environs of The City of Angels - Los Angeles. The characters of Prof, Grace, Izzy, and Marcus join him for the journey - a week in the lives of these humorous, yet complicated, Angelenos.

With the city of LA mixed into the stew pot (almost like a sixth character) Waiting... is contemporary musical enfusing a cross-pollination of Latin | Jazz | Pop | Rock | Hip Hop music, and lyrics that bite and console all at once - all serving as its musical stroytelling palette and canvas. 

The Production's Story

Back in May 2012, Waiting... had its successful workshop premiere at Boulder's SoFA.  Over the past year, the script, characters, and music & lyrics have undergone exciting and big changes as this story of GG, Prof, Grace, Izzy, and Marcus has focused, expanded, and bloomed.  

Our Story

Composer/Lyricist/Bookwriter* Michael O'Dell - an acomplished musician and music director for a plethora of shows - from NYC to SF to LA, and most recently the Music Director for the 2010/2012 In the Mood National Tour - is once again at the helm, assembling an artistically savy, talented cast, band, and production team for Waiting... to take its next step:  The 2013 Boulder International Fringe Festival this September for 6 performances. 

How YOU Can Become Part of OUR Story

Waiting... is now on the cusp to take this next BIG step but we need your financial help.  Bringing any show to the stage involves setting a specific budget and production goals to help tell the story efficiently and visually. And bringing a new theatrical work like this to the stage requires real money to meet those artistic and production goals.
 
We have set a campaign goal of $5000+ to be reached by September 9, 2013.  If we reach our goal, we get all of the funds (Huzzah!); and if we raise only a portion of our goal, we only receive a portion of the funds.  Please help us meet 100% of our goal.  ALL monies raised go toward paying:
  • A kick-ass cast (in the form of performance payment & rehearsal stipend)
  • A smoking hot band (in the form of performance payment & rehearsal stipend)
  • An amazing (and real life) grafitti artist to help us create slides and animation for our video projections (in the form of a stipend)
  • Minimal set construction and materials
  • Our 2013 BIFF entrance fee
  • Rehearsal space rental fees
  • Coffee - one must keep artists caffeinated!
  • And miscellaneous production fees

Chip in! Become part of the Waiting... team!  This will most defintiely help us meet our financial goal so we can meet our artistic goals.  And if you do, you'll get one of the cool "PERKS" (at the right side of this page).

YOU Can Us Help Share the Story of OUR Journey!

Here's where you can find us: 
 
The Official Waiting... Website/Blog
Facebook
Twitter
Soundcloud - (listen to some of the music and lyrics from the score!)
 
Every little bit of change helps - even small change.  $5, $10.  Even a contribution of $1!  And if you cannot contribute, but would still like to help, spread the word about this show and our journey to The 2013 Boulder International Fringe Festival!
 
THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!
 
* Lillie Jayne and Michael Mannion have contributed their time and talents to helping our Waiting... characters come to life.

story:
Jordan Saenz, a recent alumnus of the California Institute of the Arts, has taken big leaps to produce her choreographic work since her commencement in May 2012. Seeking to push the boundaries of dance and art making, she formed the group Saenz and the Noise. Comprised of some of Jordan's favorite choreographers and dearest friends, this collective has had quite an eventful year. Thus far, Jordan’s work has been shown at Pieter Performance Space, Live Arts L.A., and Highways Performance space. In November of 2012, her work was selected to be performed as part of REDCAT’S Fall Studio. Jordan allows her hip hop training to influence her contemporary movement in an attempt to offer audiences explosive, percussive movement and a sense of familiarity. In a playful back and forth between ambiguity and honesty, she aims to make the human experience easily accessible.

 

Evan White is a Saxophonist/electronic musician/producer from Denver, Colorado. Evan solely composed and performed the music for Saenz's previous dance piece and found great joy in the collaboration. He believes that with this project, collectively with more musicians and dancers, the musicians will be able to find greater inspiration through the movements of the dancers and vice versa.

 

Steven Kai van Betten is a Guitarist/Composer/Teacher, who is actively involved in the Los Angeles creative music community. Born and raised in the rural town of Blue Diamond, Nevada, Steven began studying guitar and writing music at an early age.  He now composes and performs with several different bands branching from intimate chamber folk music to rhythmically interlocking indie rock. In addition, he has had the opportunity to collaborate and compose music for several different emerging choreographers and made his debut as a film composer in Dave Wolter’s student academy award winning animation “Eyrie”. 

 

July 11-12

ARC Performance Space in Pasadena

For this project, Jordan is interested in in creating a dialogue with musicians that will blur the line between the two mediums. Featuring original music by Evan White and Steven Van Betten, this new work explores the fragmentation of memory. Their aim is to capture the sentiment of clinging to fading memories, while longing to erase others. Together, the three of them will create a space where dance and music can overlap and rely on one another.

Dancers:

Lindsey Lollie, Jamie Pea, Princess Romero, Jordan Saenz, Kerrie Schroeder, Tiffany Stacey and Stephanie Zaletel

 

Musicians:

Evan White, Steven Van Betten, John Schwerbel

 

Lighting Design: Andrew Munie

 

The Impact

It is imperitive that we continue to make art in these times to cultivate our community and enrich our youth.  As the world continues to change, it is important for us to evolve and take part in effecting the environment we live in.  Unfortunately funds for the arts are hard to come by and that's where you can help contribute.  By aiding us in the funding of this project it will not only support these amazing artists, but also promote music and dance making in the community.  It will bring forth an awareness and appreciation for art.  You have the chance to contribute to something that will continue to grow and inspire others!  

Funding Goal is $3500

Dancers and musicians $2200

Rental Space and insurance waver $800

Equipment and costumes $300

Lighting $200

With your donations and support we will be able to pay the dancers, musicians, lighting designer and other aspects of production.  Anything helps!

Thank You!

story:
So, what is it I'm doing?

My name is Megan Marshall and I am making my way to New York City this summer. I will be interning with both a production/management company and a theatre company. It has always been my goal and dream to work in New York's theatre industry. After I graduate UC's College-Conservatory of Music next year, I will be moving to the city to become a permanent resident. These upcoming internships are wildly important to the start of my career. Working in both a business environment and an artistic environment, I will be acquiring knowledge to help fulfill my life-long goal of creating my own theatre company in New York. This next step in my career-building process is immensely invigorating and a little frightening (in the most exciting way, of course). I would love for you to join me. Through your donations, you become a partner in my artistic journey. Together, I believe we can build something new and exciting to impact the world of theatre.

The Logistics:

Interns are often paid very little for their work. One internship is for school credit and the other will be giving me a $20 travel stipend. Clearly, this will not help me support myself while I'm working in the city. It may seem strange to be working for practically nothing, but as I described before, the experience is invaluable. My expenses will include travel costs, rent and utilities, metrocards, and food. All this comes to around $3,650. My goal for this fundraiser is $1,500 to help lighten that number. But, anything helps! Here's a breakdown of expected costs:

Travel:$400

Rent & Utilities (3 months): $2,500

Metrocards (3 months): $345

Food (3 months): $400

Your contributions are vitally important for me to make this career-enhancing journey. I am endlessly grateful for anything that can be donated. Every little bit helps!

The Impact:

I cannot express how important this experience is to me and my career. Many of you know me as an actor, but I want to contribute to the theatre world in more ways than that. I believe that theatre has a unique way of reaching out to the eclectic group of people that make up our world... I want to use my aforementioned goal of creating a theatre company to take advantage of that unique communication. I intend to develop a company that focuses on works dealing with violence in today's culture. Not only do I want to produce plays that deal with that subject matter, but I also intend for the company to be heavily involved in community organizations that deal with these issues.

That being said, a girl about to graduate college has to start somewhere to achieve such a large goal. These internships are Step One.

Please donate to help me take this giant leap forward. All donations will go directly to my internship expenses.

If I happen to exceed my goal, I will be donating all extra donations to the local Women Helping Women Center who serve survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Their efforts to promote awareness and to help prevent violent crimes have led me to a working relationship with the organization. I intend on sharing excess donations with them due to their support throughout the beginning of my artistic journey.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you're unable to make a donation, don't worry about it! There are other ways to help: please share my campaign by posting it to your Facebook or emailing it to anyone who may want to contribute. And please send positive vibes!
story_txt:
So, what is it I'm doing?
My name is Megan Marshall and I am making my way to New York City this summer. I will be interning with both a production/management company and a theatre company. It has always been my goal and dream to work in New York's theatre industry. After I graduate UC's College-Conservatory of Music next year, I will be moving to the city to become a permanent resident. These upcoming internships are wildly important to the start of my career. Working in both a business environment and an artistic environment, I will be acquiring knowledge to help fulfill my life-long goal of creating my own theatre company in New York. This next step in my career-building process is immensely invigorating and a little frightening (in the most exciting way, of course). I would love for you to join me. Through your donations, you become a partner in my artistic journey. Together, I believe we can build something new and exciting to impact the world of theatre.


The Logistics:
Interns are often paid very little for their work. One internship is for school credit and the other will be giving me a $20 travel stipend. Clearly, this will not help me support myself while I'm working in the city. It may seem strange to be working for practically nothing, but as I described before, the experience is invaluable. My expenses will include travel costs, rent and utilities, metrocards, and food. All this comes to around $3,650. My goal for this fundraiser is $1,500 to help lighten that number. But, anything helps! Here's a breakdown of expected costs:
Travel:$400
Rent & Utilities (3 months): $2,500
Metrocards (3 months): $345
Food (3 months): $400
Your contributions are vitally important for me to make this career-enhancing journey. I am endlessly grateful for anything that can be donated. Every little bit helps!


The Impact:
I cannot express how important this experience is to me and my career. Many of you know me as an actor, but I want to contribute to the theatre world in more ways than that. I believe that theatre has a unique way of reaching out to the eclectic group of people that make up our world... I want to use my aforementioned goal of creating a theatre company to take advantage of that unique communication. I intend to develop a company that focuses on works dealing with violence in today's culture. Not only do I want to produce plays that deal with that subject matter, but I also intend for the company to be heavily involved in community organizations that deal with these issues.
That being said, a girl about to graduate college has to start somewhere to achieve such a large goal. These internships are Step One.
Please donate to help me take this giant leap forward. All donations will go directly to my internship expenses.
If I happen to exceed my goal, I will be donating all extra donations to the local Women Helping Women Center who serve survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Their efforts to promote awareness and to help prevent violent crimes have led me to a working relationship with the organization. I intend on sharing excess donations with them due to their support throughout the beginning of my artistic journey.
Other Ways You Can Help:


If you're unable to make a donation, don't worry about it! There are other ways to help: please share my campaign by posting it to your Facebook or emailing it to anyone who may want to contribute. And please send positive vibes!

story:
Tim Burton’s classic Gothic fairy tale, EDWARD SCISSORHANDS is now on stage! Opening June 25th at the Bayard Studio Theater in Williamsburg Brooklyn for 10 performance nights only!
THIS IS THE WORLD PREMIERE!

Directed by Richard Crawford, Edward Scissorhands the play will reflect the gothic fairy tale it’s purest form. With a splash of dark, edgy appeal, Richard Crawford intends on making this an experience for the audience, rather then a simple night out.

Audience members will be treated to table service during the performances, reminiscent of a Parisian speakeasy the way theater should be!

Support the show’s production and help EDWARD SCISSORHANDS become a full time run in New York!

Every donation counts! Any where from 5 dollars to 500 dollars, choose your own amount!

purchase tickets for the show at smarttix.com
visit our facebook event page here:

http://www.facebook.com/SallyGolan#!/event.php?...
Contact Sally Golan of Social Exposure media for press inquiries
sgolan1@rogers.com

story:
Support Canada’s Emerging Artists

Little Black Afro Productions is a Toronto based Theatre Company that was created to stage Luke Reece's original work. After 5 successful shows we decided to create a program where any young artist can have the opportunity to stage their work.

In the Spring of 2014, we will be producing a new piece of work by a young Canadian artist and staging it in Toronto. We will provide stage management, technicians, actors, designers, a venue, marketing/promotions, set, costumes and props. The selected artist may choose to direct their piece if they want the full experience and we will be right there with them every step of the way.

We are proud to say that we have selected our piece and it is Muse by Veronica Appia, an emerging Director and Playwright currently studying at York University.

","serif";}

Muse is an inter-media project, which combines visual and performing art in order to provide its audience with a new and innovative theatrical experience we call “Gallery Theatre”. Muse has been created and workshopped, since January 2013, in York University's Playwriting Program under the direction of Dr. Judith Rudakoff. Through this project, we aim to allow our audiences to view both visual art and theatre in a new way, while providing them with the opportunity to see the meaning behind the visual art work featured in this play, from a variety of perspectives. Set in a gallery, this show is designed to take its audience directly to the action. Spectators will be guided in groups to each piece of visual art set up around the gallery, and they will be able to view the artwork as well as a performance that coincides with each piece.

We have always been heavily involved with charity, giving a portion of our profits to a charity relevant to our production. We have volunteered with the Mad Student Society, helping them with Hamilton’s very first Mad Pride event, donated to the Mental Health Rights Coalition of Hamilton, the CP24 CHUM Christmas Wish and the Eden Food Bank. This is a tradition we intend to continue and ingrain in the artists that we take on during this project. We are looking to work with SKETCH, a community-arts-development initiative based in Toronto engaging young people homeless and on the margins from across Canada. They create opportunities for them to experience the transformative power of the arts. We are really excited to partner with them on this project.

In the eighteen months we have been running we have produced five original pieces of work, four of which were independent productions. The fifth and most recent production ‘A Little Too Close To Home’ won Best of Venue at the 2013 Hamilton Fringe Festival. Our Artistic Director Luke Reece is very well connected in the Theatre Community and we will be utilizing those connections to bring in experienced mentors to help coach our Emerging Artists. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3,270 to help us cover the costs of renting a venue, rehearsal space, set, props, costume, artist fees and marketing. We want to make sure that we can provide our emerging artist with all the resources they need to get their work to the stage. Of course, this means we need a stage.

$1,500 will go towards renting the venue

$500 will go towards rehearsal space

$200 will go towards props, costume and set

$400 will go to the performers, designers and selected playwright/director

$200 will go towards marketing

$200 will go towards charity and community outreach

$270 will go towards covering the Indiegogo fees

Our contributors will receive a number of unique and exciting perks. There is everything from a free admittance to see the performance, to having your very own website designed for you. Other highlights from our list of perks include being featured on one of our Vlogs, having a song written for you, and an invite to our VIP Company After-Party.

If we do not reach our goal then everything that we have raised will still go towards funding the Emerging Artist Project.  We will continue to work hard to ensure that this production is something we’re proud of, something our selected artist is proud of, and something that the young artists of Canada can be proud of.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! If you find yourself on Facebook or Twitter, take a few seconds to retweet us and like or share our posts. The more people know about the Emerging Artist Project, the more support Canada’s young artists can get.

If you know of a cheap place to rent rehearsal space, or a charity you think fits with our piece, or any other resources you think we could use, let us know. We can be reached at info@littleblackafro.com

Thank you very much and we appreciate the support!

story:
Help me bring my show, Last Dance into full production!

 
In 2009, I wrote a one person show about love, dance and pop music called Last Dance. This semi autobiographical piece charts Sienna's journey from elementary school til the present as she attempts to understand why her love life is far from stellar.
 
I have done a workshop production in 2010 and now I am ready to produce to mount a full production with lights in a proper theatre. I will be presenting Last Dance in September 2012. It will be directed by Djennie Laguerre and feature composer/accompanist Adam Weinmann and collaborative musician, Etienne Levesque.
 

I need about about $3500....

In order to pay for the theatre, director fees and marketing and publicity, I need about $4500. I plan to raise $1000 through fundraising events and sponsorship, so I need your help to bring it to the next level.

With the money raised on IndieGogo, I will able to:

pay the $1500 cost for the theatre

have $2000 to pay my director (Djennie Laguerre!)

 

Your contribution would mean so much to me!

Last Dance is my first one person show and the response was so positive from the workshop. I really feel people want to hear this story. After I mount this full production in September 2012, I plan to tour Last Dance to festivals all over North America and the world. So if you don't live in Toronto, your contribution will help me to bring Last Dance to your city!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, but you still want to support, please:
  • Spread the word via facebook, twitter etc
  • Let me know if you can donate a product or service that I can raffle off at one of my fundraiser

 

Thank you, thank you for supporting independent art making! No matter how much you give, it makes a difference!

story:
My Dream Coming True

Hi, I'm Hypnotist Kevin Lepine.  A Detroit native and New Orleans transplant now living in Las Vegas.  I have been touring the world doing Hypnosis Show for over 15 years.  Two years ago I was picked up to be part of Hypnosis Unleashed/Hypnotiq on the Las Vegas Strip.  Our theater closed ending a very successful run.  Now a major Las Vegas Hotel and Casino here in Las Vegas is offering me my own showroom!

 

This is a dream come true!  Doing hypnosis shows has always been my passion.  Making people laugh all over the world and showing them what their minds can really do is incredible.  My show has meet to amazing reviews and now it gets to grow even further. 

 

But for my dream to come true I need your help.

I NEED YOU!

Opening a show in Vegas is expensive and tough.  Thankfully having worked here the last two years has given me the experience on how to make it.  With the support of the Hotel, great friend&fellow performer Michael Johns, and people anxious to push ticket sales this will be great.  But there are things I need in order to do it right.

1)  Advertisement:

     a) Rack Cards for all the different brokers

     b) Postcards/flyers

     c)  Magazine Ads

     d)  Posters

     e)  Outdoor Banners

     f)  Graphic Design

     g)  Website

 

2)  Sound and Lights

     a) The sound system will need to be upgraded in the room

     b)  A small row of new stage lights and spot light will be needed

 

3)  Opening costs

     a) Legal fees

     b) Room deposits

     c)  Additional insurances

These are a small part of opening a show in Vegas.  While I want your help, I need your partnership.  All donations to getting the show open will come with everything from Hypnotic Self Help CD's, DVD's, Show Tickets, even trips out here.  I want you to be part of the experience.  I will even be starting a blog detailing everything that is happening for you to follow along!

Let's make it happen!

This will launch my dream where I've wanted it to go!  Will it cure the common cold or make travel to Mars cheaper?  Probably not.  But it will be fun, give people laughter and employ people so that's good!


It's a night out of laughter and fun.  It's another way to show people what hypnosis can do.  It's a fun show that has gotten great reviews.  Now it can go to a whole new level!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can only throw in a buck or two, it helps.  Plus you can make that buck or two really valuable by putting the link to this on your Facebook wall, Tweet it, or email it.
 
Everything helps.  In the words of the wise and old philosophers Bartles and James:  "Thank you for your support!"

story:
Our Story

Rite of Passage Theatre Company exists to facilitate opportunity for young "coming of age" theatre artists who are transitioning into the professional world. We believe that training, skill, patience, and dedication to our art must be coupled with a chance to perform in order to foster success. Rite of Passage is also dedicated to the cultivation and realization of new and thought-provoking works by both emerging and established artists.


Love Song of the Albanian Sous Chef by Robert Askins, our submission into the 2011 Festival of Independent Theatres, was accepted and is running from July 23 to August 6 at The Bath House Cultural Center in Dallas, Texas. We are asking for your help in assisting us finance this show's World Premiere.


What We Need

Love Song of the Albanian Sous Chef is, without a doubt, our biggest production to date. Without giving too much away, the story incorporates elements of magic and the supernatural, along with a strong musical undertone (it is a Love Song, after all). We are wanting to raise an additional $750 to what we already have in order to give this show a full World Premiere production. Not extravagant, but full. The money raised will go towards costume rental/purchase, set build, puppet construction, food props, as well as for necessary electrical equipment for our "magic" and live musicians.


What You Get

We are excited to be able to offer some perks to our donors! We cannot thank you enough for your support, but wanted to give you something special for being our favorites. By contributing to our campaign, you can receive ultra-cool items like: original music from our show, Rite of Passage swag and exclusives like a cast/crew cookbook, among others depending on your gift level. Check out the perks list on the right and THANK YOU SO MUCH.


Other Ways You Can Help

Another invaluable way to show your support is to attend our shows. If you're in the Dallas area, we would love for you to come see Love Song of the Albanian Sous Chef. The schedule for the festival can be found here. Also, visit our website to view updates for this and future productions.

story:
Our Story

"There was a town. There was a circus. And there was an elephant..."


Elephant's Graveyard is a play combining historical fact and legend to tell the story of the only known lynching of an elephant. Told through the perspective of the townspeople of Erwin, Tennessee, and the people of Spark's World Famous Circus, Elephant's Graveyard is a play about spectacle, greed, and revenge.


The project is being presented by a group of students at Pace University in lower Manhattan.


Elephant's Graveyard by George Brant

Place: Schaeberle Studio, 41 Park Row, 10th Floor

Time: November 8th-12th, 8pm

Ticket Reservations: theater@pace.edu


Director: Colton Childs

Assistant Director: Ellie Garvey

Stage Manager: Catherine Volpe

Costume Design: Matsy Stinson

Set Design: Jeffrey T. Perri

Lighting Design: Justin West

Assistant Stage Managers: Austin Klich, Brian Piehl


Ringmaster: Ian Cherry

Trainer: Joe Cordaro

Ballet Girl: Polina Ionina

Tour Manager: Brandon Pfeltz

Strongman: Eamon Goebel

Clown: Xavier Reminick

Drummer: Jesse Keitel

Hungry Townsperson: Ashley Romans

Marshal: Joshua Wise

Muddy Townsperson: Rachel Tate

Preacher: Niko Papastefanou

Steam Shovel Operator: Keith Vartanian

Young Townsperson: Emma Jane

Engineer: Steven Brandt

Guitarist: Grant Crawford


Elephant's Graveyard is produced by special arrangement with Samuel French, Inc.


What We Need & What You Get

Considering we are a group of theater students, our funds are limited. We are relying on donations by wonderful folks like you to help bring our vision to the stage.


What's In It For Us?


Each dollar you donate will help provide paint, materials for our set, costumes, props, musical instruments needed for the show, as well as various other expenses.


What's In It For You?


Your $5 Donation Gets You: A handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.

Your $10 Donation Gets You: Acknowledgement in the program AND a handwritten leter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.

Your $30 Donation Gets You: A full-sized poster from our production, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.

Your $50 Donation Gets You: A full-sized poster from our production signed by the cast, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.

Your $75 Donation Gets You: Two tickets to the invited dress performance on Monday, November 7th at 8pm, a full-size poster from our production signed by the cast, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.


All rewards can be picked up following each performance at the box office. If you are unable to attend the show, we will be happy to mail them to you.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please send this campaign to others and help spread the word about Elephant's Graveyard at Pace University!


http://www.indiegogo.com/elephantsgraveyard

Considering we are a group of theater students, our funds are limited. We are relying on donations by wonderful folks like you to help bring our vision to the stage.

What's In It For Us?

Each dollar you donate will help provide paint, materials for our set, costumes, props, musical instruments needed for the show, as well as various other expenses.

What's In It For You?

Your $5 Donation Gets You: A handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.
Your $10 Donation Gets You: Acknowledgement in the program AND a handwritten leter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.
Your $30 Donation Gets You: A full-sized poster from our production, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.
Your $50 Donation Gets You: A full-sized poster from our production signed by the cast, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.
Your $75 Donation Gets You: Two tickets to the invited dress performance on Monday, November 7th at 8pm, a full-size poster from our production signed by the cast, acknowledgement in the program, and a handwritten letter from a member of the Elephant's Graveyard family.

All rewards can be picked up following each performance at the box office. If you are unable to attend the show, we will be happy to mail them to you.


Other Ways You Can Help
Please send this campaign to others and help spread the word about Elephant's Graveyard at Pace University!

http://www.indiegogo.com/elephantsgraveyard

story:
Last year over 25 supporters contributed $1,600 to fund Kevin Jenkins' dance film "Luminos".  It went on to win Pointe Magazine's Editors Choice Award and was featured in the February 2012 issue. 

This year Kevin embarks on a much more ambitious project with his new film "Black Tie Affair," a humorous and moving film involving a man, a black suit, and a myriad of dancing scenarios.  

Join Kevin and support this film by contributing to the $5,000 budget needed to produce his new work.  Every dollar goes towards the production costs and paying the artists involved.  There will be original songs composed and recorded, filming and editing costs, and choreographer/dancer stipends to facilitate this film's completion. 

Thank you for supporting this project and thank you for supporting art.

 

Create Art

Inspire Hope

Inspire Hope

story:
Hi! We’re RubyRico Productions, a live-music-and-dance company in Austin, Texas, which produces gritty, dazzling onstage spectacles. Our new project is a melodramatic, dancing, lip-syncing, air-guitaring tribute to the world’s most beloved mini-rock opera, Queen's BOHEMIAN RHAPSODY. It’s a big song with a big effect on people all over the world, so in order to do it justice we’re making our number as big as possible—and booking a season of appearances for it, to boot! But to make it big, we need your help.

We need to raise $3,500 for rehearsal space rental, wigs, costumes, video work and, especially, to pay 10 deeply dedicated performers, who often get nothing for months of work. So we’re asking you, our beloved community, for contributions … and to show our appreciation, we’re offering sneak peeks at rehearsals, visits to our glorious wig-maker’s studio, a cast photo, front-row tickets to our ultimate 2012 performance, and even post-show drinks with the cast. Plus the knowledge that by helping to rehearse, document, wig, costume and pay us, you’re contributing to a joyful, outrageous performance that guarantees you’ll never think of Bohemian Rhapsody the same way again.

 

YES, THAT SONG!

For copyright reasons, we can’t play the song in our video—but you know the song. It’s been sung by rockers, choirs, Muppets and a drunk Canadian who got arrested. And it’s your karaoke song!

You may well ask: What makes you think the world needs another interpretation of this masterpiece? The answer is simple: NOBODY HAS EVER DONE IT LIKE THIS BEFORE.

 

WHAT THE SONG INSPIRED/ WHAT WE'RE DOING

Equal parts dance piece, lip-sync drag number and live music video. Performed by 10 award-winning professional Austin performers. Wearing specially made, glammed-up 18th-century costumes and gigantic pastel wigs. Spouting all the pageantry, pathos, gender-mucking, pomp, circumstance, depravity and bombast we can possibly cram into it! 

 

WHEN AND WHERE IT'S HAPPENING

RubyRico Productions is preparing a season of appearances for this 10-minute extravaganza, to be presented as part of several showcases around Austin during 2012. After our August 16th and 23rd engagements at the Alamo Drafthouse’s Arena Rock Singalongs, we are excited to be providing the finale for "12 Ways to End the World" on September 25th at the ND, a fashion performance produced by Allyson Garro of Coco Coquette, who also creates monumental wigs for all the performers. 

 

HOW MUCH WE NEED TO DO THIS

Film documentation (generously discounted rate)                                               $   200

60 hours rehearsal space rental (crazy cheap $10/hour rate)                              $   600

10 wigs (designing & styling donated by Coco Coquette)                                    $   700

10 costumes (design & construction by Amanda Martinez)                                  $1,000

Performance pay - 10 dancers (600 rehearsal hours donated)                             $1,000

                                                                                                  TOTAL             $3,500

And if you’d rather contribute something besides money, you can always help in these ways: 

By spreading the word; helping us get gigs; doing admin/pre-production tasks; moving staging equipment (borrowed trucks get extra love!); and helping backstage during the performance.

 

WHO WE THINK WE ARE

RubyRico Productions is a self-supported performance company that since 2005 has packed theaters and nightclubs with daring, funny, extravagant performances and parties.

The Bo Rhap cast is bursting with nominees/winners of Austin Critics’ Table and B. Iden Payne awards, but these professionals also sport impressive alter egos: sleazy frontman of a ukulele band, butoh-practicing faux drag queen, Filipino folk dancer, vaudevillian baggy-pants clown, acro-yogi and bona fide Broadway star (yes, he was in Cats)!

 

WHY YOU WANNA HELP

If you’ve ever stayed in your car until the last gong, acted out the lyrics (or wanted to), or thrown up a fist during the hard-rocking sections, then you clearly share our love for the song. By contributing to our campaign, you can help us create a hilarious, heartfelt and appropriately over-the-top tribute to Queen’s magnum opus, Bohemian Rhapsody!

 

THANK YOU!

story:
The production, is a light-hearted, creative and engaging play based on a book by children’s non-fiction author Jan Adkins, Moving Heavy Things. It received a starred review in Scientific American as a distinguished science book for young people, and a “Best Science Book of the Year” from the American Association of Science Teachers. Producer Russ Skellington shares, "I met this book as a child and was inspired by it to approach problems in a more positive, more hopeful way. This feeling of empowerment is what the play celebrates."
Lift With Your Knees Productions will be enacting examples from the book using colorful sets and physical examples. In addition to actors, dancers and “Heavy Lifters” performing large-scale physics, we will also include audience participation where the audience will be invited to move heavy things too.

The production is geared to children grades 4 - 6 and hopes to share empowerment with young people, show them that they can accomplish anything they put their mind to. We’ll bring exuberance, humor and madcap excitement to simple physics. Our audience will watch big, heavy things being lifted, rolled, flipped, twirled and gently repositioned by singing characters in a colorful non-fiction presentation quite unlike anything we’ve seen before. Join us!

 

Your contrubution will go to providing transportation for patrons as the venue is a little off the beaten track. We want to provide a fun safe ride for anyone involved in the Fringe fest to get to our venue ans experence our show first hand. We are also trying to arrange for a matine show for local youth. Transportation is an issue we would like to resolve so that we can provide a free educational and entertaining afternoon for our local children. Anything you can give will help achieve this goal.

As incentives we have Copies of the Book, Moving heavy Things, Shirts, Patches, A meet and greet and other great ways for us to say thank you for your support!

Money is tight these days and we understand. Perhaps instead you could donate a few minutes of your time sharing us, Moving Heavy Things to the people you know. We may never reach them without you.

story:
What is this?

The New School for Drama is hosting a special, three-performance run of Jose Rivera's play BRAINPEOPLE in collaboration with Mr. Rivera himself, featuring New School alumni alongside other New York professionals.  This'll be the first chance to see BRAINPEOPLE in New York, and we've only got a short time to make it happen.  We need your help!

You can find details about the performances and the cast and crew on our Facebook event page.

What's BRAINPEOPLE?

BRAINPEOPLE is a play by Jose Rivera, about a woman named Mayannah who sends her armored limosine out into a ruined city to pick up two strangers and bring them back to her palatial home for an exotic feast and some deep conversation.  Things get complicated when one of the guests brings along her cadre of "brainpeople," and the meal turns into an evening of brutal honesty and terrifying introspection.

What's the money for?

This IndieGoGo is to help us raise the money to make this production happen.  Everyone involved is doing this for nothing, for a love of the project and a real belief that BRAINPEOPLE is a play people need to see.  But we need the space and the time to make that happen, and your money will go a long way to making this a reality.

The money will be used for:

  • The rental of rehearsal space
  • Props and materials for the set
  • Costumes
  • Publicity for the show
  • Other fun fees hidden inside every theatre production (lamp maintenance! transportation!)

What do I get out of it?

Other than a warm, fuzzy feeling and a contribution to the arts that will echo through the community? We've got perks! You can check 'em out along the side of the page, but they include tickets to the performances, programs, screenplays and scripts signed by Jose Rivera himself, and even a chance to get coffee with the man and ask him the burning questions that anyone might want to ask an Obie Award-winnning playwright and Academy Award-nominated screenwriter.

What if you exceed your goal?

Well, the goal for this campaign is just to get us stared: to meet all of our expected costs, we'll need close to $3000.  So money raised above and beyond our goal here will keep getting funnelled into the production, to make it as strong a piece as we possibly can.  Beyond that?  We'll put the money towards better materials for our set and costumes.  And if we raise enough money, we'd love to be able to give a little something back to our cast and crew, to thank them for the monumental effort they're already putting in.

How else can I help?

Later in May, we're hoping to have a fundraiser evening where you'll have a chance to bid on some items in a silent auction and hear monologues written by Jose and performed by a member of our wonderful cast.  We'll keep you posted as to when and where that's going to happen.

Beyond that? Spread the word! Tell your friends, tell your families, tell your dog.  Tell your favorite barista.  Tweet us!  Blog about us!  The more people who know about this little project, the more people will be able to experience this remarkable play.

Who's Jose Rivera?

Jose is a playwright and screenwriter; he's written around two dozen plays including MARISOL, REFERENCES TO SALVADOR DALI MAKE ME HOT, and MASSACRE (SING TO YOUR CHILDREN), has contributed to half a dozen TV shows (including co-creating EERIE, INDIANA), and has written a bunch of films, including MOTORCYCLE DIARIES (for which he was nominated for an Academy Award, making him the first Puerto Rican-born writer to earn the distinction) and the upcoming ON THE ROAD, based on the novel by Jack Kerouac.  He's won two Obie Awards, a Whiting Writers' Award, and a Fulbright Arts Fellowship, among many other distinctions.

What's the New School for Drama?

The New School for Drama is an MFA (Master of Fine Arts) conservatory program that trains actors, playwrights and directors in a three-year program.  The training is rigorous, high-quality, and wide-reaching, with a special focus on collaboration and the creation of new work.  You can check us out here.

story:
Inspired by Alfred Kubin’s paintings and his dystopic novel, The Other Side, which pointedly displays the perpetually claustrophobic absurdity of culture while asking us to enter and luxuriate in the adventure of the void. THE VOID explores one man’s multilayered consciousness in relation to physics and aims to present a shockingly detailed vision of articulate forms with inarticulate perceptions. An Illustrator falls into his void-mind while attempting to frame his own reality, and there finds two unconscious dual forces are waiting for him: inseparable yet opposite sisters wrestling with each other endlessly. The Illustrator’s survival depends upon engaging these two forces, eternally charged and threatening his complete annihilation.

Hybrid Stage Project is invited to present THE VOID at the Incubator Arts Project (inside St. Marks Church), in October 2010. THE VOID will be produced in association with Incubator Arts Project. Hybrid Stage Project is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas.

THE VOID
Conceived & Written by Fulya Peker and Deborah Wallace.
Featuring: Mark Jaynes, Fulya Peker, Deborah Wallace
Set design by Nate Lemoine
Lighting Design by Zach Murphy
Sound Design by Julian Mesri

Currently Hybrid Stage Project is in need of your support to bring THE VOID into life. At this point whatever you may offer, $10 or $1000, will help us a great deal. We have some perks for you in exchange. Most importantly we would like to invite you all to share the construction of THE VOID with us…

Please do spread the word…

THANK YOU!

story:
The Black Seminoles

"The Black Seminoles" is a play that tells the true but little-known story of the Black  Seminole Indians struggle to exist and maintain their freedom in Florida between 1700 and 1842. I am a descendant of William the Conqueror and the Black and Indian Seminole Indians.  I am an author and producer, and the play is adapted from my book "The Black Seminoles."  We would like for the play to open this Fall, and we need your support to help make that happen!

The play is dedicated to the thousands of black Seminoles who gave their lives in the pursuit of freedom and liberty. Very few people are even aware that such a people exist, so anyone who gives a donation will be helping us to achieve the monumental task of enlightening the world about this dramatic and important part of our history. The spell-bounding play's five main characters include Abraham, Wildcat, Cudjoe, Osceola and Osceola's wife, who are constantly under the threat of losing their freedom.  One of the most dramatic scenes of the play occurs when Osceola's wife is seized by slave-catchers at Fort King.  The seizing of Osceola's wife commenced the beginning of the Second Seminole War.   

 Our initial goal of $25,000.00 covers all the basic logistical expenses of producing a play in Tampa, Florida-- our venue fee and publicity materials,

Any money that we raise here will first cover the cost of our venue, but any further money we raise will go toward the many other cost associated with producing a play, such as our technical needs, publicity materials, and costumes.  

Anyone who gives a donation of any amount will receive thanks on the "Supporters" page of our website and anyone who gives $50.00 or more will receive a free book and have their names (or someone they would like to honor) tastefully displayed in the play's program.  Also, anyone who gives $100.00 or more will receive the same perks and an invitation to the opening night of the "The Black Seminoles." There are also some great additional perks available for larger donations, such as  DVDs of the play and personal postcards.

We will provide you with our website where we will be posting updates about the play, including the venue and dates and times of the performances.  So, if you're going to be in the Tampa Bay area on those dates, please make sure you come check us out!  Thank you in advance for your support!

story:
"YOU GOTTA BE LIKE A ROCK AND ROLL JESUS WITH A COWBOY MOUTH"

1971. New York City. Sam Shepard has left his wife to live with rock goddess Patti Smith in the Chelsea Hotel. What followed would be one of the most tumultuous periods in either artist's lives. This time of personal upheaval was documented in the play Cowboy Mouth. Set in that same destitute hotel room, the play is an intimate look into the lives of two characters(Slim and Cavale) who try to find solace in religion, sex, drugs and rock and roll; often all at once. 
This production of Cowboy Mouth is going to be staged at The Underground Theater at SUNY Purchase College on February 7-9 as senior project thesis work for the two actors involved and the costume designer. The play combines elements of kitchen-sink realism, frightening surrealistic tangents, a violent love story, and even a good old fashioned rock concert. Filled with songs, noise, sound and fury, Cowboy Mouth is a kaleidoscopic look into one of the most fractured relationships in theater history. 

WHERE YOUR $$$ IS GOING

As this in an entirely student run production, we need YOUR help in funding the basic neccesities for this play. In order to be as transparent as possible, take a look at where your hard earned money is actually going if you decide to donate to our cause.

  • The production rights to the play. We can't produce the show without the rights.
  • Materials to build the set/props
  • Costume construction
  • Making posters/playbills/other media to go along with advertising the show
  • To compensate the union professionals who are helping us put together this show.


CAST AND CREW

Starring:
Arden Winant (Cavale)
Jonathan Schenk (Slim)

Directed by Andrew Jones
Assistant Director/Stage Manager: Sebastian Pray 
Set Designer: Alexander Whittenberg
Costume Designer: Iliana Paris
Lighting Designer: Carson Volpe
Props Designer: Lacey Ballard
Dramaturg: Gabriel Vasquez
Master Electrician: Nick Sciretta
Sounds: Raymond Chalme
Video shot by Thomas DiCostanzo 

FEBRUARY 7/8/9 THE UNDERGROUND THEATER

story:
"One of Chicago's most promising young theatre companies" - Time Out

 

Interrobang Theatre Project raised the curtain on its 4th Season with the critically-acclaimed and Jeff Recommended TERMINUS by Mark O'Rowe.  The season continues with one of British playwright Philip Ridley's most exciting and frightening works, THE PITCHFORK DISNEY.

Ten years ago, Presley and Haley's parents disappeared. Now a grownup, agoraphobic, self-medicating, modern-day Hansel and Gretel, the adult-children gorge on chocolate and use fantasy as a spell to keep the boogeyman at bay.  But one night their safe isolation is shattered by the arrival a bizarre performance artist, Cosmo Disney, and his mute mate Pitchfork Cavaliere.  THE PITCHFORK DISNEY is a pitch black comedy and a gothic fairy tale that slithers between horror and our anxiety-ridden reality.


Ticket sales account for less than 30% of what it costs to produce a play in Chicago.  Interrobang Theatre Project is able to produce risky, smart, muscular work thanks to the generosity of savvy fans and donors like you. 

Support Challenging Theatre and Interrobang Theatre Project - Changing Our World One Play at a Time!


THE PITCHFORK DISNEY

by Philip Ridley

Directed by Co-Artistic Director Jeffry Stanton

Featuring Andrew Goetten (Presley Stray), Aislinn Kerchaert (Haley Stray), Mark Lancaster (Pitchfork Cavaliere), and Kevin Webb (Cosmo Disney). 

Understudies Matthew Dealy (Presley) and Eric Feltes (Cosmo) will perform the 3pm matinee on February 22, 2014.

The production team for THE PITCHFORK DISNEY includes: Stephen Carmody (Scenic Designer), Claire Chrzan* (Lighting Designer & Production Manager), Noel Huntzinger* (Costume Designer), Christopher M. LaPorte* (Sound Designer), Lindsay Bartlett (Dialect Coach), Julia Rohed* (Stage Manager), and Christopher Knarr* (Assistant Stage Manager). 

* denotes Interrobang Artistic Associate

The projected cost of this production is $15,000.00.  Your support, big or small, will help us make exciting theatre happen.


What is Interrobang Theatre Project?

Founded in 2010, Interrobang Theatre Project produces visceral, smart, substantial plays as a means to change our world one play at a time.  Interrobang is not recommended for audiences who prefer their theatre to be benign or familiar.

Interrobang Theatre Project is a 501(c) 3 tax-exempt non-profit organization, and all donations are fully tax-deductible.
