story:
Short Summary

I'm Ainsley Hillyard, a dance and theatre artist and I made a show about outer space, with my French bulldog, Jezebel. This is a huge passion project for me as it combines my love of movement, text and, well... my dog. 

Show Synopsis:

Obsessed with traveling to the past, an astronaut and her French bulldog, Jezebel, explore the universe attempting to unravel the mysteries of time travel. From distant galaxies full of nonverbal life forms, all the way to Portland, Oregon, the astronaut is desperately searching in an attempt to crack the code. A tale of adventure, heroism, mortality, and love, it is a modern day Turner and Hooch…meets Space Jam…meets Einstein’s theory of relativity.  An interweaving of text, movement, and an untrained French bulldog, each show is a new adventure.

This piece began with a two week creative process with One Yellow Rabbit’s Denise Clarke in Calgary, and questions how we interact with our animal companions, the different relationships we have with them and how much they really mean to us.

Previous performances/iterations: 

Feats Festival of Dance, Edmonton AB, July 2017.

UnoFest in Victoria BC, May 2018.

Winnipeg Fringe Festival, Winnipeg MB, July 2018.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is the first time the full length version of this piece will be performed in our home town of Edmonton and Jezebel and I are beyond excited for the production. We are hoping to raise at least $5000 for production and design fees, which will provide the adequate support for the show and the team of artists working on it!

Jezebel, at the Still Point will be running October 11-21, 2018 as part of the Roxy Performance Series presented by Their Network. They offer a multitude of support, but we still need money to help with artist and production fees!

There are some fun perks, all Jezebel oriented of course, to thank you for your contributions!

The Impact

With your support we will be able to incorporate lighting, sound and video design for the piece, which so far has existed on a very small production budget.

Your support also means that a large team of artists will be paid a fee for their work, which otherwise would be volunteered or wouldn't happen at all. There has already been so much unpaid labour on this project, as it is a huge passion and our funding has been limited.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show! Share the Facebook event and tell your friends!

story:
Who we are...

We are SQUAD Productions, a Dublin based theatre and film company dedicated to creating relatable, innovative and character driven content for an Irish audience. We have been given the opportunity to bring back the hilariously touching show HashtagRealtionshipGoalz written by Lorna Costello and directed by Emma Jane Purcell. We have been working so hard making this brilliant show bigger and even better than before. We cannot wait for you all to see it on its feet!

Why we are fundraising...

SQUAD dedicate themselves to creating innovative and interesting theatre and film. Run by young, wide-eyed, excitable people, SQUAD works hard to bring the best theatre possible to the stage and screen. Our dreams, however, have become bigger than our pockets.

Unfortunately, HashtagRelationshipGoalz is being produced with no funding. Without some backing, we will be unable to get the show on it's feet and before you, our (wonderful) audience.

By the end of this campaign, we will be using the money raised to pay for our venue, rehearsal space, lights, costumes, set and marketing campaign. Every cent raised will be used to create the world of the story and the materials needed to do so.

We understand the meaning of 'every euro counts' and every single euro donated is extremely valuable to us. Whether it is the price of a pint or the price of a castle, whatever you can donate is worth more than the world to this production.

Why should you donate?

We would really love it, if you did!

Everyone at SQUAD is very excited about this show. After performing first as part of the Smock Allies: Scene + Heard Festival, every second of this heart-breaking and heart-wrenching story took our breath away. It has been such a full-filling process and we desperately want to share it with you! By donating to this campaign you are giving us the best chance to share this beautiful story with you all.

Not only will you get to see HashtagRelationshipGoalz again - bigger and more exciting than before - you will also be giving new, dedicated and extremely talented artists a chance to put their skills to work.

DID WE ALSO MENTION THERE IS FREE STUFF?

Now I don’t know about you but, here at SQUAD, we love a freebie. By donating to this campaign there is a whole bunch of perks you can claim! From a mention in our programme to tickets, food and more. The more you donate, the better the perk!

HashtagRelationshipGoalz

Ah, young love.  Ah, really though?

Ciara is your run of the mill, chicken burger plain with nothin’ on it kinda girl.  (Garlic sauce on the side, obvo.) Ciarán is your average , curry cheese chips type of lad.  And yeah, they’ve found each other. But like yeah, bleedin’ ages ago. Ciara and Ciarán are #goalz.  Relationship goalz. So what’s left to achieve, really?

Our story takes place on the plateaux that is the ‘during’ of a relationship.  Watch our wonder couple navigate through treacherous disruptions like deciding where to eat, your stepmam being a bollocks, your best friend being a dope, getting work off for a city break, an uninspired future existence, kleptomania and deciding which boxset to watch next.

HashtagRelationshipGoalz began it's journey last year as part of the Smock Allies: Scene + Heard Festival. The sold-out performance went down incredibly with our diverse audience. It was a great show, so we decided to bring it back and make it even better.

This is SQUAD Productions 10th new play. Last year, Artistic Director Leah Moore won the best new writing award at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival with her play Wasting Paper. This also isn't writer Lorna Costello's first rodeo either.  Lorna's first show GULP opened at Scene + Heard 2016 before enjoying a packed out week at the International Bar.

Not able to donate, but want to help?

That's no problem! There are loads of way to help us out. By simply sharing this campaign or telling your friends to get the word out, you will be helping this incredible show on it's feet.

Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to catch all the details about the show. Want more information? Contact us on squadtheatrecompany@gmail.com, we would be delighted to tell you more!

 

SQUAD Productions and the HashtagRelationshipGoalz team would like to thank everyone for their donations, likes and shares during this campaign. You are our favourite people and we are incredibly grateful for your generosity!

story:
Who Are We?

We are a group of high-school students who came together last year for a summer Musical Theatre camp at Inspire Arts Academy. During the camp we wrote our own musical! We came up with the concept, characters, script, blocking, lyrics, choreography, set, and costumes (with a little help!).

Our teachers believed in us and believed in our idea. They encouraged us to workshop the idea to make a full-length musical, this time with our own original music as well. We lost some cast, found some cast, reworked, rewrote, and have come up with something we are really proud of.

All of us love performing but have been limited to our high-school theatre programs (as amazing as they are) and are craving the opportunity to see our own creation onstage. We're hard workers who are willing to pull our weight to make this happen, but we can't do it without your help.

Where Is My Donation Going?

Any and all donations will be going towards the budget of creating our show. It costs a lot of money to put up a musical, even without paying for script-rights. Our goal has been calculated as our ideal budget, but any donations received enter the production fund.

Your donations will be going towards:

  • Theatre Rental
  • Tech Rental (microphones, receivers, fog machines, special lighting, etc.)
  • Costume Materials
  • Prop Materials
  • Set Materials

What we already have:

  • Rehearsal Space (a major cost to putting on a show)
  • A Director and Musical Director mentoring us
  • Access to Fight Directors, Lighting Designers, and Stage Management
  • A strong script and actors willing to put in the work to make it show-worthy
  • A cast and volunteers willing to help with costume, set, and prop creation

If we don't make our goal, we have back-up plans to cut down our costs. But we would like to have the budget to make this the best production value we can!

We will also be doing other fundraising activities, but we know crowd-funding can be a great resource!

Why Should I?

You'll be supporting us in beginning our creative careers outside of school, as well as supporting arts in our community! There are many programs and opportunities for young children to perform theatre, as well as adults. But our demographic doesn't always have the same options available. 

There are many community theatre groups out there putting great work into the world, but we haven't found another place willing to take a chance on a bunch of kids by putting their original ideas on a stage. We don't just want to be actors, we want to be writers, creators, and well-rounded artists. You'll be helping support that.

Also...we have perks!

If you donate you will receive funny, personal, and heartfelt thanks from us in the form of some quirky gifts that match the tone of our quirky, meta, comedy!

 

In Conclusion

Helping us put on this show is helping young artists get their foot in the door.

If you can't donate yourself, please help us by spreading word about our campaign!

story:
What is Paradise Road?

Paradise Road is James Stone’s first completely original long-form play. It began life as “Same Difference” and the first scene was featured in Bites & Scratches at The Park Theatre, Finsbury Park, in July 2016. (Bites and Scratches is a regular new writing event staged by Fine Mess Theatre Company).

The script was completed in December 2016 and will premier in a professional production by Tales Retold, in April 2018, at Sheffield Library Theatre,

 

Who is James Stone?

James has been a professional writer and director for nearly twenty years, with experience in radio advertising, corporate creative writing, novel adaptations, scripting for musicals and original plays. 

 

Who are Tales Retold?

Tales Retold is a London-based production company, set up in 2009, which has produced high quality theatre in London, Edinburgh and Brighton, as well as co-producing a TV comedy pilot, Cold Callers.

 

Why fund Paradise Road?

We are very excited about premiering the play in the writer's home town of Sheffield.  It is important to us because it is a unique story about the challenges of taking asylum seekers into your home.

By helping us today you will not only assist us in showing the piece to over 500 people but you will be enabling the development of a very important story. We would like to tour the show once we have premiered it.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The money you donate will help us to cover the following costs:

Actor and Creative salaries.

Creative materials to build the set and props.

Marketing- flyers and posters.

 

The Impact of your generosity

Your contribution to our project will make such a difference to:

  • Analysing and discussing our concept of the world and Western/ Eastern traditions.
  • Tales Retold has has success with crowdfunding campaigns for (Antigone at the Hope Theatre).
  • Discussing issues which can sometimes be taboo subjects
  • Raising awareness of local Refugee charities like Assist.

 

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a show can be challenging and raising the money is always the tricky part.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you cannot contribute financially. If you would like to help raise awareness of our project we suggest the following ways you can:

  • Share this campaign on facebook, twitter, Instagram or by email and help us make some noise. If you can tag @talesretold and @paradiseroadplay.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for taking time to read our campaign.

The Impact of your generosity

Your contribution to our project will make such a difference to:

Analysing and discussing our concept of the world and Western/ Eastern traditions.
Tales Retold has has success with crowdfunding campaigns for (Antigone at the Hope Theatre).
Discussing issues which can sometimes be taboo subjects
Raising awareness of local Refugee charities like Assist.


 
Risks & Challenges
Putting on a show can be challenging and raising the money is always the tricky part.
 
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you cannot contribute financially. If you would like to help raise awareness of our project we suggest the following ways you can:

Share this campaign on facebook, twitter, Instagram or by email and help us make some noise. If you can tag @talesretold and @paradiseroadplay.
You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for taking time to read our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Elli Scharlin and I'm a senior at Wesleyan University.

  • Lost and Found is a fun, vulgar, fantastical, but most importantly, relevant coming of age story.

  • This musical is somewhere between Avenue Q, Into the Woods and The Wizard of Oz.

  • By reaching the campaign goal, I will be able to purchase the tools needed to bring a new dimension to my final Wesleyan hoorah (lights, props, costumes, etc...)

The Impact

  • Lost and Found explores the struggles of a dangerous species: Teenage Girls. It also does another thing, it redeems them...Girls need a show like this (and so do their parents).

  • This show allows for sexuality to be a positive and present aspect which is a more realistic approach to a coming of age story. 

  • Lost and Found follows Spencer Maude through a fantastical journey to reclaim her virginity. Along the journey, the audience engages with topics such as consensuality, loss, and family dynamics (I would want my teenager self to have seen this show).

Risks & Challenges

  • I am still looking for a performance space on Wesleyan's Campus that will fit the needs of the show.

  • We are currently in discussion with multiple on-campus venues to host our production.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Click on the links to spread the word about this project that means so much to me and my team! 

  • Feel free to listen to any of the samples that have been posted!

 

 

 

Keep reading for a quick peek into the cast and crew of Lost and Found!

story:
Our Production - Gutenburg: The Musical

Chris Adams presents Gutenberg! The Musical! by Anthony King and Scott Brown. Adams, a UVIC grad, has performed in some of the greatest theatres across Canada including The Globe in Regina, The Centaur in Montreal, and Vertigo in Calgary. Erik Gow is a Studio 58 graduate who works as a performer/teacher/multi-instrumentalist with such companies as The Arts Club, Gateway Theatre, TUTS, Chemainus Theatre Festival, Axis Theatre, and many more.  This professional dynamic duo has come together under the guidance of Axis Theatre’s Chris McGregor to present this two-man spoof, ahem, ode to Broadway.

In this whirlwind 90 minute musical comedy, Chris and Erik play over 30 characters. A pair of aspiring playwrights perform a backers’ audition for their new project - a big, splashy musical about printing press inventor Johann Gutenberg. With an unending supply of enthusiasm, Bud and Doug sing all the songs and play all the parts in their crass not-so-historically-accurate epic musical, with the hope that one of the producers in attendance will take them to Broadway – fulfilling their ill-advised dreams.

The Fringe Festival provides a valuable opportunity for professional artists to come together as collectives and produce work they are excited about, and on on much smaller budget than usual. Of course, there are still basic costs we need to cover — pianos to play, props to toss around, hats, hats, and hats! — not to mention finding room in the budget to compensate the artists for their time and talents. We believe art can pay in more than exposure or experience, and to that end we need you help!

Let’s Crunch the Numbers

Here's the basic equation we’re working with:

Figure 1. Production Costs — $6000.00

Our biggest budget items include the show rights ($2400), venue ($800), and fringe fees ($500). They do not include paying anyone on the creative team — under usual equity contracts, our artists fees would be higher than our entire production budget for this show. Fringe makes it possible to do this show without that money, but of course, it also means… we’re doing it without that money. 

Instead, the project is running as a profit share — anything we make on the show is divided among the artists as compensation for their time and talents in mounting the show. An excellent idea until we look at our next figure.

Figure 2. Potential Ticket Revenue — $4800.00

You see the challenge. Even with all contributors working for free, the production operates at a loss. We are asking for your sponsorship to help us balance this equation, and to help us put the profit back in profit share.

Your End of the Equation

We are really excited about what you’ll find on your end of the equation. With perks ranging from our endless gratitude and the critical title of “Headgear Hero” to the possibility of joining Erik and Chris on stage for your moment in the spotlight, we’re hoping there’s something to inspire everyone. 

Why Gutenburg?

With over 30 characters between two performers, this show makes the most of our dynamic performers’ physical and vocal talents, and their ability to transform from one person to the next. It can be difficult to stage in such a way that keeps the story and the characters crisp and clear. When you nail it, however, you are rewarded with a show that is witty and highly hilarious, and carries the audience through a roller coaster of roles and personas. 

Gutenberg: The Musical suits the Fringe to a tee! It’s simple — just two guys and a box of hats. It’s engaging — its play-within-a-play narrative placing the audience right in the room with the characters, a real and present part of their world. And finally, when you get down to it, it’s about two artists determined to find a venue for their artistic dreams — hey, what’s the Fringe for?

We Know It Won’t Be Easy

We’ve got out work cut out for us. There are upwards of 80 other shows going up at the Vancouver Fringe this year, so there will be lots of amazing work for audiences to choose from. Being seen and heard is a challenge, but we are determined to stand out and fill our audience each night! 

Luckily, we’ve got a passionate team of experienced performers and problems solvers on board. Gutenberg! The Muscial! marks the 11th musical Chris Adams has produced over the past 5 years, and he knows a thing or two about producing quality work on a tight budget. 

Finding audiences isn’t the only challenge — a two-hand 90 minute show requires some serious stamina to execute! Erik and Chris are more than up to the challenge, having worked together before, as well as with their director Chris McGregor. This team is tried and true!

We have the plan! The pieces are in place! Now we need your support!

 

Help Spread the Word!

When Johann Gutenberg invented the printing press, it revolutionized the spread of information, making it possible for people to share their thoughts, feelings, and opinions far and wide. 

In 2017 we all have this ability in our pockets, we invite you to say thanks to Mr. Gutenberg by getting on social media and spreading the word about the show and our campaign. 

Whether or not you’re able to become a sponsor, your support is incredibly valuable!

Thank you!

story:
who i am

I am an actor, playwright, screenwriter, director, and producer. I've studied, trained with, and performed at some of the best theatre companies and classical ensembles in the country, including Shakespeare & Co., Pig Iron Theatre, The Antaeus Company, and A Noise Within. Romeo and Juliet is a play I've lived with, like most of us, for a very long time, and have even performed in twice: as Balthasar at the Illinois Shakespeare Festival when I was training as an actor at Illinois State University, and as Benvolio at A Noise Within, here in Los Angeles.

I have a deep, staggering love for this play, and feel that its power sometimes gets lost in period costumes, or the size of large Shakespeare festivals around the country, and by stripping a lot of that away, and bringing the actors and the audience closer in an intimate black box theater space, and working with actors and specific music, my vision will create something very raw, immediate, visceral, and an experience with the play audiences have never had before.

your guiding hands

Your contribution will make it possible to have the time, space, and resources to be able to find the heart and soul of this extraordinary play, and give the actors freedom to express the truth of themselves through these characters and Shakespeare's stunning language.

Our budget includes:

Theater rental plus the insurance fee for 5 performances at the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2018: $1275.00
Hollywood Fringe Festival registration fee: $250
Hollywood Fringe Festival advertising (Fringe guide/website): $300
80 hours (4 weeks/20 hours weekly) rehearsal space rental @ 25/hour: $2000
8 actors @ $100: $800
Festival Stage manager, 12 hours @ $30/hourly for tech/performances: $360
= $4, 985.
Anything over our modest budget of $5000 will go towards props, costumes, sound, and a higher wage for the ensemble of actors.

the gift of giving

Morley is one of Los Angeles' most loved and sought-after street artists, and he has created a huge following in the city for his poignant, funny, and meaningful posters and installations:

"Morley’s work can feel like love notes, private jokes, public secrets or a last testament. He provides a cool tonic for the heat and isolation of Los Angeles. "

- Frank Warren (Founder of PostSecret)

Morley has generously created truly unique, one-of-a-kind artwork for images, posters, and other Romeo and Juliet memorabilia exclusively for our generous contributors; in addition to this incredible artwork, for those willing to go above and beyond with their contributions, we will be giving all-inclusive, discovery access to material used for the production: our world-premiere adaptation of Shakespeare's script of Romeo and Juliet, a private link to footage and photo stills of our live performance & behind-the-scenes of the rehearsal and production process, as well as a curated playlist of music used for our soundtrack, an invitation to join cast and crew at our opening night after party, tickets to the show, and much more. 

did my heart love till now?

Shakespeare's play is one of rage, grief, boundless love, and the profound mistakes we make when lost in hatred and retaliation and separateness, and now, more than any other time in my life, this play resonates in profound ways, and I want to create a deep, meaningful, immediate, visceral, and true experience for the artists and audiences.

The process of creating theatre, and producing it in a commercial landscape is a huge challenge, but I believe it is a necessary thing for people to come together and experience our bodies, voices, breath, and emotions in an intimate space, making alive what Shakespeare wrote over 400 years ago; and even though it is a tragic love story, bringing joy and life and hope to the telling of it, and continue in the lineage of actors throughout the centuries who have devoted their lives to giving Shakespeare's gift to audiences who join us in that sacred space.

my bounty is as boundless as the sea

Join us, if you will, and even if a financial contribution isn't something you can do, spread the word through e-mails, share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and any other platform. The generosity of your word is so important, and it means the world to us that you will be advocating for a group of artists who are gathering together to create something beautiful for everyone who is able to join us at the Hollywood Fringe Festival this summer and beyond. 

Thank you!!

story:
Puss in Cahoots –Mess Up The Mess Christmas Show

Be part of creating this year’s alternative take on a traditional Christmas Show!

The Show

12th-14th December

Puss in Cahoots

Ammanford Miners Theatre

Devised by Mess Up The Mess and Katy Owen

The actors are waiting for you in a community centre somewhere that smells of bolognese and hamster. They have been turning up (mostly) on time since September, covered in tinsel, candied fruit and humming a merry verse of 'Deck The Halls'. They are ready to entertain you and they are going to try their festive best...(However  Kylie's on the wrong bus heading for the Mumbles and Tyler's had to go back to his Nan's because she can't find her back door key.)

Still the show must go on and somehow it will....

Mess Up The Mess present 'Puss In Cahoots'. A Pantomime filled with family entertainment, songs, slapstick, dancing, the well-loved tradition of cross dressing and props made out of our own skin...joke! That was a joke....oh and there's plenty of those too! Come along this Christmas (we might need you to step in for Kylie!)

Who’s involved?

Mess Up The Mess Theatre Company creates theatre with, for and by young people. This community production involves over 50 young people aged 11-25 who take part in professionally led weekly drama workshops. The inclusive workshops enable young people to be mentored in all areas of the performing arts including devising, writing, acting, singing, movement, technical theatre and performing. Young people will be involved in every element of Puss in Cahoots from developing the characters to lighting the show.

Mess Up The Mess is working alongside Star Quest, a local children’s performing arts group led by Debbie Elias, and local youth dance group Statik, led by her daughter Abbie Elias, to enable up to another 50 children and young people to take part in what has fast become a popular entertainment fixture on the local festive calendar!

Why we need your funding?

No matter what happens Puss in Cahoots is going to be a hugely entertaining and high quality production. We have an incredibly talented young cast and crew supported by amazing youth arts workers who are putting all their energy into crafting this show for you.

With your help we can make Puss in Cahoots even more side splittingly funny. Even shinier. And even fuller of festive sounds to fill you with Christmas cheer well into the New Year!

Make some Christmas dreams come true. Donate to Puss in Cahoots and you will help create an even more memorable experience for the performers and audience alike!

story:
“Da-Doo:" Help Us Get Audrey II

Help the cast of Little Shop of Horrors rent Audrey II.

Nine high school and middle school students in Morgantown have been hard at work the past few weeks rehearsing for Morgantown Theatre Company’s (MTC) production of Little Shop of Horrors. Rehearsals have been going splendidly as these enthusiastic and talented students dive into character work, accents, choreography, three part harmony, stage fighting,and much more. 


However,something is missing...  THE PLANT!  

The Plant, Audrey II, is a crucial character in this award-winning Broadway musical.

In Little Shop of Horrors,  a florist (Seymour) finds an amazing new species of plant. Little does he know, the plant (Audrey II) is actually an alien species determined to take over the world! The sprout Audrey II convinces Seymour to feed it blood, and eventually people, to make it grow.  In return, all sorts of wonderful things start happening to Seymour.

Audrey II is a series of four puppets, ranging from a small sprout to a gigantic, man-eating alien plant.  Audrey II is played by a puppeteer who manipulates the puppet and an actor who provides the voice of the sassy plant who talks and sings to Seymour, frequently asking him to…

“FEED ME!”  This is how you can help FEED OUR PLANT!


We are asking the Morgantown community, family and friends of MTC, theatre lovers, and supporters of children and the arts to help MTC and the cast raise money to rent the plants.

Our Goal is to raise $3,000 November 30, 2014. 

Morgantown Theatre Company, a non-profit 501(c) 3 organization, provides theatre arts education for children of all ages. Programs range from once a week drama classes to full scale productions performed at the Metropolitan Theatre on High Street. However, these high quality shows also have high production costs such as rights and licensing, costumes, advertising, and set. In addition to these costs, Little Shop of Horrors  also has the added expense of the Audrey II plants!


How can you help FEED OUR PLANT!

You can help us rent Audrey II by donating to our project, “Da-Doo:" Help Us Get Audrey II. Click the contribute now button in the top right corner.

Finally, we also invite you to come to the show!  Performances are October 24th and 25th at 7:30 p.m., and October 26th at 3:30 p.m. All performances are in the Metropolitan Theatre at 369 High Street, Morgantown WV. 

Tickets: Adult $10; Child $8


For more information and tickets please visit www.morgantowntheatrecompany.org.
story_txt:
“Da-Doo:"
Help Us Get Audrey II 
Help
the cast of Little
Shop of Horrors rent
Audrey II. 

Nine high school and middle school students in Morgantown have been hard at work the past
few weeks rehearsing for Morgantown Theatre Company’s (MTC)
production of Little
Shop of Horrors.
Rehearsals have been going splendidly as these enthusiastic and
talented students dive into character work, accents, choreography,
three part harmony, stage fighting,and
much more.  
However,something
is missing...  THE PLANT!
 
The
Plant, Audrey II, is a crucial character in this award-winning Broadway musical. 

In
Little
Shop of Horrors,
 a florist (Seymour) finds an amazing new species of plant.
Little does he know, the plant (Audrey II) is actually an alien
species determined to take over the world! The sprout Audrey II
convinces Seymour to feed it blood,
and
eventually people,
to
make it grow.  In
return, all sorts of wonderful things start happening to Seymour. 

Audrey
II is a series of
four puppets, ranging from a small sprout to a gigantic, man-eating
alien plant.  Audrey II is played by a puppeteer who manipulates
the puppet and an actor who provides the voice of the sassy plant who
talks and sings to Seymour,
frequently
asking him to…
“FEED
ME!”  This is how you can help FEED OUR PLANT!

We
are asking the Morgantown community, family and friends of MTC,
theatre lovers, and supporters of children and the arts to help MTC
and the cast raise money to rent the plants. 


Our
Goal is to raise $3,000 November 30, 2014.  

Morgantown
Theatre Company, a non-profit 501(c) 3 organization, provides theatre
arts education for children of all ages. Programs range from once a
week drama classes to full scale productions performed at the
Metropolitan Theatre on High Street. However, these high quality
shows also have high production costs such as rights and licensing,
costumes, advertising, and set. In addition to these costs, Little
Shop of Horrors  also
has the added expense of the Audrey II plants! 


How
can you help FEED OUR PLANT!
You
can help us rent Audrey II by donating to our project, “Da-Doo:"
Help Us Get Audrey II. Click the contribute now button in the top right corner. 

Finally,
we also invite you to come to the show!  Performances are
October 24th and 25th at 7:30 p.m., and October 26th at 3:30 p.m. All
performances are in the Metropolitan Theatre at 369 High Street,
Morgantown WV.  Tickets: Adult $10; Child $8
For
more information and tickets please visit www.morgantowntheatrecompany.org.

story:
The Bring a Weasel + a Pint of Yr Own Blood Festival

Each year, three writers adapt a shared well of source material. The results are mounted in a full production at CSC in NYC.

This year's writers -- John Budge, Zarina Shea, and Heloise Wilson -- are adapting Gorky's Reminiscences of Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Andreev.

Strange and wonderful things happen in the Brooklyn College Playwriting MFA program, led by Mac Wellman and Erin Courtney. Even the yellow-bellied journalist-types think so... http://nyti.ms/1Edz01w

There are three ways you can support our project!

1. Donate! Straight up donate. Here.

2. Come to our party! June 3, 6-10 pm. Juke Bar. East Village.

We'll have performances throughout the evening.

$25 gets you in + a drink ticket. Donate $25 here and select "Party!" as your perk, and we'll put your name on the guest list. 

3. Check out our silent auction!

http://www.32auctions.com/weaselfest

Tickets to plays, writing space memberships, a hoodie from the Beijing Central Academy of Drama... crazy good stuff. 

(drawing by Erin Courtney)

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Fear No Colours is a Glasgow based non-profit theatre company with a focus on visceral and bold productions of contemporary plays. We made our debut last year with Cleansed and Phaedra’s Love by Sarah Kane at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe where we received amazing reviews and nominations, performing for a much larger audience than expected! This season we are diving into the terrifying and beautiful work of Philip Ridley, and once more aiming for Edinburgh!

WHY EDINBURGH, YOU ASK?

The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the largest performance arts festival in the world, with over 3000 shows hitting the Scottish capital every August. For emerging artists such as ourselves, Edinburgh is the ‘holy grail’, and an amazing opportunity to show work to a large audience, while also being inspired by and learning from countless other brilliant artists, gaining invaluable experience and networking with industry professionals.

WHY ARE WE ASKING YOU FOR MONEY?

Edinburgh is a fantastic opportunity, but also very expensive. Fear No Colours is a non-profit company, meaning we do not have the resources to pay any of our artists, make a living from our work or even cover our expenses. Instead, we need to raise money to pay for a platform to do our work on. We're creating two mind-blowing shows that we're super proud of and know can do really well at the festival, and when there's no public funds to help us get there, we're hoping that you will! Last year, three of our actors got paid, professional acting jobs from 'being discovered' in FNC shows, and we really want to create more opportunities like that for our team.

We want our fundraising campaign to be fun - we take our work so seriously that we need to let loose on the side and we would love for our friends and supporters to join us in the good times! We're a company bursting with creative energy - musicians, poets, writers, comedians and artists - and we think you should get something original and personal reflecting this in return for your contribution!

SO...WHAT'S ALL THIS MONEY GOING TO BUY?

Venue hire, royalties to the playwright, a place to live for the team while we're in Edinburgh, PR material (posters and flyers), props, costumes and quite a lot of stage blood. Although we've made every effort to save money wherever possible, there's still quite a lot of essentials left on our list.

WHAT ARE THE SHOWS ABOUT?

Mercury Fur

In the burning and blood soaked ruins of London, brothers Elliot and Darren are preparing a party for a wealthy client. Besides drinks and snacks, their guest requests a ten year old boy and a sharp meat hook. Of course the customer is always right. Let the party begin!

One of the most controversial and harrowing plays of our time, Mercury Fur continues to push boundaries, separate audiences and spark debate. Philip Ridley’s savage masterpiece asks how far we will go for the ones we love and if there ever is a pain too great to bear.


Dark Vanilla Jungle

Andrea wants a family. She wants to belong, to be loved. She wants it so much that she is prepared to do the unthinkable. Nobody really knows what happened that night in Epping Forest, what happened to the baby. Witchcraft? The press must have got all that wrong, surely. She is ready to tell the truth now. If only you will listen.​

Philip Ridley's stunning monologue is a tale of abuse, pain, loneliness and the greatest love anyone ever knew. Brutally human and intensely passionate, Fear No Colours’ intimate production brings the text closer than ever before.


WHAT THE PRESS SAID LAST TIME

‘The acting is first rate, while the choreography manages to combine beauty with a degree of meaning ... Fear No Colours are well worth following in the future’  **** British Theatre Guide

‘A brave and brutal performance ... plays with your emotion and tugs at your heart.’ **** The Reviews Hub

‘This splendid production by Fear No Colours is an admirable tour de force.’ **** The List

‘Midtgard’s direction shines ... this show has to be seen ... simply a staggering and barbaric piece of theatre.’ ***** Edfringe Review

‘Your instinct is to look away but it's so visually stunning, you can't help but watch ... a truly visceral and powerful ensemble piece of work. ‘**** Theatreview

‘This is visceral drama at its most haunting ... the quality of the acting and direction make this a must see play.’ **** DarkChat

Cleansed was nominated in five categories for the 2015 DarkChat awards: Best Play, Best Male Actor (Raymond Wilson), Best Female Actor (Siofra Dromgoole), Best Supporting Male Actor (Sam Skoog) and Best Director.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We are overwhelmed by the amazing support we have received already, and if you would like to help us out in other ways, help spreading the word, coming to our fundraiser events or just sending us some encouraging words goes a long way! You can follow us on facebook and twitter to keep up with our news and events, and there is also more info to be found on our website www.fearnocolours.com

OUR TEAM

Julia Midtgard – Director

Julia is a Norwegian theatre director educated at the University of Glasgow with a degree in Theatre Studies, and currently undertakes a postgraduate degree in Playwriting and Dramaturgy. Besides directing Cleansed and Phaedra’s Love last year, she also directed an excerpt from David Greig’s Brewers Fayre at Playwright’s Studio Scotland’s event ‘Crossing the Lines’ at the Arches in Glasgow.

Raymond Wilson – actor and co-producer

Raymond is a native Glaswegian actor who is actively involved in various short-film, theatre and voice-acting productions in and around the area. Most recently he has appeared as Macduff in STaG's Macbeth, as well as in BBC's long-running seriesHome Front. Raymond is back for his second season with FNC after performing as Robin in last year’s production of Cleansed and is excited to be back in the rehearsal room for our upcoming season.

Raymond plays Elliot in Mercury Fur

Aea Varfis-van Warmelo – actor

Edinburgh-born but raised in Greece and French-educated, Aea is a trilingual actor currently studying at the University of Glasgow. She is a member of the National Youth Theatre, having trained in their Epic Stages course and performed in their immersive production Viral. This is her second season with Fear No Colours and she is very excited to perform with us again.

Aea plays Andrea in Dark Vanilla Jungle and Party Piece in Mercury Fur

Sam Skoog – actor

Sam is a London-born, New Zealand-raised actor and physical performer. Around the time of his leaving Wellington College, he performed with home-grown devising company Patacake Productions, and for Pan Pan Theatre in their touring production of The Rehearsal; Playing the Dane for its Wellington run. He was also a member of Long Cloud Youth Theatre, a training and performing group that worked throughout Wellington theatres. After finishing high school, Sam moved back to the UK, where he took part in workshop courses with RADA and Central School of Speech and Drama before beginning his degree at The University of Glasgow. He has worked as an administrator and performer for Student Theatre at Glasgow, with past roles including Demetrius in A Midsummer Night’s Dream and the title role inMacbeth. For Fear No Colours’ 2015 Edinburgh Festival Fringe season Sam performed as Carl in Cleansed, as well as Doctor and Vulture in Phaedra’s Love.

Sam plays Spinx in Mercury Fur

Robert Turner – actor

Robert Turner is an actor and musician currently based in Glasgow. Raised in the south east of England, he was first introduced to acting at A-level and is now studying Theatre along with English Literature at Glasgow University. He has become heavily involved with STAG (student theatre at Glasgow) performing in a diverse range of student-written plays. Also a dedicated musician, he has busked and played at many venues in and around the south east and is currently exploring the Glasgow music scene. Robert is excited to gain further acting experience and looks forward to working with FNC.

Robert plays Naz in Mercury Fur

Tom White – actor


Tom is a Glasgow-based actor in his first season with Fear No Colours. He was previously a member of The Drama Studio Edinburgh and has performed in the Touring Consortium’s production of To Sir, With Love with Matthew Kelly. Tom has been extensively involved with STaG (Student Theatre at Glasgow), performing in a variety of student-written plays and as Lysander in A Midsummer Night’s Dream. Most recently, he performed as Gus in Pinter’s The Dumb Waiter with Broken Mirror Theatre.

Tom plays Lola in Mercury Fur

Siofra Dromgoole – actor

Siofra Ivy Jessica Dromgoole, born in London, is in her second year at the University of Glasgow, studying English literature. At a young age she was part of a Globe touring production of A Winter's Tale, and was a part of The Tricycle and Arcola youth theatre companies. Her first role after numerous high school parts was Grace in Cleansed for FNC last season, and she also performed as Strophe in Phaedra’s Love.

Siofra plays Duchess in Mercury Fur

William Watt – actor

William has performed in a few dozen plays in Edinburgh and Glasgow, having had the good fortune to play Stanley Kowalski in A Streetcar Named Desire, Steerpike inGormenghast and Claudio in Much Ado About Nothing, amongst others. Aside from playing what, on reflection, can only be described as an ‘ouvre of bastards’ he's also had a good deal of experience with stand-up and sketch comedy, directed a production of Coriolanus and been part of the touring folk tale based show Stranger Walks Into A Bar at the Tron Theatre and Scottish Storytelling Centre. William is delighted to be a part of this Fear No Colours production and very appreciative of the welcome he's been given, and would also like to thank his character for retroactively justifying all the partying he's done over the years as ‘research’.

William plays Party Guest in Mercury Fur

Callum Partridge – actor

Callum is born in London, but raised internationally, having moved country every four years since he was born. He has performed in various amateur and semi-professional productions, both as a musician and an actor, in London and Oxford before moving to Glasgow. For Fear No Colours’ 2015 season, Callum performed as Rod in Cleansed and Hippolytus in Phaedra’s Love at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, as well as Anthony in Brewers Fayre at the Arches in Glasgow as part of Playwrights’ Studio Scotland’s event ‘Crossing the Lines’. He has also worked with Playwrights’ Studio as an actor for their young writers workshop programme.

Callum plays Darren in Mercury Fur


Laila Burāne – costume designer

Laila Burāne is a Latvian costume designer and theatre maker, currently based in Glasgow where she undertakes a postgraduate degree in Playwriting and Dramaturgy. Previous costume credits include Sarah Kane (dir. Mārtiņš Eihe, Creative Association Nomadi, Latvia, 2011), Titus (dir. Bryan Reynolds, Transversal Theater Company in collaboration with University College Utrecht, Netherlands, 2012), Railroad (dir. Bryan Reynolds, European Polytheatre: Cultural Expression and Awareness Laboratory, Sweden, 2013), Bzzap! (dir. Bryan Reynolds, Transversal Theatre Company, Netherlands, 2014). Previous credits as assistant director and dramaturg include Road Map in the Meat Pavilion (dir. Krista Burāne, Creative Association Nomadi and The New Theatre Institute in Latvia, Latvia, 2014),The Reading Room (dir. Mārtiņš Eihe, The New Theatre Institute in Latvia, Latvia, 2015).


Sean Byrne – stage combat instructor

story:
About Leviathan Lab

Founded in 2009, Leviathan Lab is a professional creative studio that invests in the advancement of Asian American performing artists. Leviathan was founded with the goal of expanding the reach of Asian American artistic voices and telling our stories to communities who haven't yet heard nor had the joy of experiencing them. Our projects – online, on film, and on stage – strive to show Asian Americans in innovative and dynamic ways: sexy, powerful, vital, and fun. 

Theatre and film production in New York City is an expensive endeavor, and your help is essential in helping us do this important work. Your contribution will help us secure:

  • Rehearsal rooms and performance venues
  • Performer and technical artist fees
  • Production, venue, and, rehearsal insurance
  • Production costs, including costumes, sets, lights, and publicity

Your contribution is tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law, and will help to jump start our fundraising efforts for our 2014-2015 project roster, which includes:

  • Ghost Stories Reading Series: Three Original Short Musicals Inspired by Asian Ghost Stories
    Friday, November 21 at 7:30 p.m.
    Saturday, November 22 at 5:00 p.m.
    University Settlement Speyer Hall
    184 Eldridge Street
    $10 admission includes wine and     snacks

    Click here for tickets via Brown Paper Tickets!

    Leviathan Lab, in collaboration with     The Performance Project @ University Settlement is proud to present GHOST STORIES.         GHOST STORIES is our first project in our New Musicals Initiative, curated by lyricist/librettist Robert Lee (Heading East, Takeaway) and directed by Tony Award-winner BD Wong (M.Butterfly, Jurassic World), featuring work by emerging Asian American composers and lyricists. The evening will include Lobsters Live Forever by Sam Chanse & Bob Kelly, The Puzzling Disappearance of Yinxing Villa by Yan Li & Jason Purdy, and Untitled by Katie Baldwin Eng and Jeff Tang.

    GHOST STORIES is made possible in part with public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.
  • #TellYourStory: A Social Media Workshop with @sree
    Friday, December 5th
    Uris Center for Education, North Classroom
    1000 5th Avenue (enter at 81st Street)
    5:30 p.m. Wine Social & Networking
    6:00 p.m. Workshop
    FREE!

    Leviathan Lab, in collaboration with our friends in the new fellow Asian American led performance group     Hypokrit Theatre Company, will present a free social media workshop for intermediate and advanced users of social media for small businesses and not-for-profit arts organizations led by Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Sree joined the Met after spending 20+ years at Columbia University as  full-time professor at Columbia Journalism School and a year as the university's first Chief Digital Officer. In 2009, he was named one of AdAge's 25 media people to follow on Twitter; in 2010 was named one of Poynter's 35 most influential people in social media; and in 2014, was named one of the most influential Chief Digital Officers by CDO Club. Sree, and his work at the Met, was recently featured in the New York Times.
  • The After School Playmaking Project at P.S. 124
    2015 will mark the second year of our Applied Theatre Initiative bringing this terrific after-school playwriting program to the 5th grade students of P.S. 124-Yung Wing School. Taught by Leviathan's Applied Theatre Initiative Directors Lydia Gaston and Claro De Los Reyes, with playwright advisor Kristine M. Reyes (2014-2015 Dramatists Guild Fellow), the student's plays will be rehearsed and performed by the grown-up artists of Leviathan Lab in late April and early December 2015. Click here to to see photos on our website of our 2013 performances!
Thanks in advance for your generous contribution, and we can't wait to share our projects with you!
Leviathan Lab is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Leviathan Lab must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute now, please consider helping Leviathan out in other ways:

  • Please get the word out about our campaign
  • You can use IndieGoGo's nifty share tools to get the word out via social media
story_txt:
About Leviathan Lab 

Founded in 2009, Leviathan Lab is a professional creative studio that invests in the advancement of Asian American performing artists. Leviathan was founded with the goal of expanding the reach of Asian American artistic voices and telling our stories to communities who haven't yet heard nor had the joy of experiencing them. Our projects – online, on film, and on stage – strive to show Asian Americans in innovative and dynamic ways: sexy, powerful, vital, and fun. Theatre and film production in New York City is an expensive endeavor, and your help is essential in helping us do this important work. Your contribution will help us secure:
Rehearsal rooms and performance venues
Performer and technical artist fees
Production, venue, and, rehearsal insurance
Production costs, including costumes, sets, lights, and publicity
Your contribution is tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law, and will help to jump start our fundraising efforts for our 2014-2015 project roster, which includes:


Ghost Stories Reading Series: Three Original Short Musicals Inspired by Asian Ghost StoriesFriday, November 21 at 7:30 p.m.Saturday, November 22 at 5:00 p.m.University Settlement Speyer Hall184 Eldridge Street$10 admission includes wine and snacksClick here for tickets via Brown Paper Tickets!Leviathan Lab, in collaboration with The Performance Project @ University Settlement is proud to present GHOST STORIES. GHOST STORIES is our first project in our New Musicals Initiative, curated by lyricist/librettist Robert Lee (Heading East, Takeaway) and directed by Tony Award-winner BD Wong (M.Butterfly, Jurassic World), featuring work by emerging Asian American composers and lyricists. The evening will include Lobsters Live Forever by Sam Chanse & Bob Kelly, The Puzzling Disappearance of Yinxing Villa by Yan Li & Jason Purdy, and Untitled by Katie Baldwin Eng and Jeff Tang. GHOST STORIES is made possible in part with public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.




#TellYourStory: A Social Media Workshop with @sreeFriday, December 5thUris Center for Education, North Classroom1000 5th Avenue (enter at 81st Street)5:30 p.m. Wine Social & Networking6:00 p.m. WorkshopFREE!Leviathan Lab, in collaboration with our friends in the new fellow Asian American led performance group Hypokrit Theatre Company, will present a free social media workshop for intermediate and advanced users of social media for small businesses and not-for-profit arts organizations led by Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Sree joined the Met after spending 20+ years at Columbia University as  full-time professor at Columbia Journalism School and a year as the university's first Chief Digital Officer. In 2009, he was named one of AdAge's 25 media people to follow on Twitter; in 2010 was named one of Poynter's 35 most influential people in social media; and in 2014, was named one of the most influential Chief Digital Officers by CDO Club. Sree, and his work at the Met, was recently featured in the New York Times.




The After School Playmaking Project at P.S. 1242015 will mark the second year of our Applied Theatre Initiative bringing this terrific after-school playwriting program to the 5th grade students of P.S. 124-Yung Wing School. Taught by Leviathan's Applied Theatre Initiative Directors Lydia Gaston and Claro De Los Reyes, with playwright advisor Kristine M. Reyes (2014-2015 Dramatists Guild Fellow), the student's plays will be rehearsed and performed by the grown-up artists of Leviathan Lab in late April and early December 2015. Click here to to see photos on our website of our 2013 performances!


Thanks in advance for your generous contribution, and we can't wait to share our projects with you!Leviathan Lab is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Leviathan Lab must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Please get the word out about our campaign You can use IndieGoGo's nifty share tools to get the word out via social media

story:
"Reaching the Dream"

This campaign is to help my daughter follow her dream. Jaylene is a 13yr old beautiful young girl who is dedicated and talented. She has been selected by an official showcase Talent scout to be showcased at Hollywood Showcase. 

This is an opportunity to sponsor a model or talent to be showcased at Hollywood Showcase, which takes place in January 15th, 2015- January 18, 2015, at The Millennium Biltmore Hotel, Los Angeles California.  

Major modeling and talent agencies will see the models and talent that are selected to be showcased at this event from the United States as well as Europe and Asia.  The discovery of many of the models and talent working in todays market were found at Hollywood showcase!

 Dear Potential Sponsors:

SHOWCASE INCLUDES:

- REGISTRATION FEES AND SHOWCASE BADGE

- ENROLLMENT IN 5 OFFICIAL SHOWCASE AUDITIONS

- SHOWCASE SEMINARS/ WORKSHOPS ADMITTANCE: EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE WITH TOP NAMES OF FASHION, ACTING AND TALENT.

-PERSONAL COUNCELING AND REPRESENTATION DURING SHOWCASE

-MANAGEMENT & MARKETING SERVICES DURING AND AFTER THE SHOWCASE

- WORKSHOPS FOR INTERVIEW, AUDITION AND "GO-SEE" DAY

Sponsors can donate what you wish too.  Those donating $100 dollars or more  will be listed in the Official Hollywood Showcase Directory, which is given to all participants and their families, agents, managers, casting directors and industry executives attending the event.  This is a great advertising opportunity for you and  may be tax deductible as an advertising expense.

    As a proud mother who has paved the way for my daughter's interest I believe in her talent and her potential to become something bigger.  So with your support and response to this campaign you can be a part of her success. I promise you that when Jaylene is up on stage receiving her awards she will not forget all of you  who has helped made this happen.

    Please accept our sincerest gratitude for helping Jaylene achieve her highest goals in the entertainment business.

    Thank You

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I know some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Get the word out on "Reaching the Dream" campaign and help me help Jaylene make some noise about her campaign.
    • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who are we?

My name is Bob Prescott, and I am a senior Theatrical Studies major at Ball State University. For the past 3 years, I have been a board member of Busted Space Theatre Company. This past school year, Busted Space has grown immensely. In addition to our normal mainstays, we have, for the first time in our short history, a season! The next event we have coming up in our season is the full production of Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play by Anne Washburn.

Mr. Burns is a play that deals with the question of what we're left with after a disaster. Following a large-scale, possibly global, nuclear meltdown, the world is left without power. Without electricity, the world is forced to live off the essentials. But what then? You have to be entertained. And what's better entertainment than The Simpsons? The group of survivors in the show go from remembering a Simpsons episode around a campfire, to 7 years later when they have formed a travelling theatre troupe to perform episodes of The Simpsons, to 75 years after that when their show has become a grand, masked musical theatre performance.

As a contributor, you will be helping this production happen. Busted Space is an entirely student-run organization, so therefore, we don't have any overhead. Donations to this show would help us make better sets and props to enhance our production and do this amazing script justice. 

What We Need & What You Get

For this production, we've budgeted out $500. This budget is going to cover payment of rights, printing of marketing materials, lighting fixture rental, dramaturgical display printing, costumes, props, and IndieGoGo fees. While we don't expect to come in under budget, if we happen to have extra funds after the production, they will be donated to the Department of Theatre and Dance at Ball State for Student Scholarships.

We have a lot of fun perks for this project, including social media shout outs, signed posters, a pizza party with the cast, and the masks of Simpsons characters used in Act 3 of the show! Be sure to check them out and donate to the perk that you find most exciting!

The Impact

We're students. We're not interested in making money off of this show. So, any profit made on this production will be donated to the Department of Theatre and Dance at Ball State to go to Student Scholarships.

Our production offers many opportunities for directors, dramaturgs, actors, and designers. By funding this project, you are helping Undergraduates in the Department of Theatre and Dance to gain more experience before we graduate and head into the real world. 

Risks & Challenges

There are no more significant hurdles than there are for any other theatrical performance. Props break, accidents happen, but I would call myself a bad member of the Ball State Department of Theatre and Dance if I said that I wasn't able to handle a crisis. 

With our cast of 8 actors, 3 understudies, 2 assistant directors, 2 stage managers, and production team of about 8 more, I can confidently say that any accidents or unfortunate events will be ably taken care of.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that everyone may not be able to contribute monetarily to our show. And that's fine! If you find yourself in this boat and still want to help out, please share our campaign on social media so we can reach more people!

story:
Teri and Oliver Steele have been a part of New York’s Dance landscape for the past 20 years, as dancers, teachers, choreographers and mentors.  

They founded Steeledance in 1995 and have surrounded themselves with an eclectic group of artists who constantly inspire and push them to grow and create work worthy of their time and talents.

WE ARE AIMING TO RAISE:

$10,000 in 20 days in celebration of our 20th Anniversary Season May 2, 9, 10 at the Salvatore Capezio Theater. 

We are in the process of creating a world premiere for this special anniversary  entitled Devastating Beauty. 

The new work features our stunning current steeledancers as well as veteran cast members and new talent - 20 years - 20 dancers. 

We are exploring themes on human relationships and how we relate to and interpret the concept of beauty. In true Steeledance form—theatrics, visual design, and costuming—will play an integral part in this creation. 

Contributions will go towards costuming, lighting design, dancers pay, marketing, rehearsal space, and basically helping us make it gorgeous.

WATCH US IN REHEARSAL:


Devastating Beauty takes on new challenges for the Steeles as they develop the role of fabric in the work. The fabric layers the vision with a unique tactile component from exorbitant costumes built onto the dancers onstage, to flowing large pieces used to create separate spaces. 

 In this work, they are likening fabric to the skin of one as we age--the perceptions of beauty, the acceptance or defiance of age and the changes it brings. Teri and Oliver explore what is means to maintain and refine beauty in movement as one matures. This is a personal issue, clearly :-)

With your support we can get even closer to producing a fully realized production and compensate the collaborating artists who are making it happen. 

We are using IndieGoGo to get us closer to an overall budget of $30,000

RISKS AND CHALLENGES:

As a small dance company in New York City there are many challenges we face. The biggest risk for us right now is not actualizing the work in the fullest way it is intended. With a very minimal staff we are trying to juggle many balls, keep our heads on straight, and produce a fully conceived show for this huge milestone in our careers. 

We simply cannot make this happen without the support of those who love art, and those who are interested in the sustainability and evolution of the field.

Teri L. Steele / Steeledance is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community.Contributions to The Field earmarked for Teri L. Steele / Steeledance are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038,
phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our nationalcharities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Click Aquí para Español! 

What is Havana Love Letters?

  • Havana Love Letters is a new ballet with an original score, and the first collaboration between Cuba’s Institute of the Arts (the famed El ISA)  and a team of artists from the U.S. 
  • Havana Love Letters  brings Cuban dancers together with choreographer Suki John, composer Joel Diamond, scenic designer Brian Clinnin and costume designer Murell Horton.

  • In June 2016, Havana Love Letters will workshop at Cuba's Teatro Bertolt Brecht as part of the Festival of the Arts. 

Havana Love Letters is actively developing cultural relations between the US and Cuba!

  • Help us extend an olive branch through dance, one of the most basic forms of human communication!
  • The production process will be filmed and photographed, so this historic collaboration can be shared on the screen as well as the stage. Once the ballet has been developed, it will be available for professional companies in Cuba and the U.S.

Magnitude of This Collaboration 

  • A project of this size and scope builds cooperation between our two peoples, who have been kept apart for far too long.
  • Dance goes far beyond the spoken word, communicating across language and distance. Havana Love Letters - or Cartas de Amor as it is titled in Cuba - creates a bridge across time and cultures. 

Our Funding Goals

  • Our goal is to raise $10,000 with this platform. The funds raised here will pay for transportation, housing for our team, costumes and set elements.
  • Meeting this goal guarantees that Cuban drivers, translators and filmmakers who are not paid by El ISA will be compensated fairly for their work on the project.

Inspirations

  • Havana Love Letters is inspired by Havana itself, by Cuban dancers and musicians, by poet Nicolas Guillén, painter Wilfredo Lam, and author Gabriel Garcia Márquez. Joel Diamond and Suki John have created six ballets together with Cuban dance companies such as Ballet Nacional de Cuba, Danza Contemporánea, Narciso Medina, and Danza Espiral.

Risks & Challenges

  • As diplomacy and international developments ebb and flow between the US and Cuba, this project offers an exciting opportunity to establish enduring cultural exchange through one of Cuba's favorite art forms: dance. 
  • As of now, there is still no government funding for artistic projects in Cuba -- so WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Ways You Can Help

  • No gift is too small! 
  • By supporting this cause you are actively helping develop cultural relations between the US and Cuba.

If you are unable to contribute, we encourage you to make some noise on social media about this campaign and use the IndieGoGo share tools to help us spread the word!



Español

¿Qué es La Habana Cartas de Amor?

La Habana Cartas de Amor es una nuevo choreodrama, o ballet narrativo, que se estrenará durante el festival Días de la Danza de La Habana, Cuba en abril 2016.  

En una colaboración sin precedentes, un grupo de artistas de EEUU se une a los bailarines, músicos y diseñadores excepcionales del Instituto Superior del Arte (El ISA, algo asi como el Julliard de Cuba).  La Habana Love Letters explora la naturaleza voluble y perdurable del amor - que ofrece el romance, la esperanza y la paciencia - ideales importantes en estos tiempos de cambio entre nuestros dos pueblos.

La Habana Love Letters, Inc. es una organización de voluntarios sin fines de lucro formada y administrada en Fort Worth, Texas, con una red de voluntarios operando de costa a costa.  Los fondos recaudados se destinarán a la preparación preliminar del proyecto de actuación, que luego tomará forma definitiva en La Habana y se presentará durante el festival Días de la Danza.

Antecedentes sobre este proyecto

Hace veintidós años la famosa bailarina Alicia Alonso encargó a la coreógrafa Suki John un ballet para el Ballet Nacional de Cuba.  Con tal fin, Suki encargó la música  al compositor Joel Diamond, quien escribió una esplendida partitura en tan solo una semana.  Como resultado de esta colaboración, se estrenó Después de Pandora, en el Gran Teatro de La Habana en 1993.

Dos años más tarde Suki y Joel volvieron a colaborar en la creación del ballet BarrigaBestia para la Compañía de Danza de Narciso Medina, presentada durante el primer Festival de La Habana de la danza moderna: Dias de la Danza. Y empezaron a imaginar otro ballet - La Habana Love Letters. 

En 2016, Dias de la Danza celebra 20 años como festival de un mes de la danza contemporánea.  La Habana Love Letters será la primera coproducción entre El ISA, Juilliard de Cuba, y un equipo de artistas norteamericanos. Esta colaboración sin precedentes es ideal para la construcción de puentes y el intercambio intercultural entre EEUU y Cuba.

Ninguna contribución es pequeña. Al apoyar este proyecto, usted está ayudando activamente a promover las relaciones culturales entre Estados Unidos y Cuba. Si no puede contribuir, por favor ayúdenos promoviendo y compartiendo esta campaña en las redes sociales. Gracias!

En 2016, Dias de la Danza celebra 20 años como festival de un mes de la danza contemporánea.  La Habana Love Letters será la primera coproducción entre El ISA, Juilliard de Cuba, y un equipo de artistas norteamericanos. Esta colaboración sin precedentes es ideal para la construcción de puentes y el intercambio intercultural entre EEUU y Cuba.Ninguna contribución es pequeña. Al apoyar este proyecto, usted está ayudando activamente a promover las relaciones culturales entre Estados Unidos y Cuba. Si no puede contribuir, por favor ayúdenos promoviendo y compartiendo esta campaña en las redes sociales. Gracias!
